column4: Reprocessed Mariner 10 data was used to produce this image of Mercury. The smooth band is an area of which no images were taken.]]-->

date=March 2014}}: robotic]] [[space probe]] launched by [[NASA]] on 3 November 1973, to fly by the planets [[Mercury (planet)
column3: Mercury]] and [[Venus]]. It was the first spacecraft to perform flybys of multiple planets.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=Beyond Earth: A Chronicle of Deep Space Exploration, 1958–2016

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: ''Mariner 10'' was launched approximately two years after ''[[Mariner 9]]'' and was the last spacecraft in the [[Mariner program]]. (Mariner 11 and 12 were allocated to the [[Voyager program]] and redesignated ''[[Voyager 1]]'' and ''[[Voyager 2]]''.)

The mission objectives were to measure Mercury's environment, atmosphere, surface, and body characteristics and to make similar investigations of Venus. Secondary objectives were to perform experiments in the [[interplanetary medium]] and to obtain experience with a dual-planet [[gravity assist]] mission. ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s science team was led by [[Bruce C. Murray]] at the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]].<ref name=Schudel>{{cite news
column4: title=Bruce C. Murray, NASA space scientist, dies at 81

An artists' impression of the ''Mariner 10'' mission. The first mission to perform a [[gravity assist]], it used a flyby of the planet [[Venus]] in order to decrease its perihelion. This would allow the spacecraft to meet Mercury on three occasions in 1974 and 1975.]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: ''Mariner 10'' was the first spacecraft to make use of an interplanetary [[gravitational slingshot]] maneuver, using Venus to bend its flight path and bring its [[perihelion]] down to the level of Mercury's orbit.<ref name=\"Mission Overview\">{{cite web
column8: title=Beyond Earth: A Chronicle of Deep Space Exploration, 1958–2016
column19: location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref> This maneuver, inspired by the [[orbital mechanics]] calculations of the Italian scientist [[Giuseppe Colombo]], put the spacecraft into an orbit that repeatedly brought it back to Mercury. ''Mariner 10'' used the solar [[radiation pressure]] on its [[Photovoltaic module
column20: solar panel]]s and its high-gain antenna as a means of [[attitude control]] during flight, the first spacecraft to use active solar pressure control.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The components on ''Mariner 10'' can be categorized into four groups based on their common function. The solar panels, power subsystem, attitude control subsystem, and the computer kept the spacecraft operating properly during the flight. The navigational system, including the hydrazine rocket, would keep ''Mariner 10'' on track to Venus and Mercury. Several scientific instruments would collect data at the two planets. Finally, the antennas would transmit this data to the [[Deep Space Network]] back on Earth, as well as receive commands from Mission Control. ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s various components and scientific instruments were attached to a central hub, which was roughly the shape of an octagonal prism. The hub stored the spacecraft's internal electronics.<ref name=\"NSSDC\"/><ref>Clark 2007, pp. 22-23 </ref><ref name=\"Strom16\"/> The Mariner 10 spacecraft was manufactured by Boeing.<ref name=\"Mariner 10 Quicklook\">{{cite web
column4: accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref> NASA set a strict limit of US$98 million for Mariner 10's total cost, which marked the first time the agency subjected a mission to an inflexible budget constraint. No overruns would be tolerated, so mission planners carefully considered cost efficiency when designing the spacecraft's instruments.<ref>Reeves 1994, p. 222</ref> Cost control was primarily accomplished by executing contract work closer to the launch date than was recommended by normal mission schedules, as reducing the length of available work time increased cost efficiency. Despite the rushed schedule, very few deadlines were missed.<ref name=\"Biggs\"/> The mission ended up about US$1 million under budget.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 142</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: [[Attitude control]] is needed to keep a spacecraft's instruments and antennas aimed in the correct direction.<ref>{{cite web
column12: accessdate=24 July 2015}}</ref> During course maneuvers, a spacecraft may need to rotate so that its rocket faces the proper direction before being fired. ''Mariner 10'' determined its attitude using two optical sensors, one pointed at the Sun, and the other at a bright star, usually Canopus; additionally, the probe's three [[gyroscopes]] provided a second option for calculating the attitude. Nitrogen gas thrusters were used to adjust ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s orientation along three axes.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1977, p. 58</ref><ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 50</ref><ref>{{cite book
column18: title=On Mars: Exploration of the Red Planet 1958-1978

column7: jfm=}}</ref> The spacecraft's electronics were intricate and complex: it contained over 32,000 pieces of circuitry, of which resistors, capacitors, diodes, microcircuits, and transistors were the most common devices.<ref name=\"Paul\"/> Commands for the instruments could be stored on ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s computer, but were limited to 512 words. The rest had to be broadcast by the Mission Sequence Working Group from Earth.<ref name=\"Shirley\">{{cite journal
column11: title=The Mariner 10 Mission to Venus and Mercury
column28: bibcode= 2003AcAau..53..375S}}</ref> Supplying the spacecraft components with power required modifying the electrical output of the solar panels. The power subsystem used two redundant sets of circuitry, each containing a booster regulator and an [[inverter]], to convert the panels' [[direct current
column30: AC]] and alter the voltage to the necessary level.<ref>{{cite web
column34: title=A historical overview of the electrical power systems in the US manned and some US unmanned spacecraft
column42: accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref> The subsystem could store up to 20 [[ampere hours]] of electricity on a 39 volt [[Nickel–cadmium battery

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The flyby past Mercury posed major technical challenges for scientists to overcome. Due to Mercury's proximity to the Sun, ''Mariner 10'' would have to endure 4.5 times more [[solar radiation]] than when it departed Earth; compared to previous Mariner missions, spacecraft parts needed extra shielding against the heat. Thermal blankets and a sunshade were installed on the main body. After evaluating different choices for the sunshade cloth material, mission planners chose [[beta cloth]], a combination of aluminized [[Kapton]] and glass-fiber sheets treated with [[Teflon]].<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 32–33</ref> However, solar shielding was unfeasible for some of ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s other components. ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s two solar panels needed to be kept under 115 °C. Covering the panels would defeat their purpose of producing electricity. The solution was to add an adjustable tilt to the panels, so the angle at which they faced the sun could be changed. Engineers considered folding the panels toward each other, making a V-shape with the main body, but tests found this approach had the potential to overheat the rest of the spacecraft. The alternative chosen was to mount the solar panels in a line and tilt them along that axis, which had the added benefit of increasing the efficiency of the spacecraft's nitrogen jet thrusters, which could now be placed on the panel tips. The panels could be rotated a maximum of 76°.<ref name=\"Strom16\">Strom and Sprague 2003, p. 16</ref><ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 21</ref> Additionally, ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s hydrazine rocket nozzle had to face the Sun to function properly, but scientists rejected covering the nozzle with a thermal door as an undependable solution. Instead, a special paint was applied to exposed parts on the rocket so as to reduce heat flow from the nozzle to the delicate instruments on the spacecraft.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 30–32</ref>

Accurately performing the gravity assist at Venus posed another hurdle.<ref>Reeves 1994, p. 242</ref> If ''Mariner 10'' was to maintain a course to Mercury, its trajectory could deviate no more than {{convert
column3: km}} from a critical point in the vicinity of Venus.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 56</ref> To ensure that the necessary course corrections could be made, mission planners tripled the amount of [[hydrazine]] fuel Mariner 10 would carry, and also equipped the spacecraft with more nitrogen gas for the thrusters than the previous Mariner mission had held. These upgrades proved crucial in enabling the second and third Mercury flybys.<ref name=\"MB25\">Murray and Burgess 1977, pp. 25–26</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The mission still lacked the ultimate safeguard: a sister spacecraft. It was common for probes to be launched in pairs, with complete redundancy to guard against the failure of one or the other.<ref>Strom and Sprague 2003, p. 14</ref> The budget constraint ruled this option out. Even though mission planners stayed sufficiently under budget to divert some funding for constructing a backup spacecraft, the budget did not permit both to be launched at the same time. In the event that Mariner 10 failed, NASA would only allow the backup to be launched if the fatal error was diagnosed and fixed; this would have to be completed in the two-and-a-half weeks between the scheduled launch on 3 November 1973 and the last possible launch date of 21 November 1973.<ref name=\"MB25\"/><ref name=\"MB38\"/> (The unused backup was sent to the Smithsonian museum)

column4: An illustration showing the instruments of ''Mariner 10''.]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: ''Mariner 10'' conducted seven experiments at Venus and Mercury. Six of these experiments had a dedicated scientific instrument to collect data.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p.19</ref> The experiments and instruments were designed by research laboratories and educational institutions from across the United States.<ref>Giberson and Cunningham 1975, p. 719</ref> Out of forty-six submissions, JPL selected seven experiments on the basis of maximizing science return without exceeding cost guidelines: together, the seven scientific experiments cost US12.6 million dollars, about one-eighth of the total mission budget.<ref name=\"Biggs\">{{Citation
column8: title=Mariner Venus/Mercury '73: A Strategy of Cost Control
column13: publisher=The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The imaging system, the Television Photography Experiment, consisted of two {{convert
column4: Cassegrain]] telescopes feeding [[vidicon]] tubes.<ref name=nssdccam>[https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=1973-085A-01 NASA/NSSDC – Mariner 10 – Television Photography]</ref> The main telescope could be bypassed to a smaller wide angle optic, but using the same tube.<ref name=nssdccam/> It had an 8-position filter wheel, with one position occupied by a mirror for the wide-angle bypass.<ref name=nssdccam/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The entire imaging system was imperiled when electric heaters attached to the cameras failed to turn on immediately after launch. To avoid the Sun's damaging heat, the cameras were deliberately placed on the spacecraft side facing away from the Sun. Consequently, the heaters were needed to prevent the cameras from losing heat and become so cold that they would become damaged. JPL engineers found that the vidicons could generate enough heat through normal operation to stay just above the critical temperature of -40 °C; therefore they advised against turning off the cameras during the flight. Test photos of the Earth and Moon showed that image quality had not been significantly affected.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, pp. 43–48</ref> The mission team was pleasantly surprised when the camera heaters started working on 17 January 1974, two months after launch.<ref>{{cite journal
column26: title=Bulletin No. 14: TCM-2 Performance Superb TV Heaters Have Come On
column33: accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref> Later investigation concluded that a short circuit in a different location on the probe had prevented the heater from turning on. This allowed the vidicons to be turned off as needed.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 57–58</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Of the six main scientific instruments, the {{convert
column3: kg}} cameras were by far the most massive device. Requiring 67 watts of electricity, the cameras consumed more power than the other five instruments combined.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/> The system returned about 7000 photographs of Mercury and Venus during Mariner 10's flybys.<ref name=nssdccam/>

date=March 2014}}: infrared radiation]] given off by the surface of Mercury and the atmosphere of Venus, from which the temperature could be calculated. How quickly the surface lost heat as it rotated into the planet's dark side revealed aspects about the composition of the surface, such as whether it was made out of rocks, or out of finer particles.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 21-22</ref><ref name=\"Strom-18-19\"/> The infrared radiometer contained a pair of Cassegrain telescopes fixed at an angle of 120° to each other and a pair of detectors made from antimony-bismuth [[thermopile]]s. The instrument was designed to measure temperatures as cold as -193 °C and as hot as 427 °C. Stillman C. Chase, Jr. of the Santa Barbara Research Center headed the infrared radiometer experiment.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\">{{cite book

spectrometers]] were involved in this experiment, one to measure UV absorption, the other to sense UV emissions. The occultation spectrometer scanned Mercury's edge as it passed in front of the Sun, and detected whether solar ultraviolet radiation was absorbed in certain wavelengths, which would indicate the presence of gas particles, and therefore an atmosphere.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 25-26</ref> The [[airglow]] spectrometer detected extreme ultraviolet radiation emanating from atoms of gaseous hydrogen, helium, carbon, oxygen, neon, and argon.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/><ref>Rothery 2015, p. 26</ref> Unlike the occultation spectrometer, it did not require backlighting from the Sun and could move along with the rotatable scan platform on the spacecraft. The experiment's most important goal was to ascertain whether Mercury had an atmosphere, but would also gather data at Earth and Venus and study the interstellar background radiation.<ref name=\"Strom-18-19\">Strom and Sprague 2003, pp. 18-19</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The plasma experiment's goal was to study the ionized gases ([[Plasma (physics)
date=March 2014}}: plasma]]) of the solar wind, the temperature and density of its electrons, and how the planets affected the velocity of the plasma stream.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Scanning Electrostatic Analyzer and Electron Spectrometer
column13: accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref> The experiment contained two components, facing in opposite directions. The Scanning Electrostatic Analyzer was aimed toward the Sun and could detect positive ions and electrons, which were separated by a set of three concentric hemispherical plates. The Scanning Electron Spectrometer has aimed away from the Sun, and detected only electrons, using just one hemispherical plate. The instruments could be rotated about 60° to either side.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/> By gathering data on the solar wind's movement around Mercury, the plasma experiment could be used to verify the magnetometer's observations of Mercury's magnetic field.<ref name=\"Strom-18-19\"/> Using the plasma detectors, Mariner 10 gathered the first ''in situ'' solar wind data from inside Venus' orbit.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 22-23</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Shortly after launch, scientists found that the Scanning Electrostatic Analyzer had failed because a door shielding the analyzer did not open. An unsuccessful attempt was made to forcibly unfasten the door with the first course correction maneuver.<ref name=\"No. 7\">{{cite web
column5: title=Bulletin No. 7: First Trajectory Correction Maneuver A Success
column12: accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref> The experiment operators had planned to observe the directions taken by positive ions prior to the ions' collision with the Analyzer, but this data was lost.<ref name=\"No. 15\">{{cite web
column16: title=Bulletin No. 15: Venus Flyby Set For Tuesday at 10:01 A.M. PT
column23: accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref> The experiment was still able to collect some data using the properly functioning Scanning Electron Spectrometer.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 47</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The goal of the charged particles experiment was to observe how the [[heliosphere]] interacted with [[Cosmic ray
date=March 2014}}: cosmic radiation]].<ref name=\"Strom and Sprague 2003, pp. 19\">Strom and Sprague 2003, p. 19 </ref> In connection with the plasma detectors and magnetometers, this experiment had the potential to provide additional evidence of a magnetic field around Mercury,<ref>Rothery 2015, p. 28</ref> by showing whether such a field had captured charged particles.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/> Two telescopes were used to collect highly energetic electrons and atomic nuclei, specifically oxygen nuclei or less massive.<ref name=\"Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 24\">Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 24</ref> These particles then passed through a set of detectors and were counted.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Two fluxgate magnetometers were entrusted with discerning whether Mercury produced a [[Magnetosphere
date=March 2014}}: magnetic field]],<ref>Rothery 2015, p. 27</ref> and studying the interplanetary magnetic field between flybys.<ref name=\"Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 24\"/> In designing this experiment, scientists had to account for interference from the magnetic field generated by Mariner 10's many electronic parts. For this reason, the magnetometers had to be situated on a long boom, one closer to the octagonal hub, the other one further away. Data from the two magnetometers would be cross-referenced to filter out the spacecraft's own magnetic field.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 95</ref> Drastically weakening the probe's magnetic field would have increased costs.<ref name=\"Shirley\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: This experiment investigated the mass and gravitational characteristics of Mercury. It was of particular interest because of the planet's closeness to the Sun, large orbital eccentricity, and unusual spin-orbit resonance.<ref name=NASAHistory/>

As the spacecraft passed behind Mercury on the first encounter there was an opportunity to probe the atmosphere and to measure the radius of the planet. By observing phase changes in the S-band radio signal, measurements of the atmosphere could be made. The atmosphere was assessed as having a density of about {{val
column4: u=molecules per cm<sup>3</sup>}}.<ref name=NASAHistory>[https://history.nasa.gov/SP-423/ mariner.htm History article on Mariner 10 at history.nasa.gov]</ref>
''Mariner 10'' imaged the Earth and Moon shortly after launch.]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Boeing finished building the spacecraft at the end of June 1973, and ''Mariner 10'' was delivered from Seattle to JPL's headquarters in California, where JPL comprehensively tested the integrity of the spacecraft and its instruments. After the tests were finished, the probe was transported to the [[Eastern Test Range]] in Florida, the launch site. Technicians filled a tank on the spacecraft with {{convert
column3: kg}} of hydrazine fuel so that the probe could make course corrections, and attached [[Squib (explosive)
column4: squibs]], whose detonation would signal ''Mariner 10'' to exit the launch rocket and deploy its instruments.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 42</ref><ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, pp. 36-37</ref> The planned gravity assist at Venus made it feasible to use an [[Atlas-Centaur]] rocket instead of a more powerful but more expensive [[Titan IIIC]].<ref name=\"Paul\">{{cite web
column8: title=Technical Memorandum 33-759: A Study of Mariner 10 Flight Experiences and Some Flight Piece Part Failure Rate Computations

date=March 2014}}: accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"Strom,14\">Strom and Sprague 2003, pp. 14-16</ref> The probe and the Atlas-Centaur were attached together ten days prior to liftoff. Launch posed one of the largest risks of failure for the ''Mariner 10'' mission; [[Mariner 1]], [[Mariner 3]], and [[Mariner 8]] all failed minutes after lift-off due to either engineering failures or Atlas rocket malfunctions.<ref name=\"MB38\">Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 38</ref><ref>{{cite web

column6: accessdate=22 August 2015}}</ref> The mission had a launch period of about a month in length, from 16 October 1973, to 21 November 1973. NASA chose 3 November as the launch date because it would optimize imaging conditions when the spacecraft arrived at Mercury.<ref name=\"Strom,14\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On 3 November at 17:45 UTC, the Atlas-Centaur carrying ''Mariner 10'' lifted off from pad [[Spaceport Florida Launch Complex 36
column5: website=NASA Space Science Data Coordinated Archive
column6: access-date=November 2, 2019}}</ref> The Atlas stage burned for around four minutes, after which it was jettisoned, and the Centaur stage took over for an additional five minutes, propelling ''Mariner 10'' to a [[parking orbit]]. The temporary orbit took the spacecraft one-third of the distance around Earth: this maneuver was needed to reach the correct spot for a second burn by the Centaur engines, which set ''Mariner 10'' on a path towards Venus. The probe then separated from the rocket; subsequently, the Centaur stage diverted away to avoid the possibility of a future collision. Never before had a planetary mission depended upon two separate rocket burns during the launch, and even with ''Mariner 10'', scientists initially viewed the maneuver as too risky.<ref>{{cite book

date=March 2014}}: title=Taming Liquid Hydrogen: The Centaur Upper Stage Rocket 1958-2002

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: During its first week of flight, the ''Mariner 10'' camera system was tested by taking five [[Panoramic photography
date=March 2014}}: photographic mosaics]] of the [[Earth]] and six of the [[Moon]]. It also obtained photographs of the north polar region of the Moon where prior coverage was poor. These photographs provided a basis for cartographers to update lunar maps and improve the [[Selenographic coordinates
column3: lunar control net]].<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 47–53.</ref>

column4: The trajectory of ''Mariner 10'' spacecraft: since launch on 3 November 1973, to first fly-by of Mercury on 29 March 1974.]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Far from being an uneventful cruise, ''Mariner 10''{{’}}s three-month journey to Venus was fraught with technical malfunctions, which kept mission control on edge.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 55</ref> [[Donna Shirley]] recounted her team's frustration: \"It seemed as if we were always just patching Mariner 10 together long enough to get it on to the next phase and next crisis\".<ref>Shirley 1998, p. 91 </ref> A trajectory correction maneuver was made on 13 November 1973. Immediately afterward, the star-tracker locked onto a bright flake of paint which had come off the spacecraft and lost tracking on the guide star [[Canopus]]. An automated safety protocol recovered Canopus, but the problem of flaking paint recurred throughout the mission. The on-board computer also experienced unscheduled resets occasionally, which necessitated reconfiguring the clock sequence and subsystems. Periodic problems with the high-gain antenna also occurred during the cruise. On 8 January 1974, a malfunction thought to be caused by a short-circuited diode occurred in the power subsystem.<ref name=\"Paul\"/> As a result, the main booster regulator and inverter failed, leaving the spacecraft dependent on the redundant regulator. Mission planners feared that the same problem could recur in the redundant system and cripple the spacecraft.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 55</ref>
In January 1974, ''Mariner 10'' made ultraviolet observations of [[Comet Kohoutek]]. Another mid-course correction was made on 21 January 1974.
The spacecraft passed Venus on 5 February 1974, the closest approach being {{convert
column3: km}} at 17:01 UTC. It was the twelfth spacecraft to reach Venus and the eighth to return data from the planet,<ref>{{cite web
column14: url-status=dead}}</ref> as well as the first mission to succeed in broadcasting images of Venus back to Earth.<ref name=\"Ulivi181\">Ulivi and Harland 2007, p. 181</ref> ''Mariner 10'' built upon observations made by ''Mariner 5'' six years earlier; importantly, ''Mariner 10'' had a camera whereas the prior mission lacked one.<ref name=\"Reeves 1994, p. 244\">Reeves 1994, p. 244</ref> As ''Mariner 10'' veered around Venus, from the planet's night side to daylight, the cameras snapped the probe's first image of Venus, showing an illuminated arc of clouds over the north pole emerging from darkness. Engineers initially feared that the star-tracker could mistake the much brighter Venus for Canopus, repeating the mishaps with flaking paint. However, the star-tracker did not malfunction. Earth occultation occurred between 17:07 and 17:11 UTC, during which the spacecraft transmitted X-band radio waves through Venus' atmosphere, gathering data on cloud structure and temperature.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, pp. 61-64</ref><ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 61-63</ref> Although Venus's cloud cover is nearly featureless in visible light, it was discovered that extensive cloud detail could be seen through Mariner's ultraviolet camera filters. Earth-based ultra-violet observation had shown some indistinct blotching even before ''Mariner 10'', but the detail seen by Mariner was a surprise to most researchers. The probe continued photographing Venus until 13 February 1974.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 79 </ref> Among the encounter's 4165 acquired photographs, one resulting series of images captured a thick and distinctly patterned atmosphere making a full revolution every four days,<ref name=\"Reeves 1994, p. 244\"/> just as terrestrial observations had suggested.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 68</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The mission revealed the composition and meteorological nature of the atmosphere of Venus. Data from the radio science experiment measured the extent to which radio waves passing through the atmosphere were refracted, which was used to calculate the density, pressure, and temperature of the atmosphere at any given altitude.<ref name=\"Howard\">{{cite journal
column43: title=Venus: Mass, Gravity Field, Atmosphere, and Ionosphere as Measured by the Mariner 10 Dual-Frequency Radio System
column48: publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science
column59: jfm=
column61: bibcode=1974Sci...183.1297H}}</ref> Overall, atmospheric temperature is higher closer to the planet's surface, but ''Mariner 10'' found four altitudes where the pattern was reversed, which could signify the presence of a layer of clouds.<ref name=\"DB65\">Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 65</ref> The inversions occurred at the 56, 61, 63, and 81 km levels,<ref>Giberson and Cunningham 1975, p. 726</ref> confirming previous observations made by the ''Mariner 5'' encounter.<ref name=\"Howard\"/> The ultraviolet spectrometers identified the chemical substances that comprise Venus' atmosphere.<ref>Giberson and Cunningham 1975, p. 725</ref> The elevated concentration of atomic oxygen in the upper atmosphere showed that the atmosphere is stratified into upper and lower layers that do not mix with each other; photographs of the upper and lower cloud layers corroborated this hypothesis.<ref name=\"DB65\"/> ''Mariner 10''{{’}}s ultraviolet photographs were an invaluable information source for studying the churning clouds of Venus' atmosphere. The mission researchers believed the cloud features they photographed were located in the stratosphere and upper troposphere, created by condensation; they also concluded that the contrast between darker and lighter features was due to differences in the cloud's absorptivity of UV light.<ref name=\"Murray-Belton\">{{cite journal
column83: title=Venus: Atmospheric Motion and Structure from Mariner 10 Pictures
column88: publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science
column101: bibcode=1974Sci...183.1307M}}</ref> The subsolar region was of particular interest: as the sun is straight overhead, it imparts more solar energy to this area than other part of the planet. Compared to the rest of the planet's atmosphere, the subsolar region was highly active and irregular. \"Cells\" of air lifted by convection, each up to {{convert
column103: km}} wide, were observed forming and dissipating within the span of a few hours; some had polygonal outlines.<ref name=\"Murray-Belton\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The gravity assist was also a success, coming well within the acceptable margin for error. In the four hours between 16:00 and 20:00 UTC on 5 February 1974, ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s heliocentric velocity dropped from {{convert
column15: title=Bulletin No. 18: Mariner 10 Enroute to Mercury - Continues Query of Venus
column22: accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref> This changed the shape of the spacecraft's elliptical orbit around the Sun,<ref name=\"Ulivi181\"/> so that the perihelion now coincided with the orbit of Mercury.<ref name=\"No. 18\"/>

column4: Venus in real colors, processed from clear and blue filtered ''Mariner 10'' images Venus as captured by Mariner 10.jpg
column5: ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s photograph of Venus in [[ultraviolet]] light (photo color-enhanced to simulate Venus's natural color as the human eye would see it)</gallery>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The spacecraft flew past Mercury three times. The first Mercury encounter took place at 20:47 [[Universal Time
date=March 2014}}: UTC]] on 29 March 1974,<!--- JD 2442115.5 --->at a range of {{convert
column4: km}}, passing on the shadow side.<ref name=\"Mission Overview\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: After looping once around the [[Sun]] while Mercury completed two orbits, ''Mariner 10'' flew by Mercury again on 21 September 1974,<!--- JD 2442311.5 = 196 days later ---> at a more distant range of {{convert
column3: km}} below the southern hemisphere.<ref name=\"Mission Overview\"/>

date=March 2014}}: A mosaic of images from the second encounter, covering the equator to the south pole.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: After losing roll control in October 1974, a third and final encounter, the closest to Mercury, took place on 16 March 1975,<!--- JD 2442487.5 = 176 days later, 20 days early ---> at a range of {{convert
column3: km}}, passing almost over the north pole.<ref name=\"Mission Overview\"/>

date=March 2014}}: A prominent scarp, [[Discovery Rupes]], photographed during the first flyby.
Representation of the thrust fault at Discovery Rupes

column3: Schubert]] basin, 190 km in diameter, filled by smooth plains. The basin's hummocky rim is partly degraded and cratered by later events.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: With its maneuvering gas just about exhausted, ''Mariner 10'' started another orbit of the Sun. Engineering tests were continued until 24 March 1975,<ref name=\"Mission Overview\"/> when final depletion of the nitrogen supply was signaled by the onset of an un-programmed pitch turn. Commands were sent immediately to the spacecraft to turn off its transmitter, and radio signals to Earth ceased.

date=March 2014}}: orbiting the Sun]], although its electronics have probably been damaged by the Sun's radiation.<ref>[http://www.space.com/18301-mariner-10.html  Elizabeth Howell, SPACE.com Contributor Article on mariner-10 at space.com]</ref> ''Mariner 10'' has not been spotted or tracked from Earth since it stopped transmitting. The only ways it would not be orbiting would be if it had been hit by an asteroid or gravitationally perturbed by a close encounter with a large body.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: During its flyby of Venus, ''Mariner 10'' discovered evidence of rotating clouds and a very weak magnetic field. Using a near-[[ultraviolet]] filter, it photographed Venus's [[Cirrus uncinus cloud
date=March 2014}}: chevron clouds]] and performed other [[celestial body's atmosphere

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The spacecraft flew past Mercury three times. Owing to the geometry of its orbit – its orbital period was almost exactly twice Mercury's – the same side of Mercury was sunlit each time, so it was only able to [[map]] 40–45% of Mercury's surface, taking over 2800 photos. It revealed a more or less Moon-like surface. It thus contributed enormously to our understanding of Mercury, whose surface had not been successfully resolved through telescopic observation. The regions mapped included most or all of the Shakespeare, Beethoven, Kuiper, Michelangelo, Tolstoj, and Discovery [[list of quadrangles on Mercury
date=March 2014}}: quadrangle]]s, half of Bach and Victoria quadrangles, and small portions of Solitudo Persephones (later Neruda), Liguria (later Raditladi), and Borealis quadrangles.<ref name=\"h8.pdf\">{{cite book
column4: title=Geologic Map of the Tolstoj (H-8) Quadrangle of Mercury
column9: id=USGS Miscellaneous Investigations Series Map I–1199, as part of the Atlas of Mercury, 1:5,000,000 Geologic Series

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: ''Mariner 10'' also discovered that Mercury has a tenuous [[Atmosphere of Mercury
date=March 2014}}: atmosphere]] consisting primarily of [[helium]], as well as a [[magnetic field]] and a large iron-rich [[planetary core
column3: core]]. Its radiometer readings suggested that Mercury has a nighttime temperature of −183 °C (−297 [[Fahrenheit

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Planning for ''[[MESSENGER]]'', a spacecraft that surveyed Mercury until 2015, relied extensively on data and information collected by ''Mariner 10''.

Scroll down to click on the \"Table of Contents\" link. [https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19780019203_1978019203.pdf PDF version]

date=March 2014}}: robotic]] [[space probe]] launched by [[NASA]] on 3 November 1973, to fly by the planets [[Mercury (planet)
column3: Mercury]] and [[Venus]]. It was the first spacecraft to perform flybys of multiple planets.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=Beyond Earth: A Chronicle of Deep Space Exploration, 1958–2016

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: ''Mariner 10'' was launched approximately two years after ''[[Mariner 9]]'' and was the last spacecraft in the [[Mariner program]]. (Mariner 11 and 12 were allocated to the [[Voyager program]] and redesignated ''[[Voyager 1]]'' and ''[[Voyager 2]]''.)

The mission objectives were to measure Mercury's environment, atmosphere, surface, and body characteristics and to make similar investigations of Venus. Secondary objectives were to perform experiments in the [[interplanetary medium]] and to obtain experience with a dual-planet [[gravity assist]] mission. ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s science team was led by [[Bruce C. Murray]] at the [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]].<ref name=Schudel>{{cite news
column4: title=Bruce C. Murray, NASA space scientist, dies at 81

An artists' impression of the ''Mariner 10'' mission. The first mission to perform a [[gravity assist]], it used a flyby of the planet [[Venus]] in order to decrease its perihelion. This would allow the spacecraft to meet Mercury on three occasions in 1974 and 1975.]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: ''Mariner 10'' was the first spacecraft to make use of an interplanetary [[gravitational slingshot]] maneuver, using Venus to bend its flight path and bring its [[perihelion]] down to the level of Mercury's orbit.<ref name=\"Mission Overview\">{{cite web
column8: title=Beyond Earth: A Chronicle of Deep Space Exploration, 1958–2016
column19: location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref> This maneuver, inspired by the [[orbital mechanics]] calculations of the Italian scientist [[Giuseppe Colombo]], put the spacecraft into an orbit that repeatedly brought it back to Mercury. ''Mariner 10'' used the solar [[radiation pressure]] on its [[Photovoltaic module
column20: solar panel]]s and its high-gain antenna as a means of [[attitude control]] during flight, the first spacecraft to use active solar pressure control.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The components on ''Mariner 10'' can be categorized into four groups based on their common function. The solar panels, power subsystem, attitude control subsystem, and the computer kept the spacecraft operating properly during the flight. The navigational system, including the hydrazine rocket, would keep ''Mariner 10'' on track to Venus and Mercury. Several scientific instruments would collect data at the two planets. Finally, the antennas would transmit this data to the [[Deep Space Network]] back on Earth, as well as receive commands from Mission Control. ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s various components and scientific instruments were attached to a central hub, which was roughly the shape of an octagonal prism. The hub stored the spacecraft's internal electronics.<ref name=\"NSSDC\"/><ref>Clark 2007, pp. 22-23 </ref><ref name=\"Strom16\"/> The Mariner 10 spacecraft was manufactured by Boeing.<ref name=\"Mariner 10 Quicklook\">{{cite web
column4: accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref> NASA set a strict limit of US$98 million for Mariner 10's total cost, which marked the first time the agency subjected a mission to an inflexible budget constraint. No overruns would be tolerated, so mission planners carefully considered cost efficiency when designing the spacecraft's instruments.<ref>Reeves 1994, p. 222</ref> Cost control was primarily accomplished by executing contract work closer to the launch date than was recommended by normal mission schedules, as reducing the length of available work time increased cost efficiency. Despite the rushed schedule, very few deadlines were missed.<ref name=\"Biggs\"/> The mission ended up about US$1 million under budget.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 142</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: [[Attitude control]] is needed to keep a spacecraft's instruments and antennas aimed in the correct direction.<ref>{{cite web
column12: accessdate=24 July 2015}}</ref> During course maneuvers, a spacecraft may need to rotate so that its rocket faces the proper direction before being fired. ''Mariner 10'' determined its attitude using two optical sensors, one pointed at the Sun, and the other at a bright star, usually Canopus; additionally, the probe's three [[gyroscopes]] provided a second option for calculating the attitude. Nitrogen gas thrusters were used to adjust ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s orientation along three axes.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1977, p. 58</ref><ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 50</ref><ref>{{cite book
column18: title=On Mars: Exploration of the Red Planet 1958-1978

column7: jfm=}}</ref> The spacecraft's electronics were intricate and complex: it contained over 32,000 pieces of circuitry, of which resistors, capacitors, diodes, microcircuits, and transistors were the most common devices.<ref name=\"Paul\"/> Commands for the instruments could be stored on ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s computer, but were limited to 512 words. The rest had to be broadcast by the Mission Sequence Working Group from Earth.<ref name=\"Shirley\">{{cite journal
column11: title=The Mariner 10 Mission to Venus and Mercury
column28: bibcode= 2003AcAau..53..375S}}</ref> Supplying the spacecraft components with power required modifying the electrical output of the solar panels. The power subsystem used two redundant sets of circuitry, each containing a booster regulator and an [[inverter]], to convert the panels' [[direct current
column30: AC]] and alter the voltage to the necessary level.<ref>{{cite web
column34: title=A historical overview of the electrical power systems in the US manned and some US unmanned spacecraft
column42: accessdate=30 December 2015}}</ref> The subsystem could store up to 20 [[ampere hours]] of electricity on a 39 volt [[Nickel–cadmium battery

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The flyby past Mercury posed major technical challenges for scientists to overcome. Due to Mercury's proximity to the Sun, ''Mariner 10'' would have to endure 4.5 times more [[solar radiation]] than when it departed Earth; compared to previous Mariner missions, spacecraft parts needed extra shielding against the heat. Thermal blankets and a sunshade were installed on the main body. After evaluating different choices for the sunshade cloth material, mission planners chose [[beta cloth]], a combination of aluminized [[Kapton]] and glass-fiber sheets treated with [[Teflon]].<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 32–33</ref> However, solar shielding was unfeasible for some of ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s other components. ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s two solar panels needed to be kept under 115 °C. Covering the panels would defeat their purpose of producing electricity. The solution was to add an adjustable tilt to the panels, so the angle at which they faced the sun could be changed. Engineers considered folding the panels toward each other, making a V-shape with the main body, but tests found this approach had the potential to overheat the rest of the spacecraft. The alternative chosen was to mount the solar panels in a line and tilt them along that axis, which had the added benefit of increasing the efficiency of the spacecraft's nitrogen jet thrusters, which could now be placed on the panel tips. The panels could be rotated a maximum of 76°.<ref name=\"Strom16\">Strom and Sprague 2003, p. 16</ref><ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 21</ref> Additionally, ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s hydrazine rocket nozzle had to face the Sun to function properly, but scientists rejected covering the nozzle with a thermal door as an undependable solution. Instead, a special paint was applied to exposed parts on the rocket so as to reduce heat flow from the nozzle to the delicate instruments on the spacecraft.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 30–32</ref>

Accurately performing the gravity assist at Venus posed another hurdle.<ref>Reeves 1994, p. 242</ref> If ''Mariner 10'' was to maintain a course to Mercury, its trajectory could deviate no more than {{convert
column3: km}} from a critical point in the vicinity of Venus.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 56</ref> To ensure that the necessary course corrections could be made, mission planners tripled the amount of [[hydrazine]] fuel Mariner 10 would carry, and also equipped the spacecraft with more nitrogen gas for the thrusters than the previous Mariner mission had held. These upgrades proved crucial in enabling the second and third Mercury flybys.<ref name=\"MB25\">Murray and Burgess 1977, pp. 25–26</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The mission still lacked the ultimate safeguard: a sister spacecraft. It was common for probes to be launched in pairs, with complete redundancy to guard against the failure of one or the other.<ref>Strom and Sprague 2003, p. 14</ref> The budget constraint ruled this option out. Even though mission planners stayed sufficiently under budget to divert some funding for constructing a backup spacecraft, the budget did not permit both to be launched at the same time. In the event that Mariner 10 failed, NASA would only allow the backup to be launched if the fatal error was diagnosed and fixed; this would have to be completed in the two-and-a-half weeks between the scheduled launch on 3 November 1973 and the last possible launch date of 21 November 1973.<ref name=\"MB25\"/><ref name=\"MB38\"/> (The unused backup was sent to the Smithsonian museum)

column4: An illustration showing the instruments of ''Mariner 10''.]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: ''Mariner 10'' conducted seven experiments at Venus and Mercury. Six of these experiments had a dedicated scientific instrument to collect data.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p.19</ref> The experiments and instruments were designed by research laboratories and educational institutions from across the United States.<ref>Giberson and Cunningham 1975, p. 719</ref> Out of forty-six submissions, JPL selected seven experiments on the basis of maximizing science return without exceeding cost guidelines: together, the seven scientific experiments cost US12.6 million dollars, about one-eighth of the total mission budget.<ref name=\"Biggs\">{{Citation
column8: title=Mariner Venus/Mercury '73: A Strategy of Cost Control
column13: publisher=The American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The imaging system, the Television Photography Experiment, consisted of two {{convert
column4: Cassegrain]] telescopes feeding [[vidicon]] tubes.<ref name=nssdccam>[https://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experiment/display.action?id=1973-085A-01 NASA/NSSDC – Mariner 10 – Television Photography]</ref> The main telescope could be bypassed to a smaller wide angle optic, but using the same tube.<ref name=nssdccam/> It had an 8-position filter wheel, with one position occupied by a mirror for the wide-angle bypass.<ref name=nssdccam/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The entire imaging system was imperiled when electric heaters attached to the cameras failed to turn on immediately after launch. To avoid the Sun's damaging heat, the cameras were deliberately placed on the spacecraft side facing away from the Sun. Consequently, the heaters were needed to prevent the cameras from losing heat and become so cold that they would become damaged. JPL engineers found that the vidicons could generate enough heat through normal operation to stay just above the critical temperature of -40 °C; therefore they advised against turning off the cameras during the flight. Test photos of the Earth and Moon showed that image quality had not been significantly affected.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, pp. 43–48</ref> The mission team was pleasantly surprised when the camera heaters started working on 17 January 1974, two months after launch.<ref>{{cite journal
column26: title=Bulletin No. 14: TCM-2 Performance Superb TV Heaters Have Come On
column33: accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref> Later investigation concluded that a short circuit in a different location on the probe had prevented the heater from turning on. This allowed the vidicons to be turned off as needed.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 57–58</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Of the six main scientific instruments, the {{convert
column3: kg}} cameras were by far the most massive device. Requiring 67 watts of electricity, the cameras consumed more power than the other five instruments combined.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/> The system returned about 7000 photographs of Mercury and Venus during Mariner 10's flybys.<ref name=nssdccam/>

date=March 2014}}: infrared radiation]] given off by the surface of Mercury and the atmosphere of Venus, from which the temperature could be calculated. How quickly the surface lost heat as it rotated into the planet's dark side revealed aspects about the composition of the surface, such as whether it was made out of rocks, or out of finer particles.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 21-22</ref><ref name=\"Strom-18-19\"/> The infrared radiometer contained a pair of Cassegrain telescopes fixed at an angle of 120° to each other and a pair of detectors made from antimony-bismuth [[thermopile]]s. The instrument was designed to measure temperatures as cold as -193 °C and as hot as 427 °C. Stillman C. Chase, Jr. of the Santa Barbara Research Center headed the infrared radiometer experiment.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\">{{cite book

spectrometers]] were involved in this experiment, one to measure UV absorption, the other to sense UV emissions. The occultation spectrometer scanned Mercury's edge as it passed in front of the Sun, and detected whether solar ultraviolet radiation was absorbed in certain wavelengths, which would indicate the presence of gas particles, and therefore an atmosphere.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 25-26</ref> The [[airglow]] spectrometer detected extreme ultraviolet radiation emanating from atoms of gaseous hydrogen, helium, carbon, oxygen, neon, and argon.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/><ref>Rothery 2015, p. 26</ref> Unlike the occultation spectrometer, it did not require backlighting from the Sun and could move along with the rotatable scan platform on the spacecraft. The experiment's most important goal was to ascertain whether Mercury had an atmosphere, but would also gather data at Earth and Venus and study the interstellar background radiation.<ref name=\"Strom-18-19\">Strom and Sprague 2003, pp. 18-19</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The plasma experiment's goal was to study the ionized gases ([[Plasma (physics)
date=March 2014}}: plasma]]) of the solar wind, the temperature and density of its electrons, and how the planets affected the velocity of the plasma stream.<ref>{{cite web
column6: title=Scanning Electrostatic Analyzer and Electron Spectrometer
column13: accessdate=27 July 2015}}</ref> The experiment contained two components, facing in opposite directions. The Scanning Electrostatic Analyzer was aimed toward the Sun and could detect positive ions and electrons, which were separated by a set of three concentric hemispherical plates. The Scanning Electron Spectrometer has aimed away from the Sun, and detected only electrons, using just one hemispherical plate. The instruments could be rotated about 60° to either side.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/> By gathering data on the solar wind's movement around Mercury, the plasma experiment could be used to verify the magnetometer's observations of Mercury's magnetic field.<ref name=\"Strom-18-19\"/> Using the plasma detectors, Mariner 10 gathered the first ''in situ'' solar wind data from inside Venus' orbit.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 22-23</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Shortly after launch, scientists found that the Scanning Electrostatic Analyzer had failed because a door shielding the analyzer did not open. An unsuccessful attempt was made to forcibly unfasten the door with the first course correction maneuver.<ref name=\"No. 7\">{{cite web
column5: title=Bulletin No. 7: First Trajectory Correction Maneuver A Success
column12: accessdate=25 May 2015}}</ref> The experiment operators had planned to observe the directions taken by positive ions prior to the ions' collision with the Analyzer, but this data was lost.<ref name=\"No. 15\">{{cite web
column16: title=Bulletin No. 15: Venus Flyby Set For Tuesday at 10:01 A.M. PT
column23: accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref> The experiment was still able to collect some data using the properly functioning Scanning Electron Spectrometer.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 47</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The goal of the charged particles experiment was to observe how the [[heliosphere]] interacted with [[Cosmic ray
date=March 2014}}: cosmic radiation]].<ref name=\"Strom and Sprague 2003, pp. 19\">Strom and Sprague 2003, p. 19 </ref> In connection with the plasma detectors and magnetometers, this experiment had the potential to provide additional evidence of a magnetic field around Mercury,<ref>Rothery 2015, p. 28</ref> by showing whether such a field had captured charged particles.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/> Two telescopes were used to collect highly energetic electrons and atomic nuclei, specifically oxygen nuclei or less massive.<ref name=\"Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 24\">Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 24</ref> These particles then passed through a set of detectors and were counted.<ref name=\"Science Instrument Survey\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Two fluxgate magnetometers were entrusted with discerning whether Mercury produced a [[Magnetosphere
date=March 2014}}: magnetic field]],<ref>Rothery 2015, p. 27</ref> and studying the interplanetary magnetic field between flybys.<ref name=\"Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 24\"/> In designing this experiment, scientists had to account for interference from the magnetic field generated by Mariner 10's many electronic parts. For this reason, the magnetometers had to be situated on a long boom, one closer to the octagonal hub, the other one further away. Data from the two magnetometers would be cross-referenced to filter out the spacecraft's own magnetic field.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 95</ref> Drastically weakening the probe's magnetic field would have increased costs.<ref name=\"Shirley\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: This experiment investigated the mass and gravitational characteristics of Mercury. It was of particular interest because of the planet's closeness to the Sun, large orbital eccentricity, and unusual spin-orbit resonance.<ref name=NASAHistory/>

As the spacecraft passed behind Mercury on the first encounter there was an opportunity to probe the atmosphere and to measure the radius of the planet. By observing phase changes in the S-band radio signal, measurements of the atmosphere could be made. The atmosphere was assessed as having a density of about {{val
column4: u=molecules per cm<sup>3</sup>}}.<ref name=NASAHistory>[https://history.nasa.gov/SP-423/ mariner.htm History article on Mariner 10 at history.nasa.gov]</ref>
''Mariner 10'' imaged the Earth and Moon shortly after launch.]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Boeing finished building the spacecraft at the end of June 1973, and ''Mariner 10'' was delivered from Seattle to JPL's headquarters in California, where JPL comprehensively tested the integrity of the spacecraft and its instruments. After the tests were finished, the probe was transported to the [[Eastern Test Range]] in Florida, the launch site. Technicians filled a tank on the spacecraft with {{convert
column3: kg}} of hydrazine fuel so that the probe could make course corrections, and attached [[Squib (explosive)
column4: squibs]], whose detonation would signal ''Mariner 10'' to exit the launch rocket and deploy its instruments.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 42</ref><ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, pp. 36-37</ref> The planned gravity assist at Venus made it feasible to use an [[Atlas-Centaur]] rocket instead of a more powerful but more expensive [[Titan IIIC]].<ref name=\"Paul\">{{cite web
column8: title=Technical Memorandum 33-759: A Study of Mariner 10 Flight Experiences and Some Flight Piece Part Failure Rate Computations

date=March 2014}}: accessdate=23 June 2015}}</ref><ref name=\"Strom,14\">Strom and Sprague 2003, pp. 14-16</ref> The probe and the Atlas-Centaur were attached together ten days prior to liftoff. Launch posed one of the largest risks of failure for the ''Mariner 10'' mission; [[Mariner 1]], [[Mariner 3]], and [[Mariner 8]] all failed minutes after lift-off due to either engineering failures or Atlas rocket malfunctions.<ref name=\"MB38\">Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 38</ref><ref>{{cite web

column6: accessdate=22 August 2015}}</ref> The mission had a launch period of about a month in length, from 16 October 1973, to 21 November 1973. NASA chose 3 November as the launch date because it would optimize imaging conditions when the spacecraft arrived at Mercury.<ref name=\"Strom,14\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On 3 November at 17:45 UTC, the Atlas-Centaur carrying ''Mariner 10'' lifted off from pad [[Spaceport Florida Launch Complex 36
column5: website=NASA Space Science Data Coordinated Archive
column6: access-date=November 2, 2019}}</ref> The Atlas stage burned for around four minutes, after which it was jettisoned, and the Centaur stage took over for an additional five minutes, propelling ''Mariner 10'' to a [[parking orbit]]. The temporary orbit took the spacecraft one-third of the distance around Earth: this maneuver was needed to reach the correct spot for a second burn by the Centaur engines, which set ''Mariner 10'' on a path towards Venus. The probe then separated from the rocket; subsequently, the Centaur stage diverted away to avoid the possibility of a future collision. Never before had a planetary mission depended upon two separate rocket burns during the launch, and even with ''Mariner 10'', scientists initially viewed the maneuver as too risky.<ref>{{cite book

date=March 2014}}: title=Taming Liquid Hydrogen: The Centaur Upper Stage Rocket 1958-2002

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: During its first week of flight, the ''Mariner 10'' camera system was tested by taking five [[Panoramic photography
date=March 2014}}: photographic mosaics]] of the [[Earth]] and six of the [[Moon]]. It also obtained photographs of the north polar region of the Moon where prior coverage was poor. These photographs provided a basis for cartographers to update lunar maps and improve the [[Selenographic coordinates
column3: lunar control net]].<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 47–53.</ref>

column4: The trajectory of ''Mariner 10'' spacecraft: since launch on 3 November 1973, to first fly-by of Mercury on 29 March 1974.]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Far from being an uneventful cruise, ''Mariner 10''{{’}}s three-month journey to Venus was fraught with technical malfunctions, which kept mission control on edge.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 55</ref> [[Donna Shirley]] recounted her team's frustration: \"It seemed as if we were always just patching Mariner 10 together long enough to get it on to the next phase and next crisis\".<ref>Shirley 1998, p. 91 </ref> A trajectory correction maneuver was made on 13 November 1973. Immediately afterward, the star-tracker locked onto a bright flake of paint which had come off the spacecraft and lost tracking on the guide star [[Canopus]]. An automated safety protocol recovered Canopus, but the problem of flaking paint recurred throughout the mission. The on-board computer also experienced unscheduled resets occasionally, which necessitated reconfiguring the clock sequence and subsystems. Periodic problems with the high-gain antenna also occurred during the cruise. On 8 January 1974, a malfunction thought to be caused by a short-circuited diode occurred in the power subsystem.<ref name=\"Paul\"/> As a result, the main booster regulator and inverter failed, leaving the spacecraft dependent on the redundant regulator. Mission planners feared that the same problem could recur in the redundant system and cripple the spacecraft.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 55</ref>
In January 1974, ''Mariner 10'' made ultraviolet observations of [[Comet Kohoutek]]. Another mid-course correction was made on 21 January 1974.
The spacecraft passed Venus on 5 February 1974, the closest approach being {{convert
column3: km}} at 17:01 UTC. It was the twelfth spacecraft to reach Venus and the eighth to return data from the planet,<ref>{{cite web
column14: url-status=dead}}</ref> as well as the first mission to succeed in broadcasting images of Venus back to Earth.<ref name=\"Ulivi181\">Ulivi and Harland 2007, p. 181</ref> ''Mariner 10'' built upon observations made by ''Mariner 5'' six years earlier; importantly, ''Mariner 10'' had a camera whereas the prior mission lacked one.<ref name=\"Reeves 1994, p. 244\">Reeves 1994, p. 244</ref> As ''Mariner 10'' veered around Venus, from the planet's night side to daylight, the cameras snapped the probe's first image of Venus, showing an illuminated arc of clouds over the north pole emerging from darkness. Engineers initially feared that the star-tracker could mistake the much brighter Venus for Canopus, repeating the mishaps with flaking paint. However, the star-tracker did not malfunction. Earth occultation occurred between 17:07 UTC and 17:11 UTC, during which the spacecraft transmitted X-band radio waves through Venus' atmosphere, gathering data on cloud structure and temperature.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, pp. 61-64</ref><ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, pp. 61-63</ref> Although Venus's cloud cover is nearly featureless in visible light, it was discovered that extensive cloud detail could be seen through Mariner's ultraviolet camera filters. Earth-based ultra-violet observation had shown some indistinct blotching even before ''Mariner 10'', but the detail seen by Mariner was a surprise to most researchers. The probe continued photographing Venus until 13 February 1974.<ref>Murray and Burgess 1977, p. 79 </ref> Among the encounter's 4165 acquired photographs, one resulting series of images captured a thick and distinctly patterned atmosphere making a full revolution every four days,<ref name=\"Reeves 1994, p. 244\"/> just as terrestrial observations had suggested.<ref>Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 68</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The mission revealed the composition and meteorological nature of the atmosphere of Venus. Data from the radio science experiment measured the extent to which radio waves passing through the atmosphere were refracted, which was used to calculate the density, pressure, and temperature of the atmosphere at any given altitude.<ref name=\"Howard\">{{cite journal
column43: title=Venus: Mass, Gravity Field, Atmosphere, and Ionosphere as Measured by the Mariner 10 Dual-Frequency Radio System
column48: publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science
column59: jfm=
column61: bibcode=1974Sci...183.1297H}}</ref> Overall, atmospheric temperature is higher closer to the planet's surface, but ''Mariner 10'' found four altitudes where the pattern was reversed, which could signify the presence of a layer of clouds.<ref name=\"DB65\">Dunne and Burgess 1978, p. 65</ref> The inversions occurred at the 56, 61, 63, and 81 km levels,<ref>Giberson and Cunningham 1975, p. 726</ref> confirming previous observations made by the ''Mariner 5'' encounter.<ref name=\"Howard\"/> The ultraviolet spectrometers identified the chemical substances that comprise Venus' atmosphere.<ref>Giberson and Cunningham 1975, p. 725</ref> The elevated concentration of atomic oxygen in the upper atmosphere showed that the atmosphere is stratified into upper and lower layers that do not mix with each other; photographs of the upper and lower cloud layers corroborated this hypothesis.<ref name=\"DB65\"/> ''Mariner 10''{{’}}s ultraviolet photographs were an invaluable information source for studying the churning clouds of Venus' atmosphere. The mission researchers believed the cloud features they photographed were located in the stratosphere and upper troposphere, created by condensation; they also concluded that the contrast between darker and lighter features was due to differences in the cloud's absorptivity of UV light.<ref name=\"Murray-Belton\">{{cite journal
column83: title=Venus: Atmospheric Motion and Structure from Mariner 10 Pictures
column88: publisher=American Association for the Advancement of Science
column101: bibcode=1974Sci...183.1307M}}</ref> The subsolar region was of particular interest: as the sun is straight overhead, it imparts more solar energy to this area than other part of the planet. Compared to the rest of the planet's atmosphere, the subsolar region was highly active and irregular. \"Cells\" of air lifted by convection, each up to {{convert
column103: km}} wide, were observed forming and dissipating within the span of a few hours; some had polygonal outlines.<ref name=\"Murray-Belton\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The gravity assist was also a success, coming well within the acceptable margin for error. In the four hours between 16:00 UTC and 20:00 UTC on 5 February 1974, ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s heliocentric velocity dropped from {{convert
column15: title=Bulletin No. 18: Mariner 10 Enroute to Mercury - Continues Query of Venus
column22: accessdate=7 September 2015}}</ref> This changed the shape of the spacecraft's elliptical orbit around the Sun,<ref name=\"Ulivi181\"/> so that the perihelion now coincided with the orbit of Mercury.<ref name=\"No. 18\"/>

column4: Venus in real colors, processed from clear and blue filtered ''Mariner 10'' images Venus as captured by Mariner 10.jpg
column5: ''Mariner 10''{{'}}s photograph of Venus in [[ultraviolet]] light (photo color-enhanced to simulate Venus's natural color as the human eye would see it)</gallery>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The spacecraft flew past Mercury three times. The first Mercury encounter took place at 20:47 [[Universal Time
date=March 2014}}: UTC]] on 29 March 1974,<!--- JD 2442115.5 --->at a range of {{convert
column4: km}}, passing on the shadow side.<ref name=\"Mission Overview\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: After looping once around the [[Sun]] while Mercury completed two orbits, ''Mariner 10'' flew by Mercury again on 21 September 1974,<!--- JD 2442311.5 = 196 days later ---> at a more distant range of {{convert
column3: km}} below the southern hemisphere.<ref name=\"Mission Overview\"/>

date=March 2014}}: A mosaic of images from the second encounter, covering the equator to the south pole.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: After losing roll control in October 1974, a third and final encounter, the closest to Mercury, took place on 16 March 1975,<!--- JD 2442487.5 = 176 days later, 20 days early ---> at a range of {{convert
column3: km}}, passing almost over the north pole.<ref name=\"Mission Overview\"/>

date=March 2014}}: A prominent scarp, [[Discovery Rupes]], photographed during the first flyby.
Representation of the thrust fault at Discovery Rupes

column3: Schubert]] basin, 190 km in diameter, filled by smooth plains. The basin's hummocky rim is partly degraded and cratered by later events.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: With its maneuvering gas just about exhausted, ''Mariner 10'' started another orbit of the Sun. Engineering tests were continued until 24 March 1975,<ref name=\"Mission Overview\"/> when final depletion of the nitrogen supply was signaled by the onset of an un-programmed pitch turn. Commands were sent immediately to the spacecraft to turn off its transmitter, and radio signals to Earth ceased.

date=March 2014}}: orbiting the Sun]], although its electronics have probably been damaged by the Sun's radiation.<ref>[http://www.space.com/18301-mariner-10.html  Elizabeth Howell, SPACE.com Contributor Article on mariner-10 at space.com]</ref> ''Mariner 10'' has not been spotted or tracked from Earth since it stopped transmitting. The only ways it would not be orbiting would be if it had been hit by an asteroid or gravitationally perturbed by a close encounter with a large body.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: During its flyby of Venus, ''Mariner 10'' discovered evidence of rotating clouds and a very weak magnetic field. Using a near-[[ultraviolet]] filter, it photographed Venus's [[Cirrus uncinus cloud
date=March 2014}}: chevron clouds]] and performed other [[celestial body's atmosphere

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The spacecraft flew past Mercury three times. Owing to the geometry of its orbit – its orbital period was almost exactly twice Mercury's – the same side of Mercury was sunlit each time, so it was only able to [[map]] 40–45% of Mercury's surface, taking over 2800 photos. It revealed a more or less Moon-like surface. It thus contributed enormously to our understanding of Mercury, whose surface had not been successfully resolved through telescopic observation. The regions mapped included most or all of the Shakespeare, Beethoven, Kuiper, Michelangelo, Tolstoj, and Discovery [[list of quadrangles on Mercury
date=March 2014}}: quadrangle]]s, half of Bach and Victoria quadrangles, and small portions of Solitudo Persephones (later Neruda), Liguria (later Raditladi), and Borealis quadrangles.<ref name=\"h8.pdf\">{{cite book
column4: title=Geologic Map of the Tolstoj (H-8) Quadrangle of Mercury
column9: id=USGS Miscellaneous Investigations Series Map I–1199, as part of the Atlas of Mercury, 1:5,000,000 Geologic Series

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: ''Mariner 10'' also discovered that Mercury has a tenuous [[Atmosphere of Mercury
date=March 2014}}: atmosphere]] consisting primarily of [[helium]], as well as a [[magnetic field]] and a large iron-rich [[planetary core
column3: core]]. Its radiometer readings suggested that Mercury has a nighttime temperature of −183 °C (−297 [[Fahrenheit

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Planning for ''[[MESSENGER]]'', a spacecraft that surveyed Mercury until 2015, relied extensively on data and information collected by ''Mariner 10''.
