arrival_date = March 11, 2020
({{Age in years, months, weeks and days

column7: title=The Coronavirus: What Scientists Have Learned So Far

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The '''[[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]]''' was confirmed to have reached the U.S. state of '''[[Arkansas]]''' in March 2020. The first case in Arkansas was reported on March 11, 2020 in [[Pine Bluff, Arkansas
column3: Jefferson County]]. As of April 13, 2020, the [[Arkansas Department of Health]] (ADH) has confirmed 1,410 positive cases of [[COVID-19]] in the state with 29 deaths and 391 recoveries. A total of 20,804 tests have been processed.<ref name=\"cit8\">{{Cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: {{2019–20 coronavirus pandemic data/United States/Arkansas medical cases chart}}
On March 11, Governor [[Asa Hutchinson]] confirmed the state's first presumptive positive coronavirus case in [[Pine Bluff, Arkansas
column4: title=Governor Hutchinson Confirms State's First Presumptive Positive COVID-19 Case

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 12, five more presumptive cases were reported, four of which had contact with the original Pine Bluff case, prompting the governor to order school closings in [[Grant County, Arkansas
column5: Saline]] counties. Dr. Nathaniel (Nate) Smith, the Director and State Health Officer of the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH), said it was believed the original Pine Bluff case likely became infected in [[New Orleans]] during [[Mardi Gras]].<ref name=\"cit2\">{{cite news
column8: title=6 presumptive positive cases of coronavirus detected in Arkansas

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 13, Governor Hutchinson announced three more presumptive cases in the state, including the first instance of community spread. He recommended not to hold gatherings of more than 200 people in the counties with affected cases.<ref name=\"cit3\">{{cite news
column4: title=3 more coronavirus cases in state, gov says; 1 patient in Little Rock, mayor reports

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 14, Governor Hutchinson announced three more presumptive positive cases, with all three cases being healthcare workers at Jefferson Regional Medical Center and related to the original Pine Bluff case.<ref name=\"cit5\">{{Cite web
column3: title=COVID-19 Cases Rise to 12 In Arkansas, 3 Healthcare Workers Infected
column7: website=University of Arkansas at Little Rock Public Radio
column12: archive-date=14 March 2020}}</ref> He acknowledged that other Arkansans had probably contracted the disease, but they haven't been confirmed due to limited testing. During a press conference with the governor, the University of [[University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences]] chancellor, Cam Patterson, remarked that he hoped adding a new machine within a week would increase the ability for testing 160 tests per day compared to the current 20.<ref name=\"cit6\">{{cite web
column14: title=3 more Arkansans test positive for virus, gov says; National Guard activated
column21: archive-date=15 March 2020}}</ref> Before the end of the day, the [[Arkansas Department of Health]]'s website had been updated to show that all presumptive positive cases were updated to confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit7\">{{cite web
column23: title=Update: 12 confirmed cases of coronavirus in Arkansas, according to Dept. of Health

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 15, Governor Hutchinson reported during a press conference that all public schools would close beginning Tuesday, March 17, with the option of closing Monday, March 16, if they were prepared. Schools would remain closed through spring break the following week. Earlier in the day, the Arkansas Department of Health's website was updated to show that there were 16 confirmed cases in the state.<ref name=\"cit9\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Schools across Arkansas to shut over coronavirus concerns

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 16, Governor Hutchinson reported during a press conference in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: Fayetteville]] that the number of cases has risen to 22, with two of these in central Arkansas and two cases in [[Cleburne County, Arkansas
column3: Cleburne County]], which were the result of out-of-state travel. He remarked that the testing capabilities of the state would be ramping up and that cases should be expected to rise along with more testing. He recommended that the number of people in events should be limited to 50, per [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column4: CDC]] guidelines. He also discouraged unnecessary out-of-state travel.<ref name=\"cit12\">{{cite news
column7: title=MARCH 16 UPDATE: Coronavirus cases in state reach 22
column16: title=Governor Asa Hutchinson strongly advises against out of state travel

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 17, Governor Hutchinson reported during a press conference in [[West Memphis, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: West Memphis]] that the number of cases remained at 22, but reiterated that confirmed cases are expected to rise as more tests occur in the coming days. He ordered all casinos closed for two weeks and said that for the next 30 days, the one-week waiting period and work reporting requirement to receive unemployment benefits had been waived.<ref name=\"cit17\">{{Cite news
column6: title=No new cases of coronavirus, Arkansas governor says; casinos ordered shut for 2 weeks
column12: archive-date=18 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website was updated with a map that showed the virus was now present in [[Cleveland County, Arkansas

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 18, Governor Hutchinson said the state was working to allocate $12 million in federal [[Community Development Block Grant]] funds, aiming to target hospitals and other businesses essential to the coronavirus response. Additionally, he said he would allocate $4 million from the state's Quick Action Closing Fund which would provide loans of up to $250,000 to help businesses make payroll and stay open. The state also requested a disaster declaration from the [[Small Business Administration]] which would help provide loans of up to $2 million to provide capital for businesses. The state is also relaxing [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program
date=March 2014}}: SNAP]] work requirements through May.<ref name=\"cit21\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Coronavirus cases rise to 37 in state
column17: title=Governor Hutchinson Announces Relief for Businesses, Child-Care Providers To Ease COVID-19 Impact
column24: archive-date=19 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Bradley County, Arkansas
column27: Washington]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 19, Governor Hutchinson reported during his daily press conference an increase to 62 confirmed cases, many from community spread. This prompted him to institute measures to try to help mitigate further spread. He announced public schools would remain closed through April 17; restaurants and bars would not be allowed to provide dine-in services but could still provide carryout, curbside pickup, or delivery, beginning Friday, March 20; state government employees would begin working from home; healthcare providers would begin screening all visitors and staff for fever and symptoms; and indoor venues such as gyms would be closed to visitors.<ref name=\"cit23\">{{Cite web
column3: title=As virus cases rise to 62 in state, gov sets new restrictions, extends school closures
column12: website=[[Arkansas Democrat-Gazette]]}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Clark County, Arkansas
column21: Van Buren]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 20, Governor Hutchinson reported during his press conference that the number of cases at that time were up to 96. Thirteen of these new cases were connected to a nursing home in Little Rock where four staff and nine residents tested positive. Dr. Nate Smith added that of the 96 cases, 26 were people over the age of 65, 62 were between ages 19 and 64, and eight were children. Education Secretary [[Johnny Key (politician)
date=March 2014}}: Johnny Key]] said that the state would apply for a federal government waiver to standardized testing requirements. Attorney General [[Leslie Rutledge]] said an additional $3 million would be added to the loan program for small businesses that the governor announced on March 18.<ref name=\"cit24\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Coronavirus cases hit 100 in state, including more than dozen at Little Rock nursing home, agency says
column15: archive-date=20 March 2020}}</ref> Col. John Schuette, installation commander of the [[Little Rock Air Force Base]], announced that an active-duty [[United States Air Force
column16: U.S. Air Force]] airman assigned to the base tested positive. A 30-day public health emergency for the base was declared.<ref name=\"cit25\">{{Cite web
column18: title=Little Rock Air Force Base confirms positive coronavirus test
column25: archive-date=21 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Benton County, Arkansas

column3: Polk]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 21, Governor Hutchinson reported an increase in the number of cases to 118. He said the state expects the spread of the virus to peak in 6 to 8 weeks, at which time there would be an estimated 1,000 Arkansans hospitalized with the disease.<ref name=\"cit26\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Virus cases in state reach 118; peak expected in 6-8 weeks, governor says
column12: archive-date=21 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Sebastian County, Arkansas
column13: Sebastian County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 22, Governor Hutchinson reported an increase in the number of cases to 165. Forty-one of the total cases came from a nursing home in Little Rock. Hutchinson said the state was having a hard tough securing [[personal protective equipment]] (PPE). Arkansas received 25 percent of the PPE the state requested from the federal government's national storehouse. He estimated that 8,000 to 10,000 Arkansans had filed for unemployment in the previous week. Due to such a high number of claims, Hutchinson said he would ask the [[Arkansas General Assembly]] to approve $1.1 million from his rainy day fund for upgrades to the unemployment system. Secretary of Commerce Mike Preston said the Arkansas Economic Development Commission had received around 300 calls and emails inquiring about the business loans the governor had outlined earlier in the week.<ref name=\"cit29\">{{Cite web
column3: title=47 new virus cases bring state's total to 165; cases surge at Little Rock nursing home, governor says
column14: title=Up to 10,000 have applied for unemployment in Arkansas in recent days
column23: archive-date=22 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Columbia County, Arkansas
column27: Woodruff]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 23, Governor Hutchinson announced cases that point of the day had risen to 174. He said the individual income tax filing deadline would be moved to July 15 and he would call for a special legislative session to deal with expected budget shortfalls due to the pandemic. Corporate taxes would still be due April 15. Hutchinson expected an estimated $353 million shortfall for the state budget. Dr. Nate Smith said that five patients at met the criteria to be called recovered cases. Smith announced that barber shops, beauty and nail salons, massage parlors, and tattoo shops would close beginning Tuesday, March 24.<ref name=\"cit32\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Governor extends individual tax deadline, says special session needed; virus cases hit 197
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> In Cleburne County, a deacon for a local church said that 34 people who attended an event at the church had tested positive and others were awaiting results.<ref name=\"cit33\">{{Cite web
column14: title=34 tied to Arkansas church test positive for coronavirus, deacon says
column23: archive-date=23 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Crawford County, Arkansas
column27: White]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The first death in the state was reported on March 24, a 91-year-old male from Faulkner County.<ref name=\"cit34\">{{Cite web
column3: title=1st coronavirus death in Arkansas reported
column12: archive-date=24 March 2020}}</ref> In his daily press conference, Governor Hutchinson reported that a second death had also occurred, a 59-year-old male from [[Sherwood, Arkansas
column13: Sherwood]]. Hutchinson reaffirmed that he did not want to issue a [[Shelter in place
column14: shelter-in-place]] order like other states had despite saying the state was still in the beginning stages of its outbreak. Both Hutchinson and Dr. Nate Smith remarked that April 12 would be too early for the state to return to normal operations, which is the date [[Donald Trump
column15: President Trump]] had targeted during an interview earlier in the day.<ref name=\"cit35\">{{Cite web
column17: title=Second person dies of virus in Arkansas, gov says; state not considering shelter-in-place order at this time
column26: access-date=24 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Cross County, Arkansas
column30: Pike]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 25, the ADH issued a recommendation that all travelers from [[New York (state)
date=March 2014}}: New York]] and all international travelers should self-quarantine for 14 days.<ref name=\"cit40\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Advisory for Travelers from New York State and All International Locations
column9: url-status=live}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Drew County, Arkansas
column10: Drew County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/> On March 26, the state reported its third death from the virus, a 73-year-old male from Cleburne County.<ref name=\"cit36\">{{Cite web
column12: title=Three COVID-19 related deaths in Arkansas, officials say
column19: url-status=live}}</ref> Governor Hutchinson announced a $116 million plan to provide support for healthcare workers in the state, with $91 million coming from the federal government. This plan would provide nurses an additional $1,000 a month with that number rising to $2,000 a month for nurses treating a COVID-19 patient.<ref name=\"cit37\">{{Cite web
column21: title=3rd coronavirus death in Arkansas; governor plans $116 million in healthcare support
column32: archive-date=27 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Chicot County, Arkansas
column36: Randolph]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 27, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Baxter County, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: Baxter County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/> On March 28, the state confirmed two more deaths, bringing the total to five. Both cases were in central Arkansas, with one person being in their 70s and the other in their 40s. The number of unemployment claims for the previous week were a record 30,000, an increase from the 9,400 the previous week.<ref name=\"cit41\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Arkansas creates COVID-19 fund as 2 more die from virus
column13: url-status=live}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Johnson County, Arkansas
column14: Johnson County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 29, the state recorded its sixth death. The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Arkansas County, Arkansas
column5: Perry]] counties had a confirmed case, and Hempstead County was reinstated on the map.<ref name=\"cit8\"/> On March 30, the state reported its seventh death, an 83-year-old woman infected in a nursing home in Little Rock. The state legislative leaders approved Governor Hutchinson's request to use $45 million from the newly created COVID-19 rainy-day fund. These funds would primarily be used for the purchase of PPE.<ref name=\"cit42\">{{Cite web
column7: title=Virus cases in Arkansas top 500; nursing home resident is 7th person to die
column18: archive-date=1 April 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Newton County, Arkansas
column20: St. Francis]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/> On March 31, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Miller County, Arkansas
column22: Scott]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 1, two additional deaths were reported, bringing the total to 10. One was from central Arkansas and no other information was provided on the other. [[Arkansas Department of Parks and Tourism]] Secretary Stacy Hurst, in an effort to limit out-of-state tourists, announced that state parks would no longer allow overnight stays and would limit the number of available parking spaces. Certain trails at [[Petit Jean State Park]] and [[Pinnacle Mountain State Park]] were deemed problematic and closed. Hutchinson made a recommendation to the [[United States Secretary of the Interior]], [[David Bernhardt]], that the [[Buffalo National River]] be closed.<ref name=\"cit45\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus cases in Arkansas reach 624; death toll at 10
column12: archive-date=3 April 2020}}</ref> State Rep. [[Reginald Murdock]] of [[Marianna, Arkansas
column13: Marianna]] announced that he had tested positive.<ref name=\"cit46\">{{Cite web
column15: title=Arkansas legislator states he has virus; test pending for 2nd lawmaker
column26: archive-date=3 April 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Carroll County, Arkansas
column28: Lee]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 2, two additional deaths were reported, bringing the total to 12. Both were from central Arkansas, with one being over 65 and the other under 65. Governor Hutchinson defended his decision to not order a shelter-in-place, arguing that the steps the state had taken were enough and that an official order to close non-essential businesses would put at least 100,000 more Arkansans out of work. Wendy Kelly, director of the [[Arkansas Department of Correction]], announced that the state's prisoners would be manufacture cloth masks for the prison system, with an expectation of 80,000 masks being produced.<ref name=\"cit43\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Arkansas prison inmates to make cloth masks; virus deaths in state rise to 12
column12: archive-date=3 April 2020}}</ref> A second member of the state legislature, Rep. [[Vivian Flowers]] of Pine Bluff, tested positive.<ref name=\"cit44\">{{Cite web
column14: title=Second member of Arkansas House infected
column23: archive-date=3 April 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Mississippi County, Arkansas
column27: Sharp]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 3, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Lafayette County, Arkansas
column3: Prairie]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 4, Governor Hutchinson signed an [[executive order]] limiting the types of guests that can stay at hotels, motels, and vacation rentals to:  healthcare professionals; first responders; law enforcement; state or federal employees on official business; National Guard members on active duty; airline crew members; patients of hospitals and their families; journalists; persons unable to return to their home due to COVID-19 travel restrictions; Arkansas citizens unable to return to their home due to exigent circumstances, such as fire, flood, tornado, or other disaster; persons in need of shelter due to domestic violence of homelessness; employees of hotels, motels, or other service providers/contractors of a hotel or motel; and persons away from their home due to work or work-related travel. He added that the state had seen a 40 percent reduction in travel since the beginning of the emergency.<ref name=\"cit47\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Governor Hutchinson Issues Executive Order Requiring New Protocols for Commercial Lodgings, Short-Term Rentals
column12: title=Governor restricts out-of-state travelers from coming into Arkansas amid COVID-19 pandemic
column21: url-status=live}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Dallas County, Arkansas
column22: Dallas County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 5, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Phillips County, Arkansas
On April 6, Governor Hutchinson announced that schools would remain closed for the remainder of the school year.<ref name=\"cit52\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus in Arkansas: Governor announces public schools remain online through end of school year
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> He also announced that the state would send five [[ventilators]] to [[Louisiana]] to help with their spread of the disease, saying Arkansas has around 800 ventilators with about 550 not being used.<ref name=\"cit51\">{{Cite web
column13: title=Arkansas to give ventilators to Louisiana
column22: url-status=live}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Clay County, Arkansas
column26: Logan]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 8, the state reported its 1,000th case. The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Madison County, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: Madison County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 10, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Marion County, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: Marion County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 11, Governor Hutchinson declared a public health emergency in response to the first presumptive case in the state.<ref name=\"cit1\"/> On March 12, the governor ordered school closings in Saline, Jefferson, Pulaski, and Grant counties until March 30.<ref name=\"cit2\"/> On March 14, Hutchinson activated the [[Arkansas National Guard]] to provide support with logistics, transportation, and other needs.<ref name=\"cit5\"/> All public schools were ordered to close beginning Tuesday, March 17.<ref name=\"cit9\"/> On March 17, Hutchinson closed casinos for two weeks and loosened restrictions on claiming unemployment benefits for 30 days.<ref name=\"cit17\"/> On March 19, Hutchinson announced new measures to help limit the spread of the disease, including keeping public schools closed through April 17 and banning restaurants and bars from providing dine-in services.<ref name=\"cit23\"/> On March 23, the individual income tax filing deadline was pushed back until July 15, and barber shops, beauty and nail salons, massage parlors, and tattoo parlors were ordered to close on Tuesday, March 24.<ref name=\"cit32\"/> On April 3, state parks began to limit their available parking spaces and ended overnight stays.<ref name=\"cit45\"/>
On April 6, the governor ordered public schools to close for the remainder of the school year.<ref name=\"cit52\"/>

column3: Frank Scott, Jr.]] announced a citywide curfew to keep residents from being outside from 12 a.m. to 5 a.m. beginning Wednesday, March 18. This did not apply to people traveling to and from work. Little Rock police officers would question people in public places, but not stop drivers. Additionally, homeless individuals would not be cited.<ref name=\"cit14\">{{Cite web
column5: title=Little Rock mayor announces citywide curfew to limit spread of coronavirus
column15: archive-date=17 March 2020}}</ref> On March 25, Scott extended the curfew to begin at 9 p.m. and end at 5 a.m. He also announced the introduction of a daytime curfew for minors from 9:00 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. that would be in effect from March 30 to April 17.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: title=Little Rock mayor extends city curfew, enforcing it with citations

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 16, the Fayetteville city council voted unanimously to grant the mayor emergency powers to regulate gatherings. The council also appropriated $3 million in emergency funds to address the pandemic locally.<ref name=\"cit19\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Fayetteville council grants mayor power to regulate gatherings

date=March 2014}}: Jonesboro]] announced on March 15 that beginning Tuesday, March 17, all in-person instructions would transition to all-online instructions for the remainder of the semester. The campus would remain open. Graduation ceremonies would be reevaluated as they got closer.<ref name=\"cit18\">{{cite web
column4: title=A-State Transitions to All-Online Course Delivery

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: [[Southeast Arkansas College]] in Pine Bluff closed on March 11 after three students had been exposed to the original Pine Bluff patient.<ref name=\"cit4\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Southeast Arkansas College closed after three students exposed to presumptive COVID-19 patient

date=March 2014}}: Magnolia]] announced on March 12 that it was canceling all face-to-face classes scheduled for the week of March 16 through March 20, prior to the week of spring break. Course delivery would shift fully online beginning March 30 and continuing through the end of the semester. The campus was not closed and housing, dining, and other services would remain in operation.<ref name=\"cit11\">{{Cite web
column4: title=SAU moves to online course delivery March 30

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The [[University of Arkansas]] at Fayetteville announced on March 12 that it was suspending all in-person classes immediately and would begin online courses starting Monday, March 16, and continue through the end of the semester. The campus was not closed and housing, dining, and other services would remain in operation.<ref name=\"cit10\">{{Cite web
column3: title=In-Person Classes Suspended; Online Course Delivery Starts March 16
column9: archive-date=18 March 2020}}</ref> After a student tested positive for COVID-19 on March 24, the university announced it would be closing campus and gave student until April 3 to leave.<ref name=\"cit38\">{{Cite web
column11: title=University of Arkansas student tests positive for COVID-19

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The [[University of Arkansas at Little Rock]] announced on the afternoon of March 12 that in-person instruction would transition immediately to online instruction. The campus would remain open. Graduation ceremonies would be reevaluated as they got closer.<ref name=\"cit31\">{{Cite web
column3: title=UA Little Rock Migrates to Online Classes Immediately

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The [[University of Arkansas at Monticello]] (UAM) announced on March 17 that all instructions would move to an online setting through the end of the semester. The university remained open, including residence halls and food services.<ref name=\"cit27\">{{Cite web
column3: title=UAM Announces Instruction Will Remain Online Until End of Spring Semester
column10: archive-date=21 March 2020}}</ref> On March 19, UAM, based on a recommendation from the University of Arkansas Board of Trustees, announced that spring commencement exercises would be postponed and graduates would be invited to participate in the December 11 commencement ceremony.<ref name=\"cit28\">{{Cite web
column12: title=UA System Vote Postpones May Commencement Ceremony at UAM Due to Current Health Crisis

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The [[Arkansas Activities Association]] announced on March 12 via Twitter that all spring sports and activities would be suspended from March 15 through March 30 with plans to reassess at that time.<ref name=\"cit20\">{{Cite tweet
In college sports, the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] cancelled all winter and spring tournaments, most notably the [[NCAA Division I
date=March 2014}}: Division I]] [[2020 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
column3: men]]'s and [[2020 NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Tournament
column4: women]]'s basketball tournaments, affecting colleges and universities statewide.<ref name=\"cit15\">{{Cite web
column6: title=NCAA cancels remaining winter and spring championships
column12: archive-date=12 March 2020}}</ref> On March 16, the [[National Junior College Athletic Association]] also canceled the remainder of the winter seasons as well as the spring seasons.<ref name=\"cit16\">{{Cite web
column14: title=NJCAA cancels spring sports, basketball nationals amid coronavirus outbreak

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: * [https://www.healthy.arkansas.gov/programs-services/topics/novel-coronavirus COVID-19 information] from the Arkansas Department of Health

column7: title=The Coronavirus: What Scientists Have Learned So Far

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The '''[[2019–20 coronavirus pandemic]]''' was confirmed to have reached the U.S. state of '''[[Arkansas]]''' in March 2020. The first case in Arkansas was reported on March 11, 2020 in [[Pine Bluff, Arkansas
column3: Jefferson County]]. As of April 13, 2020, the [[Arkansas Department of Health]] (ADH) has confirmed 1,398 positive cases of [[COVID-19]] in the state with 29 deaths and 376 recoveries. A total of 20,792 tests have been processed.<ref name=\"cit8\">{{Cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: {{2019–20 coronavirus pandemic data/United States/Arkansas medical cases chart}}
On March 11, Governor [[Asa Hutchinson]] confirmed the state's first presumptive positive coronavirus case in [[Pine Bluff, Arkansas
column4: title=Governor Hutchinson Confirms State's First Presumptive Positive COVID-19 Case

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 12, five more presumptive cases were reported, four of which had contact with the original Pine Bluff case, prompting the governor to order school closings in [[Grant County, Arkansas
column5: Saline]] counties. Dr. Nathaniel (Nate) Smith, the Director and State Health Officer of the Arkansas Department of Health (ADH), said it was believed the original Pine Bluff case likely became infected in [[New Orleans]] during [[Mardi Gras]].<ref name=\"cit2\">{{cite news
column8: title=6 presumptive positive cases of coronavirus detected in Arkansas

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 13, Governor Hutchinson announced three more presumptive cases in the state, including the first instance of community spread. He recommended not to hold gatherings of more than 200 people in the counties with affected cases.<ref name=\"cit3\">{{cite news
column4: title=3 more coronavirus cases in state, gov says; 1 patient in Little Rock, mayor reports

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 14, Governor Hutchinson announced three more presumptive positive cases, with all three cases being healthcare workers at Jefferson Regional Medical Center and related to the original Pine Bluff case.<ref name=\"cit5\">{{Cite web
column3: title=COVID-19 Cases Rise to 12 In Arkansas, 3 Healthcare Workers Infected
column7: website=University of Arkansas at Little Rock Public Radio
column12: archive-date=14 March 2020}}</ref> He acknowledged that other Arkansans had probably contracted the disease, but they haven't been confirmed due to limited testing. During a press conference with the governor, the University of [[University of Arkansas for Medical Sciences]] chancellor, Cam Patterson, remarked that he hoped adding a new machine within a week would increase the ability for testing 160 tests per day compared to the current 20.<ref name=\"cit6\">{{cite web
column14: title=3 more Arkansans test positive for virus, gov says; National Guard activated
column21: archive-date=15 March 2020}}</ref> Before the end of the day, the [[Arkansas Department of Health]]'s website had been updated to show that all presumptive positive cases were updated to confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit7\">{{cite web
column23: title=Update: 12 confirmed cases of coronavirus in Arkansas, according to Dept. of Health

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 15, Governor Hutchinson reported during a press conference that all public schools would close beginning Tuesday, March 17, with the option of closing Monday, March 16, if they were prepared. Schools would remain closed through spring break the following week. Earlier in the day, the Arkansas Department of Health's website was updated to show that there were 16 confirmed cases in the state.<ref name=\"cit9\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Schools across Arkansas to shut over coronavirus concerns

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 16, Governor Hutchinson reported during a press conference in [[Fayetteville, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: Fayetteville]] that the number of cases has risen to 22, with two of these in central Arkansas and two cases in [[Cleburne County, Arkansas
column3: Cleburne County]], which were the result of out-of-state travel. He remarked that the testing capabilities of the state would be ramping up and that cases should be expected to rise along with more testing. He recommended that the number of people in events should be limited to 50, per [[Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
column4: CDC]] guidelines. He also discouraged unnecessary out-of-state travel.<ref name=\"cit12\">{{cite news
column7: title=MARCH 16 UPDATE: Coronavirus cases in state reach 22
column16: title=Governor Asa Hutchinson strongly advises against out of state travel

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 17, Governor Hutchinson reported during a press conference in [[West Memphis, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: West Memphis]] that the number of cases remained at 22, but reiterated that confirmed cases are expected to rise as more tests occur in the coming days. He ordered all casinos closed for two weeks and said that for the next 30 days, the one-week waiting period and work reporting requirement to receive unemployment benefits had been waived.<ref name=\"cit17\">{{Cite news
column6: title=No new cases of coronavirus, Arkansas governor says; casinos ordered shut for 2 weeks
column12: archive-date=18 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website was updated with a map that showed the virus was now present in [[Cleveland County, Arkansas

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 18, Governor Hutchinson said the state was working to allocate $12 million in federal [[Community Development Block Grant]] funds, aiming to target hospitals and other businesses essential to the coronavirus response. Additionally, he said he would allocate $4 million from the state's Quick Action Closing Fund which would provide loans of up to $250,000 to help businesses make payroll and stay open. The state also requested a disaster declaration from the [[Small Business Administration]] which would help provide loans of up to $2 million to provide capital for businesses. The state is also relaxing [[Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program
date=March 2014}}: SNAP]] work requirements through May.<ref name=\"cit21\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Coronavirus cases rise to 37 in state
column17: title=Governor Hutchinson Announces Relief for Businesses, Child-Care Providers To Ease COVID-19 Impact
column24: archive-date=19 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Bradley County, Arkansas
column27: Washington]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 19, Governor Hutchinson reported during his daily press conference an increase to 62 confirmed cases, many from community spread. This prompted him to institute measures to try to help mitigate further spread. He announced public schools would remain closed through April 17; restaurants and bars would not be allowed to provide dine-in services but could still provide carryout, curbside pickup, or delivery, beginning Friday, March 20; state government employees would begin working from home; healthcare providers would begin screening all visitors and staff for fever and symptoms; and indoor venues such as gyms would be closed to visitors.<ref name=\"cit23\">{{Cite web
column3: title=As virus cases rise to 62 in state, gov sets new restrictions, extends school closures
column12: website=[[Arkansas Democrat-Gazette]]}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Clark County, Arkansas
column21: Van Buren]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 20, Governor Hutchinson reported during his press conference that the number of cases at that time were up to 96. Thirteen of these new cases were connected to a nursing home in Little Rock where four staff and nine residents tested positive. Dr. Nate Smith added that of the 96 cases, 26 were people over the age of 65, 62 were between ages 19 and 64, and eight were children. Education Secretary [[Johnny Key (politician)
date=March 2014}}: Johnny Key]] said that the state would apply for a federal government waiver to standardized testing requirements. Attorney General [[Leslie Rutledge]] said an additional $3 million would be added to the loan program for small businesses that the governor announced on March 18.<ref name=\"cit24\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Coronavirus cases hit 100 in state, including more than dozen at Little Rock nursing home, agency says
column15: archive-date=20 March 2020}}</ref> Col. John Schuette, installation commander of the [[Little Rock Air Force Base]], announced that an active-duty [[United States Air Force
column16: U.S. Air Force]] airman assigned to the base tested positive. A 30-day public health emergency for the base was declared.<ref name=\"cit25\">{{Cite web
column18: title=Little Rock Air Force Base confirms positive coronavirus test
column25: archive-date=21 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Benton County, Arkansas

column3: Polk]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 21, Governor Hutchinson reported an increase in the number of cases to 118. He said the state expects the spread of the virus to peak in 6 to 8 weeks, at which time there would be an estimated 1,000 Arkansans hospitalized with the disease.<ref name=\"cit26\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Virus cases in state reach 118; peak expected in 6-8 weeks, governor says
column12: archive-date=21 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Sebastian County, Arkansas
column13: Sebastian County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 22, Governor Hutchinson reported an increase in the number of cases to 165. Forty-one of the total cases came from a nursing home in Little Rock. Hutchinson said the state was having a hard tough securing [[personal protective equipment]] (PPE). Arkansas received 25 percent of the PPE the state requested from the federal government's national storehouse. He estimated that 8,000 to 10,000 Arkansans had filed for unemployment in the previous week. Due to such a high number of claims, Hutchinson said he would ask the [[Arkansas General Assembly]] to approve $1.1 million from his rainy day fund for upgrades to the unemployment system. Secretary of Commerce Mike Preston said the Arkansas Economic Development Commission had received around 300 calls and emails inquiring about the business loans the governor had outlined earlier in the week.<ref name=\"cit29\">{{Cite web
column3: title=47 new virus cases bring state's total to 165; cases surge at Little Rock nursing home, governor says
column14: title=Up to 10,000 have applied for unemployment in Arkansas in recent days
column23: archive-date=22 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Columbia County, Arkansas
column27: Woodruff]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 23, Governor Hutchinson announced cases that point of the day had risen to 174. He said the individual income tax filing deadline would be moved to July 15 and he would call for a special legislative session to deal with expected budget shortfalls due to the pandemic. Corporate taxes would still be due April 15. Hutchinson expected an estimated $353 million shortfall for the state budget. Dr. Nate Smith said that five patients at met the criteria to be called recovered cases. Smith announced that barber shops, beauty and nail salons, massage parlors, and tattoo shops would close beginning Tuesday, March 24.<ref name=\"cit32\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Governor extends individual tax deadline, says special session needed; virus cases hit 197
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> In Cleburne County, a deacon for a local church said that 34 people who attended an event at the church had tested positive and others were awaiting results.<ref name=\"cit33\">{{Cite web
column14: title=34 tied to Arkansas church test positive for coronavirus, deacon says
column23: archive-date=23 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Crawford County, Arkansas
column27: White]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The first death in the state was reported on March 24, a 91-year-old male from Faulkner County.<ref name=\"cit34\">{{Cite web
column3: title=1st coronavirus death in Arkansas reported
column12: archive-date=24 March 2020}}</ref> In his daily press conference, Governor Hutchinson reported that a second death had also occurred, a 59-year-old male from [[Sherwood, Arkansas
column13: Sherwood]]. Hutchinson reaffirmed that he did not want to issue a [[Shelter in place
column14: shelter-in-place]] order like other states had despite saying the state was still in the beginning stages of its outbreak. Both Hutchinson and Dr. Nate Smith remarked that April 12 would be too early for the state to return to normal operations, which is the date [[Donald Trump
column15: President Trump]] had targeted during an interview earlier in the day.<ref name=\"cit35\">{{Cite web
column17: title=Second person dies of virus in Arkansas, gov says; state not considering shelter-in-place order at this time
column26: access-date=24 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Cross County, Arkansas
column30: Pike]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 25, the ADH issued a recommendation that all travelers from [[New York (state)
date=March 2014}}: New York]] and all international travelers should self-quarantine for 14 days.<ref name=\"cit40\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Advisory for Travelers from New York State and All International Locations
column9: url-status=live}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Drew County, Arkansas
column10: Drew County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/> On March 26, the state reported its third death from the virus, a 73-year-old male from Cleburne County.<ref name=\"cit36\">{{Cite web
column12: title=Three COVID-19 related deaths in Arkansas, officials say
column19: url-status=live}}</ref> Governor Hutchinson announced a $116 million plan to provide support for healthcare workers in the state, with $91 million coming from the federal government. This plan would provide nurses an additional $1,000 a month with that number rising to $2,000 a month for nurses treating a COVID-19 patient.<ref name=\"cit37\">{{Cite web
column21: title=3rd coronavirus death in Arkansas; governor plans $116 million in healthcare support
column32: archive-date=27 March 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Chicot County, Arkansas
column36: Randolph]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 27, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Baxter County, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: Baxter County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/> On March 28, the state confirmed two more deaths, bringing the total to five. Both cases were in central Arkansas, with one person being in their 70s and the other in their 40s. The number of unemployment claims for the previous week were a record 30,000, an increase from the 9,400 the previous week.<ref name=\"cit41\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Arkansas creates COVID-19 fund as 2 more die from virus
column13: url-status=live}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Johnson County, Arkansas
column14: Johnson County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 29, the state recorded its sixth death. The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Arkansas County, Arkansas
column5: Perry]] counties had a confirmed case, and Hempstead County was reinstated on the map.<ref name=\"cit8\"/> On March 30, the state reported its seventh death, an 83-year-old woman infected in a nursing home in Little Rock. The state legislative leaders approved Governor Hutchinson's request to use $45 million from the newly created COVID-19 rainy-day fund. These funds would primarily be used for the purchase of PPE.<ref name=\"cit42\">{{Cite web
column7: title=Virus cases in Arkansas top 500; nursing home resident is 7th person to die
column18: archive-date=1 April 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Newton County, Arkansas
column20: St. Francis]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/> On March 31, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Miller County, Arkansas
column22: Scott]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 1, two additional deaths were reported, bringing the total to 10. One was from central Arkansas and no other information was provided on the other. [[Arkansas Department of Parks and Tourism]] Secretary Stacy Hurst, in an effort to limit out-of-state tourists, announced that state parks would no longer allow overnight stays and would limit the number of available parking spaces. Certain trails at [[Petit Jean State Park]] and [[Pinnacle Mountain State Park]] were deemed problematic and closed. Hutchinson made a recommendation to the [[United States Secretary of the Interior]], [[David Bernhardt]], that the [[Buffalo National River]] be closed.<ref name=\"cit45\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus cases in Arkansas reach 624; death toll at 10
column12: archive-date=3 April 2020}}</ref> State Rep. [[Reginald Murdock]] of [[Marianna, Arkansas
column13: Marianna]] announced that he had tested positive.<ref name=\"cit46\">{{Cite web
column15: title=Arkansas legislator states he has virus; test pending for 2nd lawmaker
column26: archive-date=3 April 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Carroll County, Arkansas
column28: Lee]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 2, two additional deaths were reported, bringing the total to 12. Both were from central Arkansas, with one being over 65 and the other under 65. Governor Hutchinson defended his decision to not order a shelter-in-place, arguing that the steps the state had taken were enough and that an official order to close non-essential businesses would put at least 100,000 more Arkansans out of work. Wendy Kelly, director of the [[Arkansas Department of Correction]], announced that the state's prisoners would be manufacture cloth masks for the prison system, with an expectation of 80,000 masks being produced.<ref name=\"cit43\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Arkansas prison inmates to make cloth masks; virus deaths in state rise to 12
column12: archive-date=3 April 2020}}</ref> A second member of the state legislature, Rep. [[Vivian Flowers]] of Pine Bluff, tested positive.<ref name=\"cit44\">{{Cite web
column14: title=Second member of Arkansas House infected
column23: archive-date=3 April 2020}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Mississippi County, Arkansas
column27: Sharp]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 3, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Lafayette County, Arkansas
column3: Prairie]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 4, Governor Hutchinson signed an [[executive order]] limiting the types of guests that can stay at hotels, motels, and vacation rentals to:  healthcare professionals; first responders; law enforcement; state or federal employees on official business; National Guard members on active duty; airline crew members; patients of hospitals and their families; journalists; persons unable to return to their home due to COVID-19 travel restrictions; Arkansas citizens unable to return to their home due to exigent circumstances, such as fire, flood, tornado, or other disaster; persons in need of shelter due to domestic violence of homelessness; employees of hotels, motels, or other service providers/contractors of a hotel or motel; and persons away from their home due to work or work-related travel. He added that the state had seen a 40 percent reduction in travel since the beginning of the emergency.<ref name=\"cit47\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Governor Hutchinson Issues Executive Order Requiring New Protocols for Commercial Lodgings, Short-Term Rentals
column12: title=Governor restricts out-of-state travelers from coming into Arkansas amid COVID-19 pandemic
column21: url-status=live}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Dallas County, Arkansas
column22: Dallas County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 5, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Phillips County, Arkansas
On April 6, Governor Hutchinson announced that schools would remain closed for the remainder of the school year.<ref name=\"cit52\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Coronavirus in Arkansas: Governor announces public schools remain online through end of school year
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> He also announced that the state would send five [[ventilators]] to [[Louisiana]] to help with their spread of the disease, saying Arkansas has around 800 ventilators with about 550 not being used.<ref name=\"cit51\">{{Cite web
column13: title=Arkansas to give ventilators to Louisiana
column22: url-status=live}}</ref> The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Clay County, Arkansas
column26: Logan]] counties had confirmed cases.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 8, the state reported its 1,000th case. The ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Madison County, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: Madison County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On April 10, the ADH's website updated their county map to show [[Marion County, Arkansas
date=March 2014}}: Marion County]] had a confirmed case.<ref name=\"cit8\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 11, Governor Hutchinson declared a public health emergency in response to the first presumptive case in the state.<ref name=\"cit1\"/> On March 12, the governor ordered school closings in Saline, Jefferson, Pulaski, and Grant counties until March 30.<ref name=\"cit2\"/> On March 14, Hutchinson activated the [[Arkansas National Guard]] to provide support with logistics, transportation, and other needs.<ref name=\"cit5\"/> All public schools were ordered to close beginning Tuesday, March 17.<ref name=\"cit9\"/> On March 17, Hutchinson closed casinos for two weeks and loosened restrictions on claiming unemployment benefits for 30 days.<ref name=\"cit17\"/> On March 19, Hutchinson announced new measures to help limit the spread of the disease, including keeping public schools closed through April 17 and banning restaurants and bars from providing dine-in services.<ref name=\"cit23\"/> On March 23, the individual income tax filing deadline was pushed back until July 15, and barber shops, beauty and nail salons, massage parlors, and tattoo parlors were ordered to close on Tuesday, March 24.<ref name=\"cit32\"/> On April 3, state parks began to limit their available parking spaces and ended overnight stays.<ref name=\"cit45\"/>
On April 6, the governor ordered public schools to close for the remainder of the school year.<ref name=\"cit52\"/>

column3: Frank Scott, Jr.]] announced a citywide curfew to keep residents from being outside from 12 a.m. to 5 a.m. beginning Wednesday, March 18. This did not apply to people traveling to and from work. Little Rock police officers would question people in public places, but not stop drivers. Additionally, homeless individuals would not be cited.<ref name=\"cit14\">{{Cite web
column5: title=Little Rock mayor announces citywide curfew to limit spread of coronavirus
column15: archive-date=17 March 2020}}</ref> On March 25, Scott extended the curfew to begin at 9 p.m. and end at 5 a.m. He also announced the introduction of a daytime curfew for minors from 9:00 a.m. to 2:30 p.m. that would be in effect from March 30 to April 17.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: title=Little Rock mayor extends city curfew, enforcing it with citations

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 16, the Fayetteville city council voted unanimously to grant the mayor emergency powers to regulate gatherings. The council also appropriated $3 million in emergency funds to address the pandemic locally.<ref name=\"cit19\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Fayetteville council grants mayor power to regulate gatherings

date=March 2014}}: Jonesboro]] announced on March 15 that beginning Tuesday, March 17, all in-person instructions would transition to all-online instructions for the remainder of the semester. The campus would remain open. Graduation ceremonies would be reevaluated as they got closer.<ref name=\"cit18\">{{cite web
column4: title=A-State Transitions to All-Online Course Delivery

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: [[Southeast Arkansas College]] in Pine Bluff closed on March 11 after three students had been exposed to the original Pine Bluff patient.<ref name=\"cit4\">{{Cite web
column3: title=Southeast Arkansas College closed after three students exposed to presumptive COVID-19 patient

date=March 2014}}: Magnolia]] announced on March 12 that it was canceling all face-to-face classes scheduled for the week of March 16 through March 20, prior to the week of spring break. Course delivery would shift fully online beginning March 30 and continuing through the end of the semester. The campus was not closed and housing, dining, and other services would remain in operation.<ref name=\"cit11\">{{Cite web
column4: title=SAU moves to online course delivery March 30

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The [[University of Arkansas]] at Fayetteville announced on March 12 that it was suspending all in-person classes immediately and would begin online courses starting Monday, March 16, and continue through the end of the semester. The campus was not closed and housing, dining, and other services would remain in operation.<ref name=\"cit10\">{{Cite web
column3: title=In-Person Classes Suspended; Online Course Delivery Starts March 16
column9: archive-date=18 March 2020}}</ref> After a student tested positive for COVID-19 on March 24, the university announced it would be closing campus and gave student until April 3 to leave.<ref name=\"cit38\">{{Cite web
column11: title=University of Arkansas student tests positive for COVID-19

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The [[University of Arkansas at Little Rock]] announced on the afternoon of March 12 that in-person instruction would transition immediately to online instruction. The campus would remain open. Graduation ceremonies would be reevaluated as they got closer.<ref name=\"cit31\">{{Cite web
column3: title=UA Little Rock Migrates to Online Classes Immediately

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The [[University of Arkansas at Monticello]] (UAM) announced on March 17 that all instructions would move to an online setting through the end of the semester. The university remained open, including residence halls and food services.<ref name=\"cit27\">{{Cite web
column3: title=UAM Announces Instruction Will Remain Online Until End of Spring Semester
column10: archive-date=21 March 2020}}</ref> On March 19, UAM, based on a recommendation from the University of Arkansas Board of Trustees, announced that spring commencement exercises would be postponed and graduates would be invited to participate in the December 11 commencement ceremony.<ref name=\"cit28\">{{Cite web
column12: title=UA System Vote Postpones May Commencement Ceremony at UAM Due to Current Health Crisis

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The [[Arkansas Activities Association]] announced on March 12 via Twitter that all spring sports and activities would be suspended from March 15 through March 30 with plans to reassess at that time.<ref name=\"cit20\">{{Cite tweet
In college sports, the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association]] cancelled all winter and spring tournaments, most notably the [[NCAA Division I
date=March 2014}}: Division I]] [[2020 NCAA Division I Men's Basketball Tournament
column3: men]]'s and [[2020 NCAA Division I Women's Basketball Tournament
column4: women]]'s basketball tournaments, affecting colleges and universities statewide.<ref name=\"cit15\">{{Cite web
column6: title=NCAA cancels remaining winter and spring championships
column12: archive-date=12 March 2020}}</ref> On March 16, the [[National Junior College Athletic Association]] also canceled the remainder of the winter seasons as well as the spring seasons.<ref name=\"cit16\">{{Cite web
column14: title=NJCAA cancels spring sports, basketball nationals amid coronavirus outbreak

column8: n}}) is a city in [[Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column9: Ozaukee County]], [[Wisconsin]], United States. Located on [[Interstate 43]], the community is a [[suburb]] in the [[Milwaukee metropolitan area]]. It [[Municipal corporation
column10: incorporated]] as a [[Administrative divisions of Wisconsin#City
column11: city]] in 1957 to avoid annexation by the City of [[Milwaukee]]. At the time of the [[2010 United States Census

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: \"Mequon\" may have come from the [[Ojibwe language
date=March 2014}}: Ojibwe]] word \"Emikwaan\" or \"Miguan\", meaning ladle, referring to the shape of the river in the area.<ref>\"[http://www.co.ozaukee.wi.us/history/YankeeSettler.htm \"Yankee Settler's Cottage.\"] {{webarchive
column4: date=2006-04-20}} [[Ozaukee County, Wisconsin]] website</ref> Alternatively, the name may come from an [[Algonquian languages
column5: Algonquin]] word meaning \"feather\", as suggested by the current [[Menominee]] name of the town: ''Mēkon''.<ref>{{Cite web

column4: The [[Isham Day House]] is now a museum located in Settlers Park.]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The area was originally inhabited by Native Americans, including the [[Menominee]], [[Potawatomi]], and [[Sauk people]]. In the early 19th century, the   Potawatomi had a village in present-day [[Thiensville, Wisconsin
date=March 2014}}: Thiensville]] located on Pigeon Creek, north of Freistadt Road. In 1831, The Menominee surrendered the land between the [[Milwaukee River]] and [[Lake Michigan]] to the United States Federal Government through the [[Treaty of Washington, with Menominee (1831)
column3: Treaty of Washington]].<ref name= \"corrigan\">Walter D. Corrigan, ''History of the Town of Mequon, Ozaukee County, Wisconsin, Brought Down to about 1870''. Mequon: Mequon Club, 1950.</ref> The Potawatomi surrendered the area of Mequon west of the Milwaukee River in 1833 through the [[Treaty of Chicago]], which required them to leave the area by 1838.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Early history of Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column7: accessdate=2020-01-03}}</ref> While many Native people moved west of the Mississippi River to [[Kansas]], some chose to remain, and were known as \"strolling Potawatomi\" because they were migrant [[Squatting
column8: squatters]]. Eventually the Potawatomi who evaded forced removal gathered in northern Wisconsin, where they formed the [[Forest County Potawatomi Community]].<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: White trappers, explorers, and traders used the Milwaukee River through the middle of what is now Mequon as a means of transportation. The first permanent white settlers arrived in the mid-1830s from New York, England, and Ireland. One of the first settlers was John Weston, who settled near present-day Thiensville in 1837 and served as the first postmaster of the Town of Mequon. One of the oldest surviving buildings from this period is the [[Isham Day House]], constructed in 1839 on the west bank of the river. The first [[Germans]] arrived in 1839, and in the 1840s Germans became the largest ethnic group in Mequon and Ozaukee County.<ref>{{cite web
date=March 2014}}: title=Early history of Ozaukee County, Wisconsin

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In October 1839, a party of twenty German families from [[Province of Pomerania (1815–1945)
date=March 2014}}: Pomerania]], [[Prussia]], settled the Freistadt community in the western part of the Town of Mequon. They were [[Old Lutherans]] who had resisted the Prussian government's attempts to take control over the Protestant churches through the [[Prussian Union of Churches]].<ref>Ozaukee County. [http://www.co.ozaukee.wi.us/777/Trinity-Evangelical-Lutheran-Church---Fr Trinity Evangelical Lutheran Church - Freistadt]</ref> In German, \"Freistadt\" means \"Free City\".<ref>*[http://www.wisconsinhistory.org/dictionary/index.asp?action=view&term_id=5544 Freistadt] in ''Dictionary of Wisconsin History''</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 1840, they built a log cabin church, which they named Trinity Lutheran Church. It was the first Lutheran church in Wisconsin. In 1845, what would become the [[Lutheran Synod of Buffalo]] was organized in Freistadt. However, the Freistadt church became a part of the [[Lutheran Church–Missouri Synod]] in 1848.<ref>{{cite web
date=March 2014}}: title=Early history of Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column5: accessdate=2020-01-03}}</ref> The wooden church was replaced with a limestone building in 1884.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Joachim Heinrich Thien moved to the area in 1842 from [[Oldenburg]], [[Prussia]], and helped design a plan for the settlement that would become [[Thiensville, Wisconsin
date=March 2014}}: Thiensville]]. A year later he employed a group of Native American laborers to construct a dam and a canal. He then built a sawmill and a store. Thien hosted the first town meeting for the Town of Mequon in 1846,<ref name= \"corrigan\"/> and in 1857 he established the volunteer fire department and served as its first captain.

freethinker]], as were many of the early German settlers. The influence of the freethinker societies kept formal churches out of the village until 1919, when St. Cecilia Catholic Church was built.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Encyclopedia of Milwaukee: Village of Thiensville

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Thiensville grew in part because of its location on the [[Chicago, Milwaukee, St. Paul and Pacific Railroad
date=March 2014}}: Chicago, Milwaukee & St. Paul Railway]], which was constructed in the early 1870s. In the late 19th and early 20th centuries, Thiensville was one of the most concentrated communities in the Town of Mequon. While most of Mequon was quite rural, Theinsville functioned as a downtown area with stores, mills, and professional services. The village of Theinsville incorporated in 1910.

prisoners of war]] from Camp Fredonia in [[Little Kohler, Wisconsin]] were contracted to work at the Herbert A. Nieman Canning Company in the village to make up for the loss of labor due to local men fighting in [[World War II]].<ref>{{Cite book
column4: title=Stalag Wisconsin: Inside WW II Prisoner-of-war Camps
column11: language=en}}</ref> German prisoners from Camp Rockfield in [[Rockfield, Wisconsin]], (located in present-day [[Germantown, Wisconsin
column12: Germantown]]) also worked at the Fromm Bros., Nieman & Co. Fox Ranch in northern Mequon.<ref>{{Cite book
column14: title=Stalag Wisconsin: Inside WW II Prisoner-of-war Camps

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In the 20th century, Mequon and the village of Theinsville developed a close relationship,<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=City of Mequon and Village of Thiensville Community Gateway Features {{!}} Mequon Wisconsin
column7: title=Mequon-Thiensville School District {{!}} The Launchpad to Success
column16: title=Frank L. Weyenberg Library of Mequon-Thiensville {{!}} Official Website

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The Town of Mequon experienced significant population growth during the [[suburbanization]] that followed World War II. Between 1950 and 1960, the population increased by roughly 110%, from 4,065 to 8,543. With growth came the risk that municipalities such as Thiensville or [[Milwaukee]] would try to annex land from the Town of Mequon, as happened to the Milwaukee County's [[Lake, Milwaukee County, Wisconsin
date=March 2014}}: Town of Lake]] in 1954 and [[Granville, Milwaukee
column3: Town of Granville]] in 1956. With a 1957 population of about 7,500, Mequon incorporated as a city under the terms of Wisconsin statute 66.0215, also known as \"The Oak Creek Law,\" which had been crafted to prevent suburban towns from being annexed by other municipalities.<ref>[http://nxt.legis.state.wi.us/nxt/gateway.dll?f=templates&fn=default.htm&vid=WI:Default&d=stats&jd=66.0215 Wisconsin Legislature Data<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref name=\"Encyclopedia\">{{cite web
column4: title=Encyclopedia of Milwaukee: City of Mequon

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The city continued to grow with the construction of [[Interstate 43]] in the mid-1960s, making travel to Milwaukee easier. Despite being a city, much of Mequon remains rural, and nearly half of the land in the community in undeveloped.

column12: mi}} north of Milwaukee and is part of the [[Milwaukee–Racine–Waukesha Metropolitan Area
column18: title=US Gazetteer files: 2010, 2000, and 1990}}</ref> According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the city has a total area of {{convert
column37: archivedate=2012-01-24}}</ref> As of 2005, Mequon was the third-largest city in terms of land area in the state of [[Wisconsin]].<ref>[http://www.lwm-info.org/vertical/Sites/%7B92F7D640-E25A-4317-90AD-4976378A8F8D%7D/uploads/%7B3468C14F-4B58-4594-9571-E14499B23DD9%7D.PDF Estimated Population per Square Mile of Land Area, Wisconsin Municipalities] {{webarchive
column39: date=2011-10-05 }}. The cities of [[Milwaukee]] (96.14 sq mi) and [[Madison, Wisconsin
column40: Madison]] (75.40 sq mi) are larger. Green Bay (45.53 sq mi) is the next largest city. The village of [[Kronenwetter, Wisconsin
column41: Kronenwetter]] is also larger, as are more than 200 [[Political subdivisions of Wisconsin#Town
column42: towns]].</ref> Though much of the population lives in residential areas, approximately half of the land within the city's boundaries is undeveloped or farmed.<ref name=Citywebsite>{{cite web

date=March 2014}}: Village of Thiensville]] is an [[Enclave and exclave
column3: enclave]] in central Mequon. The city is also bordered by the [[Cedarburg (town), Wisconsin
column6: Town of Grafton]] to the north; [[Lake Michigan]] to the east; the [[Bayside, Wisconsin
column8: Village of River Hills]], [[Brown Deer, Wisconsin
column10: City of Milwaukee]] to the south; and the [[Germantown, Wisconsin
column11: Village of Germantown]] to the west.

column3: The clay bluffs in Virmond Park along Lake Michigan]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The city is located on the western shore of [[Lake Michigan]], and the coastline is characterized by clay [[Cliff
date=March 2014}}: bluffs]] ranging from 80 feet (24 meters) to 140 feet (43 meters) in height with deep [[ravine]]s where streams flow into the lake. Clay bluffs are a geological formation characteristic of the Lake Michigan shoreline, and are found in few other areas of the world. Much of the coast has mixed gravel and sand beaches.<ref name=\"Resources\">{{cite web
column3: title=Inventory of Agricultural, Natural, and Cultural Resources
column7: title=Central Lake Michigan Coastal Ecological Landscape

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The city is located in the [[Southeastern Wisconsin Till Plains (ecoregion)
date=March 2014}}: Southeastern Wisconsin glacial till plains]] that were created by the [[Wisconsin glaciation]] during the most recent ice age. The soil is clayey glacial [[till]] with a thin layer of [[loess]] on the surface. The town has some [[limestone]] deposits, including the [[Devonian]] Thiensville formation in north-central Mequon and the [[Silurian]] Little Menomonee River Reef District, which contains [[Dolomite (rock)
column3: dolomite]] marine fossils. The [[Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources]] considers the eastern part of the city along the lake to be in the Central Lake Michigan Coastal ecological landscape, while the western part of the city is in the Southern Lake Michigan Coastal ecological landscape.<ref name=\"Resources\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The [[Milwaukee River]] and its [[tributary]] Pigeon Creek flow through the eastern part of the city. Little Menomonee Creek and the Little Menomonee River, which are tributaries of the [[Menomonee River]], flow through western Mequon.<ref name=\"GR3\"/>
Before white settlers arrived in the area, the Mequon was an upland forest dominated by [[Fagus grandifolia
column3: sugar maple]] trees. There is also a large [[Larix laricina
column4: tamarack]] swamp along the Little Menomonee River. Much of the original forest was cleared to prepare the land for agriculture.<ref name=Resources />

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: As land development continues to reduce wild areas, wildlife is forced into closer proximity with human communities like Grafton. Large mammals, including [[white-tailed deer]], [[coyotes]], and [[red fox]]es can be seen in the city. Many birds, including [[great blue heron]]s and [[wild turkey]]s are found in the city.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=February 13, 2020}}</ref> The city is also home to many rare and notable species, including the state-designated endangered [[Pterospora
column10: yellow gentian]]; as well as [[Lithospermum latifolium
column12: twinleaf]], which are state-designated special concern plant species.<ref name=Resources />

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The region struggles with many invasive species, including the [[emerald ash borer]], [[common carp]], [[Phalaris arundinacea

Mequon experiences four distinct [[season]]s, with variation in precipitation and temperature being very wide. The overall climate of the city is moderated by nearby [[Lake Michigan]], which causes temperatures to be cooler in summer and especially spring, and which keeps overnight temperatures warmer in winter. In March and April, the temperature in Mequon can be 10 to 15 degrees Fahrenheit (5 to 8 degrees Celsius) cooler than temperatures in towns just 15 miles (25 kilometers) farther from the lake.{{Citation needed
date=March 2014}}: date=November 2012}} In December and January, the effect is reversed, with temperatures in inland towns falling much lower.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In Mequon, the warmest month of the year is July, when the high temperature averages 81 °F (27 °C), with low temperatures of approximately 59 °F (15 °C). June and July are the wettest months of the year, with the majority of [[rain]] falling in short-lived [[thunderstorm]]s. January is the coldest month in Mequon, with average high temperatures averaging only 27 °F (-3 °C), and lows averaging 11 °F (-12 °C).<ref name=TWC>{{cite web
date=March 2014}}: title=Average Weather for Mequon, WI - Temperature and Precipitation
column6: accessdate=29 November 2012}}</ref> February is the driest month, with almost all precipitation falling in the form of [[snow]]. In an average winter, 47.0 in (1.3m) of snow falls. The city's proximity to Lake Michigan often [[lake-effect snow
column7: increases]] the snow received by the city. Most of the city's snowfall comes from systems such as [[Alberta clipper]]s and [[Panhandle hook]]s.{{Citation needed

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The highest temperature ever recorded in Mequon was 105 °F (41 °C) on July 24, 1935, and again on July 17, 1995. The coldest temperature ever recorded in the city was -40 °F (-40 °C), on January 17, 1982, also known as [[Cold Sunday]].<ref name=TWC/>

column3: Located in rural northwest Mequon, the [[O'Brien-Peuschel Farmstead]] was settled in 1846 and has extant buildings dating to as early as 1850. It is [[National Register of Historic Places listings in Ozaukee County, Wisconsin
column4: listed]] on the [[National Register of Historic Places]].]]

column3: Farmers in eastern Mequon built [[Round barn#Octagonal
column4: octagonal barns]], believing the shape to be better suited to the winds coming off nearby Lake Michigan. The 1891 Frank Vocke barn is a surviving example of these once-common barns.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=The Clausing Octagon Barns of Ozaukee County: An In-Depth Study

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Mequon's economy was primarily agricultural. Some farmsteads from as early as the 1840s and 1850s still stand in the community and are listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]]. The first major businesses were hydropowered mills on the Milwaukee River and other businesses that served local farmers, many of which concentrated in Thiensville.<ref>{{cite news
Beginning in the 1920s, the Nieman and Fromm families began [[fur farming]] [[Silver fox (animal)
date=March 2014}}: silver foxes]] in Mequon. Several companies, including Fromm Bros., Nieman & Co.; Federal Silver Fox Farms, Inc.; Ozaukee Fur Farms Co.; Herbert A. Nieman & Co.; and Cedarburg Fox Farms, Inc. all began operating in Mequon and southern Cedarburg in the 1920s. In 1928, 6600 of the 8841 pelts sold by the New York Auction Co. came from the Fromm and Nieman operations in Wisconsin for a record-breaking sum of $1,021,000. In 1929, the Nieman and Fromm operations broke their own record with auction sales of $1,331,679, making them a leader in the national fur industry. By 1937, the farms were selling 30,000 pelts per year. After World War II, changing consumer tastes caused the farms to begin breeding [[mink]] in addition to silver fox. Fur sales declined later in the 20th century, and farms sold their last pelts in 1985.<ref>{{cite news

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The mid-to-late 20th century saw diversification in Mequon's economy. Retail stores opened to serve the increasingly suburban community, and manufacturers opened plants. In 1983, [[Concordia University Wisconsin]] moved from its campus in Milwaukee to a newly acquired campus in Mequon. In 1994, St. Mary's Hospital Ozaukee opened. As of 2015, the two institutions—both located in close proximity to [[Interstate 43]]—were among the largest employers in Ozaukee County. Despite the growth of new industries, half of Mequon's land remains undeveloped and agriculture continues to play a significant role in the local economy.<ref name=\"Encyclopedia\"/>

column4: title=City of Mequon Community Economic Profile 2015

date=March 2014}}: Ascension Columbia St. Mary's Hospital Ozaukee

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Mequon has had a [[mayor–council government]] since its incorporation in 1957. The current mayor is John Wirth, who was elected to his first three-year term on April 2, 2019. The eight aldermen on the common council also serve three-year terms. The council meets on the second Tuesday of each month in Mequon City Hall at 7:30 p.m. A full-time staff of unelected administrators manage the city's day-to-day operations.<ref>https://www.ci.mequon.wi.us/commoncouncil</ref>
As part of [[Wisconsin's 6th congressional district]], Mequon is represented by [[Glenn Grothman]] (R) in the [[United States House of Representatives]], and by [[Ron Johnson (Wisconsin politician)
date=March 2014}}: Ron Johnson]] (R) and [[Tammy Baldwin]] (D) in the [[United States Senate]]. [[Alberta Darling]] (R) represents Mequon in the [[Wisconsin State Senate]]. Eastern Mequon is part of the [[Wisconsin State Assembly]]'s 23rd District and is represented by [[Jim Ott]] (R), while western Mequon is part of the 24th District and is represented by [[Dan Knodl]] (R).<ref>{{cite web

column6: Thomas P. Leisle<ref>''[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=-00aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=aykEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6146,3412873 Milwaukee Journal]'', April 7, 1971.</ref><ref>''[https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=bWkaAAAAIBAJ&sjid=-SkEAAAAIBAJ&pg=4275,5080317 Milwaukee Journal]'', December 6, 1982.</ref>
Christine Nuernberg<ref>''[http://www.jsonline.com/news/ozwash/43403022.html The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]'', April 21, 2009.</ref>
[[Curt Gielow]]<ref name=\"ReferenceA\">'Challenger Abendroth beats Mayor Gietlow in Mequon,' '''Milwaukee Sentinel Journal,''' Don Behm, April 2, 2013</ref>

John Wirth<ref>''[https://www.jsonline.com/story/communities/northshore/news/mequon/2019/04/02/spring-election-results-john-wirth-elected-mequon-mayor/3347311002.html The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel]'', April 2, 2019.</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Mequon's fire department was founded in 1933. There are two active fire stations in the community: one serving the east side and the other serving the west side. Fire Chief David Bialk has served with the department since 2006 oversees a staff of approximately sixty firefighters, EMTs and paramedics.<ref>{{cite web

The Mequon Police Department was established in 1958 and is located in the City of Mequon Safety Building, which also serves as one of the city's fire stations. Police Chief Patrick Pryor has served with the department since 1999.<ref>{{cite web

column3: Concordia University of Wisconsin's School of Pharmacy, in Mequon.]]

In 2009, Homestead was ranked by ''BusinessWeek'' magazine as the state's top high school.<ref>[http://images.businessweek.com/ss/09/01/0115_best_schools/51.htm American's Best High Schools], ''Bloomberg Businesweek''.</ref> The school's mascot is a Highlander.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Mequon has a number of higher education institutions, including [[Concordia University Wisconsin]], the [[Wisconsin Lutheran Seminary]], and the northern campus of the [[Milwaukee Area Technical College]].
