→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Because of this, [[Sony Pictures]] decided to not promote the horror film ''[[Brightburn]]'', which Gunn produced, at the 2018 [[San Diego Comic-Con]].<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Sony avoids mentioning James Gunn at Comic-Con presentation
column10: work=Page Six}}</ref> However, when the first trailer for the film was released on December 8, 2018, Gunn's name was prominently featured. The film opened in May 2019.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In March 2019, Gunn was reinstated by Disney as director of the film after meeting with [[Alan Horn]], chairman of Walt Disney Studios, on multiple occasions. Gunn will start production on the film once his work on ''The Suicide Squad'' has been completed.<ref name=\"GunnRehired\">{{cite web
column3: title=Disney Reinstates Director James Gunn For 'Guardians Of The Galaxy 3'

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn married actress [[Jenna Fischer]] on October 7, 2000, in an event that Gunn's hometown paper reported was officiated by [[Lloyd Kaufman]],<ref name=\"stltoday.com\"/> but which Gunn later clarified had not been: \"They said I was married by Lloyd Kaufman, which is not true. He was ''at'' my wedding and he gave a speech.\"<ref name=lloydkaufman /> Gunn and Fischer had originally met in the St. Louis area through Gunn's brother Sean, who had acted in plays alongside Fischer in high school.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After seven years of marriage, Gunn and Fischer announced their separation in a joint statement on September 5, 2007,<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=James Gunn Shares Post on Ex Jenna Fischer, Says Not All Failed Relationships Make Enemies
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2010, Fischer persuaded Gunn to cast [[Rainn Wilson]], her co-star on ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)
column18: The Office]]'', in Gunn's film ''[[Super (2010 American film)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn has been in a relationship with actress Jennifer Holland since 2015.<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Jennifer Holland, James Gunn's Girlfriend: 5 Fast Facts You Need to Know

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn was raised in a Roman Catholic family and has mentioned how prayer continues to play an important role in his life,<ref>{{cite web
column3: title='Guardians of the Galaxy' director defends Chris Pratt's tweet to Kevin Smith after backlash
column4: publisher=}}</ref> but has also said that he is \"in some ways, anti-religion\".<ref>{{Citation
column6: title=The Indoor Kids #58 — Everything with James Gunn (NSFW)
column13: archivedate=March 4, 2016}}</ref> Gunn explained his views in detail in 2016: {{quote
column14: My personal take is that there is a role for spirituality in some people's lives and I think that a belief in God can be a good thing for a great amount of people [...] I do not like any sort of faith or religion that is based on exclusivity, meaning any sort of religion that says you're damned to hell or you're not going to be saved because you don't believe the same thing I do. I believe faith and spiritual belief is a very, very personal thing and if I started applying what I believe to everybody else it would be unfair to everybody's individuality and I really hate that.<ref>{{cite web

column6: title=A Star Is Born: James Gunn turns 51 today
column11: While many sources give a birth year of 1970,<ref name=tribute>{{cite web
column17: accessdate=November 7, 2015}}</ref> Gunn graduated from [[St. Louis University High School]] in 1984,<ref name=alumni /> making 1970 questionable.<ref name=\"stltoday.com\" />
column19: name=born}}  is an American filmmaker and musician. He began his career as a screenwriter, working on movies like ''[[Scooby-Doo (film)
column20: Scooby-Doo]]''. He then began working as a director, starting with the horror-comedy film ''[[Slither (2006 film)
column21: Slither]]'' (2006), and eventually moving to the superhero genre through ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column22: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'' and ''[[The Suicide Squad (film)
column23: The Suicide Squad]]''. He also wrote and directed the web series ''[[James Gunn's PG Porn]]'' (2008–09), the [[superhero film]] ''[[Super (2010 American film)
column24: Super]]'' (2010), and the sequel to the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] film ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column25: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'' (2014) - ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2]]'' (2017).

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn was born in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]<ref name=tribute /> to parents Leota<ref name=\"GunnNoClose\">{{cite web
column3: title=James Gunn says 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2' a family affair
column13: url-status=bot: unknown}}Additional  on May 5, 2017.</ref> and James F. Gunn, an attorney.<ref name=\"stltoday.com\">{{cite web
column15: title=St. Louis director James Gunn goes galactic
column24: quote=Gunn graduated from SLUH in 1984. (Several sources, including IMDb.com, say he was born in 1970, but you do the math.)}}</ref> He was raised between St. Louis and [[Manchester, Missouri]].<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=5 Weird Things about STL Native and Guardians of the Galaxy Director James Gunn
column41: url=https://www.facebook.com/jgunn/info}}</ref> He has five siblings: actor [[Sean Gunn
column42: Sean]], actor and political writer [[Matt Gunn
column51: accessdate=November 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://qualiacapital.com/patrick-gunn Patrick Gunn profile], qualiacapital.com; accessed December 4, 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web
column59: Irish]]<ref>https://twitter.com/JamesGunn/status/812059184787165185</ref> and [[Jewish]]<ref>https://twitter.com/JamesGunn/status/736640431031779329</ref> heritage. Gunn has stated that his family's surname was originally the [[Irish people
column60: Irish]] name MacGilgunn and that it means \"sons to the servants of the god of the dead\"; it means \"son of the brown one\".<ref>Interview with James Gunn (April 4, 2012). ''The 404 Podcast'' episode 1047</ref><ref>{{cite web
column61: title=Mac Giolla Dhuinn – Irish Names and Surnames

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Growing up, Gunn was influenced by low-budget films such as ''[[Night of the Living Dead]]'' and ''[[Friday the 13th (1980 film)
date=March 2014}}: Friday the 13th]]''. He read magazines like ''[[Fangoria]]'' and attended genre movie screenings, including the original ''[[Dawn of the Dead (1978 film)
column3: Dawn of the Dead]]'' at the [[Tivoli Theatre (University City, Missouri)
column4: Tivoli Theatre]] in St. Louis. At the age of 12, he began making [[8 mm film
column5: 8 mm]] [[zombie film]]s with his brothers in the woods near their home.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\">{{cite news
column7: title=A Conversation With Director James Gunn

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn and his brothers all attended the [[Jesuit]] [[St. Louis University High School]], where he graduated in 1984.<ref name=alumni>{{cite web
column9: quote=James Gunn '84, filmmaker and screenwriter; Brian Gunn '88, screenwriter; Matt Gunn '90, writer for HBO show Real Time with Bill Maher; Sean Gunn '92, actor.}}</ref><ref name=\"stltoday.com\" /> He went on to earn a [[Bachelor of Arts]] from [[Saint Louis University]].<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=SCA Network Screening and Q&A: Guardians of the Galaxy > About the Guests
column12: publisher=[[University of Southern California School of Cinematic Arts]]
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> While at Saint Louis University, Gunn created political cartoons for the school's student weekly, The University News.<ref name=\"unewsonline.com\">{{cite news
column19: title=Gunn known for his comedy, horror and 'Scooby-Doo'
column20: accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> Gunn said that, at an unspecified time in his college education, \"I went to two years undergraduate film school at [[Loyola Marymount]] in [[Los Angeles]]. But I was pretty screwed up at the time, and had to leave. Years later I went to graduate school at the [[Columbia University School of Fine Arts]] but I studied prose writing, not film writing.\"<ref>{{cite web
column28: df=mdy-all }}</ref> He earned a [[Master of Fine Arts]] from Columbia University in 1995.<ref>{{cite web
column30: title=James Gunn ('95) Co-Writes and Directs 'Guardians of the Galaxy'
column31: publisher=[[Columbia University School of the Arts]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: While living in St. Louis, Gunn founded a band, The Icons, in 1989, serving as lead vocalist. The group released the album ''Mom, We Like It Here on Earth'' in 1994, and its songs \"Sunday\" and \"Walking Naked\" were featured in the film ''[[Tromeo and Juliet]]''. The Icons disbanded in the mid-1990s.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2018-08-06}}</ref> Gunn has continued to work in music, composing songs for ''[[Scooby-Doo (film)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: [[File:James Gunn - Guardians of the Galaxy premiere - July 2014 (cropped).jpg

Gunn began his career in filmmaking with [[Troma Entertainment]] in 1995, for which he wrote the independent film ''Tromeo and Juliet''. Working alongside his mentor [[Lloyd Kaufman]], the co-founder of Troma, Gunn learned how to write screenplays, produce films, scout locations, direct actors, distribute films, and create his own poster art.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After contributing to several other Troma films, Gunn in 2000 wrote, produced and performed in the superhero comedy ''[[The Specials (2000 film)
date=March 2014}}: The Specials]]'', directed by [[Craig Mazin]] and featuring [[Rob Lowe]], [[Thomas Haden Church]], [[Paget Brewster]], [[Judy Greer]] and [[Jamie Kennedy]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn's first major Hollywood screenplay was ''Scooby-Doo'' in 2002. In 2004, he wrote the screenplays for the remake of ''[[Dawn of the Dead (2004 film)
date=March 2014}}: Dawn of the Dead]]'' and the sequel ''Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed''. With these films, Gunn became the first screenwriter to have two films top the box office in consecutive weeks.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Strike Let St. Louisan James Gunn Widen His Horizons
column10: accessdate=June 16, 2014}}</ref> That same year, he executive produced and starred in the mockumentary ''[[LolliLove]]'', directed by and starring his then-wife [[Jenna Fischer]]. His film directorial debut was the 2006 horror-comedy ''[[Slither (2006 film)
column11: Slither]]'', which was included on Rotten Tomatoes' list of the 50 Best Ever Reviewed Horror Movies.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn's next projects included the comedy short film \"Humanzee!\" which was originally intended exclusively for the Xbox Live's ''Horror Meets Comedy'' series of short comedy films by horror directors, it was replaced with \"Sparky and Mikaela\" which debuted on Xbox Live on December 31, 2008. In an April 2009 interview on ''The [[Jace Hall]] Show'', Gunn described \"Sparky and Mikaela\" as being \"about a human [and] racoon crime fighting team and they fight crime in both the forest world, among the furry animals, and in the human world\".<ref>{{cite episode
column6: number=5}}</ref> Gunn also has a short-form web series for [[Spike.com]] titled ''[[James Gunn's PG Porn]]''.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2008, Gunn was a judge on the [[VH1]] reality television show, ''[[Scream Queens (2008 TV series)
date=March 2014}}: Scream Queens]]'' where 10 unknown actresses compete for a role in the film ''[[Saw VI]]'', where he directed contestants during acting challenges.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=A Search For Authenticity on the Set of 'Scream Queens' Season 2

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2009, Gunn announced he was going to write and direct ''Pets'', a comedy about a man who is abducted by aliens who want to turn him into a household pet, with [[Ben Stiller]], [[Stuart Cornfeld]] and Jeremy Kramer producing.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=New Regency adopts 'Pets' pitch – James Gunn to write and direct comedy
column8: accessdate=January 3, 2009}}</ref> However, by March 2009, Gunn announced, \"''Pets'' unfortunately, is done. I'm gone. I left the project for various reasons. I hope it sees the light of day somehow, but it won't be with me attached as director.\"<ref>{{cite web

date=March 2014}}: Super]]'', a [[dark comedy]] and [[superhero]] satire starring [[Rainn Wilson]] and [[Ellen Page]]. Gunn co-wrote and directed the [[Marvel Studios]] adaptation of ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column3: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'', which was released on August 1, 2014.<ref name=\"GunnGotG\">{{cite web
column7: title=James Gunn Confirmed to Direct and Rewrite Guardians of the Galaxy
column14: Sean]], has a role in the film. Gunn has appeared as an actor, mostly in smaller roles or uncredited appearances in his own projects. [[Dan Gilroy]] and [[Jack Black]] separately lamented the proliferation of superhero films,<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Superhero Movies Dissed at Oscars Despite 9 Acting Nominees With Comic Book Roles
column24: url-status=live}}</ref> Gunn responded in a Facebook post, saying in part:{{quote
column25: text=[P]opular fare in any medium has always been snubbed by the self-appointed elite. ... What bothers me slightly is that many people assume because you make big films that you put less love, care, and thought into them then people do who make independent films or who make what are considered more serious Hollywood films. ... If you think people who make superhero movies are dumb, come out and say we're dumb. But if you, as an independent filmmaker or a 'serious' filmmaker, think you put more love into your characters than the Russo Brothers do Captain America, or Joss Whedon does the Hulk, or I do a talking raccoon, you are simply mistaken.<ref>{{cite news
column26: title=I didn't really find the Jack Black superhero jokes offensive

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn wrote and produced the [[horror film]] ''[[The Belko Experiment]]'', which was released in 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Brent Sexton Signs Up For 'The Belko Experiment'
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2016, he directed three [[Stan Lee]] cameo scenes in one day, for the film ''[[Doctor Strange (2016 film)
column12: Doctor Strange]]'' and two unrevealed projects.<ref name=\"auto\">While ''Doctor Strange'' director Scott Derrickson believed Gunn directed four cameos, Gunn said on social media, \"To be honest, I think I only did THREE cameos — one was shot by someone else. And my third probably isn't what you think it is….\": {{cite web
column13: title=James Gunn directed the next four Stan Lee Marvel cameos
column18: title=And it was definitely one of the most fun times I've ever had on set ....
column27: title=James Gunn says 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2' a family affair
column38: quote=And while he directed the Stan Lee cameo in director Scott Derrickson's ''Doctor Strange'', he did not direct the Marvel Comics impresario's cameos in the upcoming ''Thor: Ragnarok'' or ''Spider-Man: Homecoming''. But, he reveals, 'I did do one that I can't talk about.'

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn wrote and directed ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2]]'' (2017).<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Marvel announces 'Guardians of the Galaxy' sequel
column7: title=James Gunn comments on directing Stan Lee Marvel cameos
column14: publisher=ew.com}}</ref> Gunn was slated to direct ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2#Sequel
column15: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3]],'' but in July 2018, [[Walt Disney Studios (division)
column16: Disney]] fired Gunn as the director amid controversy over [[off-color humor
column19: title=James Gunn Fired as Director of 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'
column24: language=en}}</ref> Gunn was rehired in March 2019.<ref name=\"GunnRehired\" />

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In October 2018, Gunn was hired to write a completely new script for ''[[The Suicide Squad (film)
date=March 2014}}: The Suicide Squad]]'', with the intention of also serving as director, after its original director [[Gavin O'Connor (filmmaker)
column3: Gavin O'Connor]] left due to scheduling issues.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=James Gunn Boards ''Suicide Squad 2'' To Write And Possibly Direct
column16: title=James Gunn in Talks to Write ''Suicide Squad 2'' for DC, Eyed to Direct (Exclusive)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn wrote a novel in 2000, ''[[The Toy Collector]]'', a story of a hospital orderly who steals drugs from the hospital which he sells to help keep his toy collection habit alive. In 1998, he and Troma's President Lloyd Kaufman co-wrote ''[[All I Need to Know about Filmmaking I Learned from The Toxic Avenger]]'', about his experiences with Kaufman while working at Troma.
He wrote the story for [[Grasshopper Manufacture]]'s video game ''[[Lollipop Chainsaw]]'', working with game designer [[Suda 51]].<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Warner to publish Grasshopper's Lollipop Chainsaw

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In July 2018, in reaction to Gunn's public criticisms of [[Donald Trump]], [[alt-right]] conspiracy theorist [[Mike Cernovich]] drew attention to tweets that Gunn wrote between 2008 and 2012, joking about topics like rape, child abuse, and pedophilia.<ref name=\"DailyDotFiring\">{{cite news
column3: title=Disney appeased the alt-right by firing James Gunn—here's why that's a big problem

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Amid criticism of the tweets, Disney severed ties with Gunn. He was fired as director of the upcoming ''Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'' film;<ref name=\"ReporterFired\">{{cite news
column7: title=James Gunn Fired as Director of 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'
column9: accessdate=July 22, 2018}}</ref> he was also dismissed from a role to help lead Marvel's planned \"Cosmic Universe\".<ref name=\"GunnCosmic\">{{cite web
column11: title=James Gunn Was Supposed To Shepherd Marvel's Cosmic Universe
column14: accessdate= July 30, 2018}}</ref> Gunn responded: \"I have regretted [those jokes] for many years since. [...] Regardless of how much time has passed, I understand and accept the business decisions taken today. Even these many years later, I take full responsibility for the way I conducted myself then. All I can do now [is offer] my sincere and heartfelt regret [...] To everyone inside my industry and beyond, I again offer my deepest apologies.\"<ref name=\"ReporterFired\"/><ref name=\"EWPetition\">{{cite news
column18: title=50,000 sign petition for Disney to rehire James Gunn for Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3

date=March 2014}}: Walt Disney Studios]]' decision received criticism from several entertainers and journalists, including actors [[Dave Bautista]], [[Selma Blair]], [[Patton Oswalt]], [[David Dastmalchian]], [[Michael Ian Black]], [[Mikaela Hoover]], [[Mike Colter]], [[Alex Winter]], [[David Hasselhoff]], directors [[Joe Carnahan]] and [[Fede Álvarez (filmmaker)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In March 2019, Gunn was reinstated by Disney as director of the film after meeting with [[Alan Horn]], chairman of Walt Disney Studios, on multiple occasions. Gunn will start production on the film once his work on ''The Suicide Squad'' has been completed.<ref name=\"GunnRehired\">{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn married actress [[Jenna Fischer]] on October 7, 2000, in an event that Gunn's hometown paper reported was officiated by [[Lloyd Kaufman]],<ref name=\"stltoday.com\"/> but which Gunn later clarified had not been: \"They said I was married by Lloyd Kaufman, which is not true. He was ''at'' my wedding and he gave a speech.\"<ref name=lloydkaufman /> Gunn and Fischer had originally met in the St. Louis area through Gunn's brother Sean, who had acted in plays alongside Fischer in high school.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After seven years of marriage, Gunn and Fischer announced their separation in a joint statement on September 5, 2007,<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=James Gunn Shares Post on Ex Jenna Fischer, Says Not All Failed Relationships Make Enemies
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2010, Fischer persuaded Gunn to cast [[Rainn Wilson]], her co-star on ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)
column18: The Office]]'', in Gunn's film ''[[Super (2010 American film)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Growing up, Gunn was influenced by low-budget films such as ''[[Night of the Living Dead]]'' and ''[[Friday the 13th (1980 film)
date=March 2014}}: Friday the 13th]]''. He read magazines like ''[[Fangoria]]'' and attended genre movie screenings, including the original ''[[Dawn of the Dead (1978 film)
column3: Dawn of the Dead]]'' at the [[Tivoli Theatre (University City, Missouri)
column4: Tivoli Theatre]] in St. Louis. At the age of 12, he began making [[8 mm film
column5: 8 mm]] [[zombie film]]s with his brothers in the woods near their home.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\">{{cite news
column7: title=A Conversation With Director James Gunn

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn and his brothers all attended the [[Jesuit]] [[St. Louis University High School]], where he graduated in 1984.<ref name=alumni>{{cite web
column9: quote=James Gunn '84, filmmaker and screenwriter; Brian Gunn '88, screenwriter; Matt Gunn '90, writer for HBO show Real Time with Bill Maher; Sean Gunn '92, actor.}}</ref><ref name=\"stltoday.com\" /> He went on to earn a [[Bachelor of Arts]] from [[Saint Louis University]].<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=SCA Network Screening and Q&A: Guardians of the Galaxy > About the Guests
column12: publisher=[[University of Southern California School of Cinematic Arts]]
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> While at Saint Louis University, Gunn created political cartoons for the school's student weekly, The University News.<ref name=\"unewsonline.com\">{{cite news
column19: title=Gunn known for his comedy, horror and 'Scooby-Doo'
column20: accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> Gunn said that, at an unspecified time in his college education, \"I went to two years undergraduate film school at [[Loyola Marymount]] in [[Los Angeles]]. But I was pretty screwed up at the time, and had to leave. Years later I went to graduate school at the [[Columbia University School of Fine Arts]] but I studied prose writing, not film writing.\"<ref>{{cite web
column28: df=mdy-all }}</ref> He earned a [[Master of Fine Arts]] from Columbia University in 1995.<ref>{{cite web
column30: title=James Gunn ('95) Co-Writes and Directs 'Guardians of the Galaxy'
column31: publisher=[[Columbia University School of the Arts]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: While living in St. Louis, Gunn founded a band, The Icons, in 1989, serving as lead vocalist. The group released the album ''Mom, We Like It Here on Earth'' in 1994, and its songs \"Sunday\" and \"Walking Naked\" were featured in the film ''[[Tromeo and Juliet]]''. The Icons disbanded in the mid-1990s.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2018-08-06}}</ref> Gunn has continued to work in music, composing songs for ''[[Scooby-Doo (film)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: [[File:James Gunn - Guardians of the Galaxy premiere - July 2014 (cropped).jpg

Gunn began his career in filmmaking with [[Troma Entertainment]] in 1995, for which he wrote the independent film ''Tromeo and Juliet''. Working alongside his mentor [[Lloyd Kaufman]], the co-founder of Troma, Gunn learned how to write screenplays, produce films, scout locations, direct actors, distribute films, and create his own poster art.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After contributing to several other Troma films, Gunn in 2000 wrote, produced and performed in the superhero comedy ''[[The Specials (2000 film)
date=March 2014}}: The Specials]]'', directed by [[Craig Mazin]] and featuring [[Rob Lowe]], [[Thomas Haden Church]], [[Paget Brewster]], [[Judy Greer]] and [[Jamie Kennedy]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn's first major Hollywood screenplay was ''Scooby-Doo'' in 2002. In 2004, he wrote the screenplays for the remake of ''[[Dawn of the Dead (2004 film)
date=March 2014}}: Dawn of the Dead]]'' and the sequel ''Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed''. With these films, Gunn became the first screenwriter to have two films top the box office in consecutive weeks.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Strike Let St. Louisan James Gunn Widen His Horizons
column10: accessdate=June 16, 2014}}</ref> That same year, he executive produced and starred in the mockumentary ''[[LolliLove]]'', directed by and starring his then-wife [[Jenna Fischer]]. His film directorial debut was the 2006 horror-comedy ''[[Slither (2006 film)
column11: Slither]]'', which was included on Rotten Tomatoes' list of the 50 Best Ever Reviewed Horror Movies.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn's next projects included the comedy short film \"Humanzee!\" which was originally intended exclusively for the Xbox Live's ''Horror Meets Comedy'' series of short comedy films by horror directors, it was replaced with \"Sparky and Mikaela\" which debuted on Xbox Live on December 31, 2008. In an April 2009 interview on ''The [[Jace Hall]] Show'', Gunn described \"Sparky and Mikaela\" as being \"about a human [and] racoon crime fighting team and they fight crime in both the forest world, among the furry animals, and in the human world\".<ref>{{cite episode
column6: number=5}}</ref> Gunn also has a short-form web series for [[Spike.com]] titled ''[[James Gunn's PG Porn]]''.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2008, Gunn was a judge on the [[VH1]] reality television show, ''[[Scream Queens (2008 TV series)
date=March 2014}}: Scream Queens]]'' where 10 unknown actresses compete for a role in the film ''[[Saw VI]]'', where he directed contestants during acting challenges.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=A Search For Authenticity on the Set of 'Scream Queens' Season 2

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2009, Gunn announced he was going to write and direct ''Pets'', a comedy about a man who is abducted by aliens who want to turn him into a household pet, with [[Ben Stiller]], [[Stuart Cornfeld]] and Jeremy Kramer producing.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=New Regency adopts 'Pets' pitch – James Gunn to write and direct comedy
column8: accessdate=January 3, 2009}}</ref> However, by March 2009, Gunn announced, \"''Pets'' unfortunately, is done. I'm gone. I left the project for various reasons. I hope it sees the light of day somehow, but it won't be with me attached as director.\"<ref>{{cite web

date=March 2014}}: Super]]'', a [[dark comedy]] and [[superhero]] satire starring [[Rainn Wilson]] and [[Ellen Page]]. Gunn co-wrote and directed the [[Marvel Studios]] adaptation of ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column3: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'', which was released on August 1, 2014.<ref name=\"GunnGotG\">{{cite web
column7: title=James Gunn Confirmed to Direct and Rewrite Guardians of the Galaxy
column14: Sean]], has a role in the film. Gunn has appeared as an actor, mostly in smaller roles or uncredited appearances in his own projects. [[Dan Gilroy]] and [[Jack Black]] separately lamented the proliferation of superhero films,<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Superhero Movies Dissed at Oscars Despite 9 Acting Nominees With Comic Book Roles
column24: url-status=live}}</ref> Gunn responded in a Facebook post, saying in part:{{quote
column25: text=[P]opular fare in any medium has always been snubbed by the self-appointed elite. ... What bothers me slightly is that many people assume because you make big films that you put less love, care, and thought into them then people do who make independent films or who make what are considered more serious Hollywood films. ... If you think people who make superhero movies are dumb, come out and say we're dumb. But if you, as an independent filmmaker or a 'serious' filmmaker, think you put more love into your characters than the Russo Brothers do Captain America, or Joss Whedon does the Hulk, or I do a talking raccoon, you are simply mistaken.<ref>{{cite news
column26: title=I didn't really find the Jack Black superhero jokes offensive

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn wrote and produced the [[horror film]] ''[[The Belko Experiment]]'', which was released in 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Brent Sexton Signs Up For 'The Belko Experiment'
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2016, he directed three [[Stan Lee]] cameo scenes in one day, for the film ''[[Doctor Strange (2016 film)
column12: Doctor Strange]]'' and two unrevealed projects.<ref name=\"auto\">While ''Doctor Strange'' director Scott Derrickson believed Gunn directed four cameos, Gunn said on social media, \"To be honest, I think I only did THREE cameos — one was shot by someone else. And my third probably isn't what you think it is….\": {{cite web
column13: title=James Gunn directed the next four Stan Lee Marvel cameos
column18: title=And it was definitely one of the most fun times I've ever had on set ....
column27: title=James Gunn says 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2' a family affair
column38: quote=And while he directed the Stan Lee cameo in director Scott Derrickson's ''Doctor Strange'', he did not direct the Marvel Comics impresario's cameos in the upcoming ''Thor: Ragnarok'' or ''Spider-Man: Homecoming''. But, he reveals, 'I did do one that I can't talk about.'

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn wrote and directed ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2]]'' (2017).<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Marvel announces 'Guardians of the Galaxy' sequel
column7: title=James Gunn comments on directing Stan Lee Marvel cameos
column14: publisher=ew.com}}</ref> Gunn was slated to direct ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2#Sequel
column15: Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3]],'' but in July 2018, [[Walt Disney Studios (division)
column16: Disney]] fired Gunn as the director amid controversy over [[off-color humor
column19: title=James Gunn Fired as Director of 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'
column24: language=en}}</ref> Gunn was rehired in March 2019.<ref name=\"GunnRehired\" />

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In October 2018, Gunn was hired to write a completely new script for ''[[The Suicide Squad (film)
date=March 2014}}: The Suicide Squad]]'', with the intention of also serving as director, after its original director [[Gavin O'Connor (filmmaker)
column3: Gavin O'Connor]] left due to scheduling issues.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=James Gunn Boards ''Suicide Squad 2'' To Write And Possibly Direct
column16: title=James Gunn in Talks to Write ''Suicide Squad 2'' for DC, Eyed to Direct (Exclusive)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn wrote a novel in 2000, ''[[The Toy Collector]]'', a story of a hospital orderly who steals drugs from the hospital which he sells to help keep his toy collection habit alive. In 1998, he and Troma's President Lloyd Kaufman co-wrote ''[[All I Need to Know about Filmmaking I Learned from The Toxic Avenger]]'', about his experiences with Kaufman while working at Troma.
He wrote the story for [[Grasshopper Manufacture]]'s video game ''[[Lollipop Chainsaw]]'', working with game designer [[Suda 51]].<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Warner to publish Grasshopper's Lollipop Chainsaw

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In July 2018, in reaction to Gunn's public criticisms of [[Donald Trump]], [[alt-right]] conspiracy theorist [[Mike Cernovich]] drew attention to tweets that Gunn wrote between 2008 and 2012, joking about topics like rape, child abuse, and pedophilia.<ref name=\"DailyDotFiring\">{{cite news
column3: title=Disney appeased the alt-right by firing James Gunn—here's why that's a big problem

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Amid criticism of the tweets, Disney severed ties with Gunn. He was fired as director of the upcoming ''Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'' film;<ref name=\"ReporterFired\">{{cite news
column7: title=James Gunn Fired as Director of 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'
column9: accessdate=July 22, 2018}}</ref> he was also dismissed from a role to help lead Marvel's planned \"Cosmic Universe\".<ref name=\"GunnCosmic\">{{cite web
column11: title=James Gunn Was Supposed To Shepherd Marvel's Cosmic Universe
column14: accessdate= July 30, 2018}}</ref> Gunn responded: \"I have regretted [those jokes] for many years since. [...] Regardless of how much time has passed, I understand and accept the business decisions taken today. Even these many years later, I take full responsibility for the way I conducted myself then. All I can do now [is offer] my sincere and heartfelt regret [...] To everyone inside my industry and beyond, I again offer my deepest apologies.\"<ref name=\"ReporterFired\"/><ref name=\"EWPetition\">{{cite news
column18: title=50,000 sign petition for Disney to rehire James Gunn for Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn married actress [[Jenna Fischer]] on October 7, 2000, in an event that Gunn's hometown paper reported was officiated by [[Lloyd Kaufman]],<ref name=\"stltoday.com\"/> but which Gunn later clarified had not been: \"They said I was married by Lloyd Kaufman, which is not true. He was ''at'' my wedding and he gave a speech.\"<ref name=lloydkaufman /> Gunn and Fischer had originally met in the St. Louis area through Gunn's brother Sean, who had acted in plays alongside Fischer in high school.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After seven years of marriage, Gunn and Fischer announced their separation in a joint statement on September 5, 2007,<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=James Gunn Shares Post on Ex Jenna Fischer, Says Not All Failed Relationships Make Enemies
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2010, Fischer persuaded Gunn to cast [[Rainn Wilson]], her co-star on ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)
column18: The Office]]'', in Gunn's film ''[[Super (2010 American film)

column14: My personal take is that there is a role for spirituality in some people's lives and I think that a belief in God can be a good thing for a great amount of people [...] I do not like any sort of faith or religion that is based on exclusivity, meaning any sort of religion that says you're damned to hell or you're not going to be saved because you don't believe the same thing I do. I believe faith and spiritual belief is a very, very personal thing and if I started applying what I believe to everybody else it would be unfair to everybody's individuality and I really hate that.<ref>{{cite web

column6: title=A Star Is Born: James Gunn turns 51 today
column11: While many sources give a birth year of 1970,<ref name=tribute>{{cite web
column17: accessdate=November 7, 2015}}</ref> Gunn graduated from [[St. Louis University High School]] in 1984,<ref name=alumni /> making 1970 questionable.<ref name=\"stltoday.com\" />
column19: name=born}}  is an American filmmaker and musician. He began his career as a screenwriter in the mid-1990s. He then began working as a director, starting with the horror-comedy film ''[[Slither (2006 film)
column20: Slither]]'' (2006), and eventually moving to the superhero genre through ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column21: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'' and ''[[The Suicide Squad (film)
column22: The Suicide Squad]]''. He also wrote and directed the web series ''[[James Gunn's PG Porn]]'' (2008–09), the [[superhero film]] ''[[Super (2010 American film)
column23: Super]]'' (2010), and the sequel to the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] film ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column24: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'' (2014) - ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2]]'' (2017).

column6: number=5}}</ref> Gunn also has a short-form web series for [[Spike.com]] titled ''[[James Gunn's PG Porn]]''.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2008, Gunn was a judge on the [[VH1]] reality television show, ''[[Scream Queens (2008 TV series)
date=March 2014}}: Scream Queens]]'' where 10 unknown actresses compete for a role in the film ''[[Saw VI]]'', where he directed contestants during acting challenges.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=A Search For Authenticity on the Set of 'Scream Queens' Season 2

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2009, Gunn announced he was going to write and direct ''Pets'', a comedy about a man who is abducted by aliens who want to turn him into a household pet, with [[Ben Stiller]], [[Stuart Cornfeld]] and Jeremy Kramer producing.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=New Regency adopts 'Pets' pitch – James Gunn to write and direct comedy
column8: accessdate=January 3, 2009}}</ref> However, by March 2009, Gunn announced, \"''Pets'' unfortunately, is done. I'm gone. I left the project for various reasons. I hope it sees the light of day somehow, but it won't be with me attached as director.\"<ref>{{cite web

date=March 2014}}: Super]]'', a [[dark comedy]] and [[superhero]] satire starring [[Rainn Wilson]] and [[Ellen Page]]. Gunn co-wrote and directed the [[Marvel Studios]] adaptation of ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column3: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'', which was released on August 1, 2014.<ref name=\"GunnGotG\">{{cite web
column7: title=James Gunn Confirmed to Direct and Rewrite Guardians of the Galaxy
column14: Sean]], has a role in the film. Gunn has appeared as an actor, mostly in smaller roles or uncredited appearances in his own projects. [[Dan Gilroy]] and [[Jack Black]] separately lamented the proliferation of superhero films,<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Superhero Movies Dissed at Oscars Despite 9 Acting Nominees With Comic Book Roles
column24: url-status=live}}</ref> Gunn responded in a Facebook post, saying in part:{{quote
column25: text=[P]opular fare in any medium has always been snubbed by the self-appointed elite. ... What bothers me slightly is that many people assume because you make big films that you put less love, care, and thought into them then people do who make independent films or who make what are considered more serious Hollywood films. ... If you think people who make superhero movies are dumb, come out and say we're dumb. But if you, as an independent filmmaker or a 'serious' filmmaker, think you put more love into your characters than the Russo Brothers do Captain America, or Joss Whedon does the Hulk, or I do a talking raccoon, you are simply mistaken.<ref>{{cite news
column26: title=I didn't really find the Jack Black superhero jokes offensive

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn wrote and produced the [[horror film]] ''[[The Belko Experiment]]'', which was released in 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Brent Sexton Signs Up For 'The Belko Experiment'
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2016, he directed three [[Stan Lee]] cameo scenes in one day, for the film ''[[Doctor Strange (2016 film)
column12: Doctor Strange]]'' and two unrevealed projects.<ref name=\"auto\">While ''Doctor Strange'' director Scott Derrickson believed Gunn directed four cameos, Gunn said on social media, \"To be honest, I think I only did THREE cameos — one was shot by someone else. And my third probably isn't what you think it is….\": {{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn wrote a novel in 2000, ''[[The Toy Collector]]'', a story of a hospital orderly who steals drugs from the hospital which he sells to help keep his toy collection habit alive. In 1998, he and Troma's President Lloyd Kaufman co-wrote ''[[All I Need to Know about Filmmaking I Learned from The Toxic Avenger]]'', about his experiences with Kaufman while working at Troma.
He wrote the story for [[Grasshopper Manufacture]]'s video game ''[[Lollipop Chainsaw]]'', working with game designer [[Suda 51]].<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Warner to publish Grasshopper's Lollipop Chainsaw

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In July 2018, in reaction to Gunn's public criticisms of [[Donald Trump]], [[alt-right]] conspiracy theorist [[Mike Cernovich]] drew attention to tweets that Gunn wrote between 2008 and 2012, joking about topics like rape, child abuse, and pedophilia.<ref name=\"DailyDotFiring\">{{cite news
column3: title=Disney appeased the alt-right by firing James Gunn—here's why that's a big problem

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Amid criticism of the tweets, Disney severed ties with Gunn. He was fired as director of the upcoming ''Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'' film;<ref name=\"ReporterFired\">{{cite news
column7: title=James Gunn Fired as Director of 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'
column9: accessdate=July 22, 2018}}</ref> he was also dismissed from a role to help lead Marvel's planned \"Cosmic Universe\".<ref name=\"GunnCosmic\">{{cite web
column11: title=James Gunn Was Supposed To Shepherd Marvel's Cosmic Universe
column14: accessdate= July 30, 2018}}</ref> Gunn responded: \"I have regretted [those jokes] for many years since. [...] Regardless of how much time has passed, I understand and accept the business decisions taken today. Even these many years later, I take full responsibility for the way I conducted myself then. All I can do now [is offer] my sincere and heartfelt regret [...] To everyone inside my industry and beyond, I again offer my deepest apologies.\"<ref name=\"ReporterFired\"/><ref name=\"EWPetition\">{{cite news
column18: title=50,000 sign petition for Disney to rehire James Gunn for Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn married actress [[Jenna Fischer]] on October 7, 2000, in an event that Gunn's hometown paper reported was officiated by [[Lloyd Kaufman]],<ref name=\"stltoday.com\"/> but which Gunn later clarified had not been: \"They said I was married by Lloyd Kaufman, which is not true. He was ''at'' my wedding and he gave a speech.\"<ref name=lloydkaufman /> Gunn and Fischer had originally met in the St. Louis area through Gunn's brother Sean, who had acted in plays alongside Fischer in high school.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After seven years of marriage, Gunn and Fischer announced their separation in a joint statement on September 5, 2007,<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=James Gunn Shares Post on Ex Jenna Fischer, Says Not All Failed Relationships Make Enemies
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2010, Fischer persuaded Gunn to cast [[Rainn Wilson]], her co-star on ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)
column18: The Office]]'', in Gunn's film ''[[Super (2010 American film)

column14: My personal take is that there is a role for spirituality in some people's lives and I think that a belief in God can be a good thing for a great amount of people [...] I do not like any sort of faith or religion that is based on exclusivity, meaning any sort of religion that says you're damned to hell or you're not going to be saved because you don't believe the same thing I do. I believe faith and spiritual belief is a very, very personal thing and if I started applying what I believe to everybody else it would be unfair to everybody's individuality and I really hate that.<ref>{{cite web

education = [[Loyola Marymount University]]
[[Saint Louis University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts

column6: title=A Star Is Born: James Gunn turns 51 today
column11: While many sources give a birth year of 1970,<ref name=tribute>{{cite web
column17: accessdate=November 7, 2015}}</ref> Gunn graduated from [[St. Louis University High School]] in 1984,<ref name=alumni /> making 1970 questionable.<ref name=\"stltoday.com\" />
column19: name=born}}  is an American filmmaker and musician. He began his career as a screenwriter in the mid-1990s. He then began working as a director, starting with the horror-comedy film ''[[Slither (2006 film)
column20: Slither]]'' (2006), and eventually moving to the superhero genre through ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column21: Guardians of the Galaxy]] (2014)'' and ''[[The Suicide Squad (film)
column22: The Suicide Squad]]'' (2021). He also wrote and directed the web series ''[[James Gunn's PG Porn]]'' (2008–09), the [[superhero film]] ''[[Super (2010 American film)
column23: Super]]'' (2010), and the sequel to the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] film ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column24: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'' (2014) - ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2]]'' (2017).

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn was born in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]<ref name=tribute /> to parents Leota<ref name=\"GunnNoClose\">{{cite web
column3: title=James Gunn says 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2' a family affair
column13: url-status=bot: unknown}}Additional  on May 5, 2017.</ref> and James F. Gunn, an attorney.<ref name=\"stltoday.com\">{{cite web
column15: title=St. Louis director James Gunn goes galactic
column24: quote=Gunn graduated from SLUH in 1984. (Several sources, including IMDb.com, say he was born in 1970, but you do the math.)}}</ref> He was raised between St. Louis and [[Manchester, Missouri]].<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=5 Weird Things about STL Native and Guardians of the Galaxy Director James Gunn
column41: url=https://www.facebook.com/jgunn/info}}</ref> He has five siblings: actor [[Sean Gunn
column42: Sean]], actor and political writer [[Matt Gunn
column51: accessdate=November 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://qualiacapital.com/patrick-gunn Patrick Gunn profile], qualiacapital.com; accessed December 4, 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web
column59: Irish]]<ref>https://twitter.com/JamesGunn/status/812059184787165185</ref> and [[Jewish]]<ref>https://twitter.com/JamesGunn/status/736640431031779329</ref> heritage. Gunn has stated that his family's surname was originally the [[Irish people
column60: Irish]] name MacGilgunn and that it means \"sons to the servants of the god of the dead\"; it means \"son of the brown one\".<ref>Interview with James Gunn (April 4, 2012). ''The 404 Podcast'' episode 1047</ref><ref>{{cite web
column61: title=Mac Giolla Dhuinn – Irish Names and Surnames

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Growing up, Gunn was influenced by low-budget films such as ''[[Night of the Living Dead]]'' and ''[[Friday the 13th (1980 film)
date=March 2014}}: Friday the 13th]]''. He read magazines like ''[[Fangoria]]'' and attended genre movie screenings, including the original ''[[Dawn of the Dead (1978 film)
column3: Dawn of the Dead]]'' at the [[Tivoli Theatre (University City, Missouri)
column4: Tivoli Theatre]] in St. Louis. At the age of 12, he began making [[8 mm film
column5: 8 mm]] [[zombie film]]s with his brothers in the woods near their home.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\">{{cite news
column7: title=A Conversation With Director James Gunn

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn and his brothers all attended the [[Jesuit]] [[St. Louis University High School]], where he graduated in 1984.<ref name=alumni>{{cite web
column9: quote=James Gunn '84, filmmaker and screenwriter; Brian Gunn '88, screenwriter; Matt Gunn '90, writer for HBO show Real Time with Bill Maher; Sean Gunn '92, actor.}}</ref><ref name=\"stltoday.com\" /> He went on to earn a [[Bachelor of Arts]] from [[Saint Louis University]].<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=SCA Network Screening and Q&A: Guardians of the Galaxy > About the Guests
column12: publisher=[[University of Southern California School of Cinematic Arts]]
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> While at Saint Louis University, Gunn created political cartoons for the school's student weekly, The University News.<ref name=\"unewsonline.com\">{{cite news
column19: title=Gunn known for his comedy, horror and 'Scooby-Doo'
column20: accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> Gunn said that, at an unspecified time in his college education, \"I went to two years undergraduate film school at [[Loyola Marymount]] in [[Los Angeles]]. But I was pretty screwed up at the time, and had to leave. Years later I went to graduate school at the [[Columbia University School of Fine Arts]] but I studied prose writing, not film writing.\"<ref>{{cite web
column28: df=mdy-all }}</ref> He earned a [[Master of Fine Arts]] from Columbia University in 1995.<ref>{{cite web
column30: title=James Gunn ('95) Co-Writes and Directs 'Guardians of the Galaxy'
column31: publisher=[[Columbia University School of the Arts]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: While living in St. Louis, Gunn founded a band, The Icons, in 1989, serving as lead vocalist. The group released the album ''Mom, We Like It Here on Earth'' in 1994, and its songs \"Sunday\" and \"Walking Naked\" were featured in the film ''[[Tromeo and Juliet]]''. The Icons disbanded in the mid-1990s.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2018-08-06}}</ref> Gunn has continued to work in music, composing songs for ''[[Scooby-Doo (film)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: [[File:James Gunn - Guardians of the Galaxy premiere - July 2014 (cropped).jpg

Gunn began his career in filmmaking with [[Troma Entertainment]] in 1995, for which he wrote the independent film ''Tromeo and Juliet''. Working alongside his mentor [[Lloyd Kaufman]], the co-founder of Troma, Gunn learned how to write screenplays, produce films, scout locations, direct actors, distribute films, and create his own poster art.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After contributing to several other Troma films, Gunn in 2000 wrote, produced and performed in the superhero comedy ''[[The Specials (2000 film)
date=March 2014}}: The Specials]]'', directed by [[Craig Mazin]] and featuring [[Rob Lowe]], [[Thomas Haden Church]], [[Paget Brewster]], [[Judy Greer]] and [[Jamie Kennedy]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn's first major Hollywood screenplay was ''Scooby-Doo'' in 2002. In 2004, he wrote the screenplays for the remake of ''[[Dawn of the Dead (2004 film)
date=March 2014}}: Dawn of the Dead]]'' and the sequel ''Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed''. With these films, Gunn became the first screenwriter to have two films top the box office in consecutive weeks.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Strike Let St. Louisan James Gunn Widen His Horizons
column10: accessdate=June 16, 2014}}</ref> That same year, he executive produced and starred in the mockumentary ''[[LolliLove]]'', directed by and starring his then-wife [[Jenna Fischer]]. His film directorial debut was the 2006 horror-comedy ''[[Slither (2006 film)
column11: Slither]]'', which was included on Rotten Tomatoes' list of the 50 Best Ever Reviewed Horror Movies.<ref>{{cite web

In 1998, he and Troma's President Lloyd Kaufman co-wrote ''[[All I Need to Know about Filmmaking I Learned from The Toxic Avenger]]'', about his experiences with Kaufman while working at Troma.
He wrote the story for [[Grasshopper Manufacture]]'s video game ''[[Lollipop Chainsaw]]'', working with game designer [[Suda 51]].<ref>{{cite news

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In July 2018, in reaction to Gunn's public criticisms of [[Donald Trump]], [[alt-right]] conspiracy theorist [[Mike Cernovich]] drew attention to tweets that Gunn wrote between 2008 and 2012, joking about topics like rape, child abuse, and pedophilia.<ref name=\"DailyDotFiring\">{{cite news

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Amid criticism of the tweets, Disney severed ties with Gunn. He was fired as director of the upcoming ''Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'' film;<ref name=\"ReporterFired\">{{cite news
column7: title=James Gunn Fired as Director of 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 3'
column9: accessdate=July 22, 2018}}</ref> he was also dismissed from a role to help lead Marvel's planned \"Cosmic Universe\".<ref name=\"GunnCosmic\">{{cite web
column11: title=James Gunn Was Supposed To Shepherd Marvel's Cosmic Universe
column14: accessdate= July 30, 2018}}</ref> Gunn responded: \"I have regretted [those jokes] for many years since. [...] Regardless of how much time has passed, I understand and accept the business decisions taken today. Even these many years later, I take full responsibility for the way I conducted myself then. All I can do now [is offer] my sincere and heartfelt regret [...] To everyone inside my industry and beyond, I again offer my deepest apologies.\"<ref name=\"ReporterFired\"/><ref name=\"EWPetition\">{{cite news

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn married actress [[Jenna Fischer]] on October 7, 2000, in an event that Gunn's hometown paper reported was officiated by [[Lloyd Kaufman]],<ref name=\"stltoday.com\"/> but which Gunn later clarified had not been: \"They said I was married by Lloyd Kaufman, which is not true. He was ''at'' my wedding and he gave a speech.\"<ref name=lloydkaufman /> Gunn and Fischer had originally met in the St. Louis area through Gunn's brother Sean, who had acted in plays alongside Fischer in high school.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After seven years of marriage, Gunn and Fischer announced their separation in a joint statement on September 5, 2007,<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=James Gunn Shares Post on Ex Jenna Fischer, Says Not All Failed Relationships Make Enemies
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2010, Fischer persuaded Gunn to cast [[Rainn Wilson]], her co-star on ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)
column18: The Office]]'', in Gunn's film ''[[Super (2010 American film)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn has been in a relationship with actress Jennifer Holland since 2015.<ref>{{cite news

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn was raised in a Roman Catholic family and has mentioned how prayer continues to play an important role in his life,<ref>{{cite web

column4: publisher=}}</ref> but has also said that he is \"in some ways, anti-religion\".<ref>{{Citation
column6: title=The Indoor Kids #58 — Everything with James Gunn (NSFW)
column13: archivedate=March 4, 2016}}</ref> Gunn explained his views in detail in 2016: {{quote
column14: My personal take is that there is a role for spirituality in some people's lives and I think that a belief in God can be a good thing for a great amount of people [...] I do not like any sort of faith or religion that is based on exclusivity, meaning any sort of religion that says you're damned to hell or you're not going to be saved because you don't believe the same thing I do. I believe faith and spiritual belief is a very, very personal thing and if I started applying what I believe to everybody else it would be unfair to everybody's individuality and I really hate that.<ref>{{cite web

[[Saint Louis University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts

column6: title=A Star Is Born: James Gunn turns 51 today
column11: While many sources give a birth year of 1970,<ref name=tribute>{{cite web
column17: accessdate=November 7, 2015}}</ref> Gunn graduated from [[St. Louis University High School]] in 1984,<ref name=alumni /> making 1970 questionable.<ref name=\"stltoday.com\" />
column19: name=born}}  is an American filmmaker and musician. He began his career as a screenwriter in the mid-1990s. He then began working as a director, starting with the horror-comedy film ''[[Slither (2006 film)
column20: Slither]]'' (2006), and eventually moving to the superhero genre through ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column21: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'' and ''[[The Suicide Squad (film)
column22: The Suicide Squad]]''. He also wrote and directed the web series ''[[James Gunn's PG Porn]]'' (2008–09), the [[superhero film]] ''[[Super (2010 American film)
column23: Super]]'' (2010), and the sequel to the [[Marvel Cinematic Universe]] film ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column24: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'' (2014) - ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2]]'' (2017).

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn was born in [[St. Louis, Missouri]]<ref name=tribute /> to parents Leota<ref name=\"GunnNoClose\">{{cite web
column3: title=James Gunn says 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2' a family affair
column13: url-status=bot: unknown}}Additional  on May 5, 2017.</ref> and James F. Gunn, an attorney.<ref name=\"stltoday.com\">{{cite web
column15: title=St. Louis director James Gunn goes galactic
column24: quote=Gunn graduated from SLUH in 1984. (Several sources, including IMDb.com, say he was born in 1970, but you do the math.)}}</ref> He was raised between St. Louis and [[Manchester, Missouri]].<ref>{{cite web
column26: title=5 Weird Things about STL Native and Guardians of the Galaxy Director James Gunn
column41: url=https://www.facebook.com/jgunn/info}}</ref> He has five siblings: actor [[Sean Gunn
column42: Sean]], actor and political writer [[Matt Gunn
column51: accessdate=November 7, 2015}}</ref><ref>[http://qualiacapital.com/patrick-gunn Patrick Gunn profile], qualiacapital.com; accessed December 4, 2014.</ref><ref>{{cite web
column59: Irish]]<ref>https://twitter.com/JamesGunn/status/812059184787165185</ref> and [[Jewish]]<ref>https://twitter.com/JamesGunn/status/736640431031779329</ref> heritage. Gunn has stated that his family's surname was originally the [[Irish people
column60: Irish]] name MacGilgunn and that it means \"sons to the servants of the god of the dead\"; it means \"son of the brown one\".<ref>Interview with James Gunn (April 4, 2012). ''The 404 Podcast'' episode 1047</ref><ref>{{cite web
column61: title=Mac Giolla Dhuinn – Irish Names and Surnames

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Growing up, Gunn was influenced by low-budget films such as ''[[Night of the Living Dead]]'' and ''[[Friday the 13th (1980 film)
date=March 2014}}: Friday the 13th]]''. He read magazines like ''[[Fangoria]]'' and attended genre movie screenings, including the original ''[[Dawn of the Dead (1978 film)
column3: Dawn of the Dead]]'' at the [[Tivoli Theatre (University City, Missouri)
column4: Tivoli Theatre]] in St. Louis. At the age of 12, he began making [[8 mm film
column5: 8 mm]] [[zombie film]]s with his brothers in the woods near their home.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\">{{cite news
column7: title=A Conversation With Director James Gunn

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn and his brothers all attended the [[Jesuit]] [[St. Louis University High School]], where he graduated in 1984.<ref name=alumni>{{cite web
column9: quote=James Gunn '84, filmmaker and screenwriter; Brian Gunn '88, screenwriter; Matt Gunn '90, writer for HBO show Real Time with Bill Maher; Sean Gunn '92, actor.}}</ref><ref name=\"stltoday.com\" /> He went on to earn a [[Bachelor of Arts]] from [[Saint Louis University]].<ref>{{cite web
column11: title=SCA Network Screening and Q&A: Guardians of the Galaxy > About the Guests
column12: publisher=[[University of Southern California School of Cinematic Arts]]
column17: url-status=live}}</ref> While at Saint Louis University, Gunn created political cartoons for the school's student weekly, The University News.<ref name=\"unewsonline.com\">{{cite news
column19: title=Gunn known for his comedy, horror and 'Scooby-Doo'
column20: accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> Gunn said that, at an unspecified time in his college education, \"I went to two years undergraduate film school at [[Loyola Marymount]] in [[Los Angeles]]. But I was pretty screwed up at the time, and had to leave. Years later I went to graduate school at the [[Columbia University School of Fine Arts]] but I studied prose writing, not film writing.\"<ref>{{cite web
column28: df=mdy-all }}</ref> He earned a [[Master of Fine Arts]] from Columbia University in 1995.<ref>{{cite web
column30: title=James Gunn ('95) Co-Writes and Directs 'Guardians of the Galaxy'
column31: publisher=[[Columbia University School of the Arts]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: While living in St. Louis, Gunn founded a band, The Icons, in 1989, serving as lead vocalist. The group released the album ''Mom, We Like It Here on Earth'' in 1994, and its songs \"Sunday\" and \"Walking Naked\" were featured in the film ''[[Tromeo and Juliet]]''. The Icons disbanded in the mid-1990s.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=2018-08-06}}</ref> Gunn has continued to work in music, composing songs for ''[[Scooby-Doo (film)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: [[File:James Gunn - Guardians of the Galaxy premiere - July 2014 (cropped).jpg

Gunn began his career in filmmaking with [[Troma Entertainment]] in 1995, for which he wrote the independent film ''Tromeo and Juliet''. Working alongside his mentor [[Lloyd Kaufman]], the co-founder of Troma, Gunn learned how to write screenplays, produce films, scout locations, direct actors, distribute films, and create his own poster art.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After contributing to several other Troma films, Gunn in 2000 wrote, produced and performed in the superhero comedy ''[[The Specials (2000 film)
date=March 2014}}: The Specials]]'', directed by [[Craig Mazin]] and featuring [[Rob Lowe]], [[Thomas Haden Church]], [[Paget Brewster]], [[Judy Greer]] and [[Jamie Kennedy]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn's first major Hollywood screenplay was ''Scooby-Doo'' in 2002. In 2004, he wrote the screenplays for the remake of ''[[Dawn of the Dead (2004 film)
date=March 2014}}: Dawn of the Dead]]'' and the sequel ''Scooby-Doo 2: Monsters Unleashed''. With these films, Gunn became the first screenwriter to have two films top the box office in consecutive weeks.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Strike Let St. Louisan James Gunn Widen His Horizons
column10: accessdate=June 16, 2014}}</ref> That same year, he executive produced and starred in the mockumentary ''[[LolliLove]]'', directed by and starring his then-wife [[Jenna Fischer]]. His film directorial debut was the 2006 horror-comedy ''[[Slither (2006 film)
column11: Slither]]'', which was included on Rotten Tomatoes' list of the 50 Best Ever Reviewed Horror Movies.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn's next projects included the comedy short film \"Humanzee!\" which was originally intended exclusively for the Xbox Live's ''Horror Meets Comedy'' series of short comedy films by horror directors, it was replaced with \"Sparky and Mikaela\" which debuted on Xbox Live on December 31, 2008. In an April 2009 interview on ''The [[Jace Hall]] Show'', Gunn described \"Sparky and Mikaela\" as being \"about a human [and] racoon crime fighting team and they fight crime in both the forest world, among the furry animals, and in the human world\".<ref>{{cite episode
column6: number=5}}</ref> Gunn also has a short-form web series for [[Spike.com]] titled ''[[James Gunn's PG Porn]]''.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2008, Gunn was a judge on the [[VH1]] reality television show, ''[[Scream Queens (2008 TV series)
date=March 2014}}: Scream Queens]]'' where 10 unknown actresses compete for a role in the film ''[[Saw VI]]'', where he directed contestants during acting challenges.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=A Search For Authenticity on the Set of 'Scream Queens' Season 2

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2009, Gunn announced he was going to write and direct ''Pets'', a comedy about a man who is abducted by aliens who want to turn him into a household pet, with [[Ben Stiller]], [[Stuart Cornfeld]] and Jeremy Kramer producing.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=New Regency adopts 'Pets' pitch – James Gunn to write and direct comedy
column8: accessdate=January 3, 2009}}</ref> However, by March 2009, Gunn announced, \"''Pets'' unfortunately, is done. I'm gone. I left the project for various reasons. I hope it sees the light of day somehow, but it won't be with me attached as director.\"<ref>{{cite web

date=March 2014}}: Super]]'', a [[dark comedy]] and [[superhero]] satire starring [[Rainn Wilson]] and [[Ellen Page]]. Gunn co-wrote and directed the [[Marvel Studios]] adaptation of ''[[Guardians of the Galaxy (film)
column3: Guardians of the Galaxy]]'', which was released on August 1, 2014.<ref name=\"GunnGotG\">{{cite web
column7: title=James Gunn Confirmed to Direct and Rewrite Guardians of the Galaxy
column14: Sean]], has a role in the film. Gunn has appeared as an actor, mostly in smaller roles or uncredited appearances in his own projects. [[Dan Gilroy]] and [[Jack Black]] separately lamented the proliferation of superhero films,<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Superhero Movies Dissed at Oscars Despite 9 Acting Nominees With Comic Book Roles
column24: url-status=live}}</ref> Gunn responded in a Facebook post, saying in part:{{quote
column25: text=[P]opular fare in any medium has always been snubbed by the self-appointed elite. ... What bothers me slightly is that many people assume because you make big films that you put less love, care, and thought into them then people do who make independent films or who make what are considered more serious Hollywood films. ... If you think people who make superhero movies are dumb, come out and say we're dumb. But if you, as an independent filmmaker or a 'serious' filmmaker, think you put more love into your characters than the Russo Brothers do Captain America, or Joss Whedon does the Hulk, or I do a talking raccoon, you are simply mistaken.<ref>{{cite news
column26: title=I didn't really find the Jack Black superhero jokes offensive

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn wrote and produced the [[horror film]] ''[[The Belko Experiment]]'', which was released in 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Brent Sexton Signs Up For 'The Belko Experiment'
column11: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2016, he directed three [[Stan Lee]] cameo scenes in one day, for the film ''[[Doctor Strange (2016 film)
column12: Doctor Strange]]'' and two unrevealed projects.<ref name=\"auto\">While ''Doctor Strange'' director Scott Derrickson believed Gunn directed four cameos, Gunn said on social media, \"To be honest, I think I only did THREE cameos — one was shot by someone else. And my third probably isn't what you think it is….\": {{cite web
column13: title=James Gunn directed the next four Stan Lee Marvel cameos
column18: title=And it was definitely one of the most fun times I've ever had on set ....
column27: title=James Gunn says 'Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2' a family affair
column38: quote=And while he directed the Stan Lee cameo in director Scott Derrickson's ''Doctor Strange'', he did not direct the Marvel Comics impresario's cameos in the upcoming ''Thor: Ragnarok'' or ''Spider-Man: Homecoming''. But, he reveals, 'I did do one that I can't talk about.'

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Because of this, [[Sony Pictures]] decided to not promote the horror film ''[[Brightburn]]'', which Gunn produced, at the 2018 [[San Diego Comic-Con]].<ref>{{cite web
column7: title=Sony avoids mentioning James Gunn at Comic-Con presentation

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In March 2019, Gunn was reinstated by Disney as director of the film after meeting with [[Alan Horn]], chairman of Walt Disney Studios, on multiple occasions. Gunn will start production on the film once his work on ''The Suicide Squad'' has been completed.<ref name=\"GunnRehired\">{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Gunn married actress [[Jenna Fischer]] on October 7, 2000, in an event that Gunn's hometown paper reported was officiated by [[Lloyd Kaufman]],<ref name=\"stltoday.com\"/> but which Gunn later clarified had not been: \"They said I was married by Lloyd Kaufman, which is not true. He was ''at'' my wedding and he gave a speech.\"<ref name=lloydkaufman /> Gunn and Fischer had originally met in the St. Louis area through Gunn's brother Sean, who had acted in plays alongside Fischer in high school.<ref name=\"stlmag.com\"/> After seven years of marriage, Gunn and Fischer announced their separation in a joint statement on September 5, 2007,<ref>{{cite news

column17: url-status=live}}</ref> In 2010, Fischer persuaded Gunn to cast [[Rainn Wilson]], her co-star on ''[[The Office (U.S. TV series)
column18: The Office]]'', in Gunn's film ''[[Super (2010 American film)

I believe faith and spiritual belief is a very, very personal thing and if I started applying what I believe to everybody else it would be unfair to everybody's individuality and I really hate that.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: '''Tarvaris Jackson''' (April 21, 1983 – April 12, 2020) was an [[American football]] [[quarterback]]. Born and raised in [[Montgomery, Alabama]], Jackson played [[college football]] at [[Arkansas Razorbacks football
column3: Alabama State]], and in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) for the [[Minnesota Vikings]], [[Seattle Seahawks]], and [[Buffalo Bills]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The Vikings selected Jackson in the second round of the [[2006 NFL Draft]], and Jackson played for the Vikings from 2006 to 2010. A reserve quarterback for much of his time with the Vikings, Jackson was starting quarterback for the [[2007 Minnesota Vikings season
date=March 2014}}: 2007 season]] and part of the [[2008 Minnesota Vikings season
column3: 2008 season]], after which Jackson started the Vikings' [[2008-09 NFL playoffs#NFC: Philadelphia Eagles 26, Minnesota Vikings 14
column4: Wild Card playoff game]]. In 2011, Jackson signed with the Seahawks and was starting quarterback for [[2011 Seattle Seahawks season
column5: the 2011 season]]. Jackson was then traded to the Bills before the [[2012 NFL season]] but never played a game.  Jackson returned to the Seahawks in 2013. He was the backup quarterback for [[Russell Wilson]] during [[Super Bowl XLVIII]] over the [[Denver Broncos]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson was born and raised in Montgomery, Alabama, and graduated from [[Sidney Lanier High School]] of Montgomery in 2001.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Montgomery native Tarvaris Jackson talks Lanier, ASU football
column6: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Jackson then enrolled at the [[University of Arkansas]] and played three games for the [[Arkansas Razorbacks football]] team as a freshman but suffered a season-ending injury. Consequently, Jackson received a medical [[Redshirt (college sports)
column7: redshirt]] for the season.<ref name=\"Seahawks bio\">{{cite web
column14: accessdate=November 13, 2014 }}</ref> Jackson finished 2001 with 3 of 9 passes completed for 53 yards and 1 interception and rushed 14 yards on 7 carries.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> In 2002, Jackson played 8 games. He completed 14 of 39 passes for 143 yards, 1 touchdown, and 2 interceptions and rushed -16 yards in 14 carries.<ref>{{Cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2003, after trailing on the depth chart to future first round draft pick [[Matt Jones (wide receiver)
date=March 2014}}: Matt Jones]], Jackson transferred to [[Alabama State University]] and led the [[Alabama State Hornets football
column3: Hornets]] to an 8-5 record, [[Southwestern Athletic Conference]] (SWAC) Eastern Division title, and berth in the [[SWAC Championship Game]].<ref name=\"Seahawks bio\"/> He completed 160 of 316 passes for 2,342 yards, 18 touchdowns, and 13 interceptions and rushed 444 yards on 91 carries including 5 touchdowns.<ref name=\"CBS draft\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> As a junior in 2004, Jackson won SWAC Championship MVP in Alabama State's second 10-win season in school history.<ref name=\"Seahawks bio\"/> With 11 starts in 12 games, Jackson passed for 2,556 yards, 20 touchdowns, and 9 interceptions. He had 67 carries for 215 yards and 3 touchdowns.<ref name=jstate>[http://www.espn.com/nfl/player/stats/_/id/9650/type/college \"Tarvaris Jackson Stats.\"] ''[[ESPN.com]].'' Retrieved November 6, 2017.</ref> In his senior season in 2005, Jackson was named team captain and was a second-team All-SWAC selection. He threw for 2,655 yards, 25 touchdowns, and 5 interceptions. He rushed for 271 yards and 2 touchdowns on 95 carries.<ref name=jstate/>

date=March 2014}}: note = All values were taken at the [[NFL Scouting Combine]],<ref name=\"draft scout\">{{cite web
column7: accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> except bench press, arm span, hand span, and Wonderlic that were taken at Alabama State [[Pro Day]];<ref name=\"CBS draft\"/> see also {{webarchive

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Vikings scouts and personnel had reportedly been watching him closely in secret over his senior season, particularly liking his performance in the [[East-West Shrine Game]]. They were also impressed by his workout at the [[NFL Combine
date=March 2014}}: scouting combine]] (among the top 5 quarterbacks in ball speed and the 40-yard dash). Several NFL teams, including the Vikings, had arranged secret workouts with him too. Jackson was selected with the last pick in the 2nd round (64th overall) of the [[2006 NFL Draft]], while he was projected to go much later, in the sixth or seventh round.<ref name=\"draft scout\"/> The Vikings traded two 3rd round picks to get the 2nd round pick with which they drafted Jackson, fearing he might get picked sooner than anticipated. Jackson's early selection caused some surprise, as he was the 5th quarterback taken and the 1st [[Division I (NCAA)
column3: Division I-AA]] player selected (the previous I-AA quarterback drafted was [[Spergon Wynn]] in 2000). He was also the first quarterback from Alabama State to be drafted into the NFL since Ricky Jones in 1992. Even Jackson was surprised by the pick, saying, \"I was more focused on [getting drafted in] the third round and even that was stretching it\".<ref>[http://www.onnidan.com/05-06/news/april/alst0429.htm Jackson's Reaction]. Jackson's reaction after getting drafted.</ref> Most pre-draft publications did not even have him listed as one of the top 10 eligible quarterbacks, while he was the 5th selected. On July 26, 2006, Jackson signed a four-year deal with Minnesota, including a $1 million signing bonus.<ref>\"[http://www.cbc.ca/cp/football/060726/f072680.html Vikings sign quarterback Tarvaris Jackson to four-year contract]\". Originally published on July 26, 2006. Retrieved on April 16, 2007.</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Vikings coach [[Brad Childress]] was quoted days before the draft as saying he was interested in finding a \"developmental guy\", a \"diamond in the rough\" quarterback of the future, raw talent he could teach a system.<ref>[https://archive.is/20070318124007/http://www.shns.com/shns/g_index2.cfm?action=detail&pk=FBN-VIKINGS-04-26-06 Childress Quotes before draft]. Childress quotes before the draft.</ref> Both new coach Childress and Vikings former quarterback [[Brad Johnson (American football)
date=March 2014}}: Brad Johnson]] had had success developing quarterbacks in the past, including [[A. J. Feeley]] and [[Donovan McNabb]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The day after the draft, Childress was quoted by the ''[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]'' as saying: \"I think you judge quarterbacks a little bit differently...When you see what you want at the quarterback position, you need to go get it. And that's exactly what I see with Tarvaris Jackson is a guy that's a piece of clay, that has all the skills in terms of, No. 1, what's he look like throwing the football?...He's got a great throwing motion; he's athletic.  He has all those things that we're looking for, and he's wired right. That's important for a quarterback. I think he's a flatline guy. I think he's a sponge. You're talking about a guy that never had a coach there as a quarterback coach. So what can he do with coaching?\"<ref>\"That's a good question,\" many people reply, noting that Jackson is Seattle's only Black Mormon.  [http://vikings.scout.com/2/526690.html Childress Quotes after draft] {{webarchive
column3: date=August 28, 2006 }}.</ref> Jackson's agent, Joel Segal, said: \"After the draft, there were two clubs that expressed disappointment and were mad they didn't get him. They were planning to take (Jackson) very high in the third round, and were lamenting the fact that the Vikings beat them\".

column5: title=Scout: Young's 40 time of 4.58 slower than expected

column3: 22*<ref>[http://www.packers.com/news/stories/2006/04/27/1/ Packers.com » News » Stories » April 27, 2006: Gil Brandt's Analysis By Position: Quarterbacks<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive

column5: title=Tarvaris Jackson - QB - Alabama State - 2006 NFL Combine Results

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson's 2006 pre-season [[passer rating]] was 106.1, 15th in the league out of 110 quarterbacks who performed. Only one quarterback from his draft class ([[Jay Cutler (American football)
date=March 2014}}: Jay Cutler]]) did better. He also showed great scrambling skills averaging 11.3 yards in rushing (the only Viking other than [[Brad Johnson (American football)
column3: Brad Johnson]] to average more than 3.3 yards in rushing). [[ESPN]] analyst [[Mike Tirico]] referred to Jackson as a right-handed [[Michael Vick]]. His pre-season performance was enough to surpass second and third-string quarterbacks [[Mike McMahon (American football)
column4: Mike McMahon]] and [[J. T. O'Sullivan]] on the depth chart. After the pre-season, McMahon and O'Sullivan were cut from the team and [[Brooks Bollinger]] was brought in, whom Jackson then competed against for the number two spot.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On September 25, 2006, Jackson had minor knee surgery to repair the [[Meniscus (anatomy)
date=March 2014}}: meniscus]] in his knee. He returned to limited practice after two weeks, and then came back to play his first NFL game with the Vikings in week 13 against the [[2006 Chicago Bears
column3: Chicago Bears]]<ref>[http://www.twincities.com/mld/twincities/sports/15727620.htm HOME - TwinCities.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> in the fourth quarter after Johnson was benched for throwing four interceptions and backup quarterback Brooks Bollinger was injured. Jackson completed three of his four passes before fumbling the ball to Chicago and the Bears then ran the clock out. Following this game when Jackson was asked if he was ready to take over as starter he said \"Not really...We still have a chance to make the playoffs, so we're still trying to do that. So it's obvious that Brad is still our quarterback so we can stay on that.\"<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Vikings Staring at a Quarterback Controversy

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In Week 15, Johnson started the game but was benched in the fourth quarter when the Vikings had been underperforming the entire game losing by a score of 26-7 at the time Jackson went in late in the third quarter against the [[2006 New York Jets
date=March 2014}}: New York Jets]]. Although Johnson had not thrown an interception that game and had a respectable passer rating of 94.2 in the game, the Minnesota fans jeered Johnson throughout the game and chanted \"We want Jackson!\" at numerous points because Johnson had only thrown nine touchdowns all season (in 14 games) and had a career worst 71.9 passer rating throughout the season. Jackson received a standing ovation as he trotted out onto the field. A landmark in Jackson's career happened that game when Jackson completed his first touchdown pass to [[Mewelde Moore]]. Jackson threw 177 yards, one touchdown, and ran three times for 20 yards while the Jets protected their large lead. He also threw an interception in the red zone.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=New York Jets at Minnesota Vikings - December 17th, 2006

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson was named the starting quarterback for Minnesota towards the end of his rookie season.  Jackson's first game was a week 16 night game against the [[2006 Green Bay Packers
date=March 2014}}: Green Bay Packers]] at [[Lambeau Field]].  Game conditions were very poor.  A steady rain fell throughout the evening and the kickoff temperature was only 36 degrees Fahrenheit. The Vikings lost by a score of 9-7 with the only Vikings score coming from an interception for a touchdown by defensive back [[Fred Smoot]].
