column5: title=Tarvaris Jackson, Seattle Seahawks sign contract
column8: accessdate=August 25, 2013}}</ref> Jackson competed with [[Brady Quinn]] for the backup quarterback spot behind starter [[Russell Wilson]]. To coincide with the signing of Jackson, the [[Seattle Seahawks]] released quarterback [[Jerrod Johnson]].<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Seahawks officially sign Tarvaris Jackson, release Jerrod Johnson
column16: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> The Seahawks released quarterback Brady Quinn and made Jackson the official backup quarterback to Wilson.<ref>{{Cite web
column18: title=Brady Quinn loses Seattle Seahawks' backup QB fight
column24: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Jackson appeared in three games of the 2013 regular season producing 151 passing yards and a touchdown.<ref>{{Cite web
column29: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> During [[Super Bowl XLVIII]] against the [[2013 Denver Broncos season
column30: Denver Broncos]], Jackson came in relief of [[Russell Wilson]] during the fourthquarter, marking the first time in 13 years any backup quarterback has played in a Super Bowl. The Seahawks won their first Super Bowl in franchise history as they defeated the Broncos 43–8.<ref>{{Cite web
column32: title=Super Bowl XLVIII - Seattle Seahawks vs. Denver Broncos - February 2nd, 2014
column35: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Following the season, Jackson signed a one-year deal to stay with the Seahawks. The Seahawks made it to [[Super Bowl XLIX]], but failed to repeat as Super Bowl champions as they fell to the [[New England Patriots]] by a score of 28–24.<ref>{{Cite web
column37: title=Super Bowl XLIX - Seattle Seahawks vs. New England Patriots - February 1st, 2015

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Following the 2015 season, Jackson became an unrestricted free agent.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Report: Tarvaris Jackson will hit free agency

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On June 24, 2016, Jackson was arrested in [[Kissimmee, Florida]].  In July 2016, Jackson said he did not have money to pay for an attorney and requested a public defender.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Ex-Seahawk QB Tarvaris Jackson says he’s broke, asks for public defender, is denied
column7: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> On August 3, 2016, the Florida Assistant State Attorney dropped the case.<ref name=\"FL DA\">{{Cite web
column9: title=Ex-Vikings QB Tarvaris Jackson won't be prosecuted for alleged assault

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2018, Jackson took a graduate assistant role at Alabama State, his alma mater.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Tarvaris Jackson moves on from NFL career to coaching
column6: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> In 2019, Jackson was named quarterbacks coach for [[Tennessee State Tigers football

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson was killed on April 12, 2020, in a car accident in Alabama. The [[Alabama Law Enforcement Agency]] said that Jackson was involved in a single-car crash at 8:50 p.m.<ref>{{cite tweet
column3: title=Former #Seahawks QB Tarvaris Jackson died last night in a car accident in Alabama, a spokesperson for his employer Tennessee State tells me. Jackson, 36, was TSU’s QB coach. Along with Seattle, he also played for the #Vikings and #Bills.
column9: title=Former NFL QB Tarvaris Jackson dies in car crash
column14: title=Ex-NFL QB Tarvaris Jackson dies in car crash

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: *[http://www.mnscore.com/blog/?p=418 Q&A with Vikings QB Tarvaris Jackson at Minnesota Score]

date=March 2014}}: image=Tarvaris Jackson at 2014 Seahawks Super Bowl parade.jpg

caption=Jackson at the Seahawks' post-
[[Super Bowl XLVIII]] parade in 2014.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: '''Tarvaris Jackson''' (April 21, 1983 – April 12, 2020) was an [[American football]] [[quarterback]]. Born and raised in [[Montgomery, Alabama]], Jackson played [[college football]] at [[Arkansas Razorbacks football
column3: Alabama State]], and in the [[National Football League]] (NFL) for the [[Minnesota Vikings]], [[Seattle Seahawks]], and [[Buffalo Bills]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The Vikings selected Jackson in the second round of the [[2006 NFL Draft]], and Jackson played for the Vikings from 2006 to 2010. A reserve quarterback for much of his time with the Vikings, Jackson was starting quarterback for the [[2007 Minnesota Vikings season
date=March 2014}}: 2007 season]] and part of the [[2008 Minnesota Vikings season
column3: 2008 season]], after which Jackson started the Vikings' [[2008-09 NFL playoffs#NFC: Philadelphia Eagles 26, Minnesota Vikings 14
column4: Wild Card playoff game]]. In 2011, Jackson signed with the Seahawks and was starting quarterback for [[2011 Seattle Seahawks season
column5: the 2011 season]]. Jackson was then traded to the Bills before the [[2012 NFL season]] but never played a game.  Jackson returned to the Seahawks in 2013. He was the backup quarterback for [[Russell Wilson]] during [[Super Bowl XLVIII]] over the [[Denver Broncos]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson was born and raised in Montgomery, Alabama, and graduated from [[Sidney Lanier High School]] of Montgomery in 2001.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Montgomery native Tarvaris Jackson talks Lanier, ASU football
column6: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Jackson then enrolled at the [[University of Arkansas]] and played three games for the [[Arkansas Razorbacks football]] team as a freshman but suffered a season-ending injury. Consequently, Jackson received a medical [[Redshirt (college sports)
column7: redshirt]] for the season.<ref name=\"Seahawks bio\">{{cite web
column14: accessdate=November 13, 2014 }}</ref> Jackson finished 2001 with 3 of 9 passes completed for 53 yards and 1 interception and rushed 14 yards on 7 carries.<ref>{{Cite web
column19: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> In 2002, Jackson played 8 games. He completed 14 of 39 passes for 143 yards, 1 touchdown, and 2 interceptions and rushed -16 yards in 14 carries.<ref>{{Cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2003, after trailing on the depth chart to future first round draft pick [[Matt Jones (wide receiver)
date=March 2014}}: Matt Jones]], Jackson transferred to [[Alabama State University]] and led the [[Alabama State Hornets football
column3: Hornets]] to an 8-5 record, [[Southwestern Athletic Conference]] (SWAC) Eastern Division title, and berth in the [[SWAC Championship Game]].<ref name=\"Seahawks bio\"/> He completed 160 of 316 passes for 2,342 yards, 18 touchdowns, and 13 interceptions and rushed 444 yards on 91 carries including 5 touchdowns.<ref name=\"CBS draft\">{{cite web
column8: accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> As a junior in 2004, Jackson won SWAC Championship MVP in Alabama State's second 10-win season in school history.<ref name=\"Seahawks bio\"/> With 11 starts in 12 games, Jackson passed for 2,556 yards, 20 touchdowns, and 9 interceptions. He had 67 carries for 215 yards and 3 touchdowns.<ref name=jstate>[http://www.espn.com/nfl/player/stats/_/id/9650/type/college \"Tarvaris Jackson Stats.\"] ''[[ESPN.com]].'' Retrieved November 6, 2017.</ref> In his senior season in 2005, Jackson was named team captain and was a second-team All-SWAC selection. He threw for 2,655 yards, 25 touchdowns, and 5 interceptions. He rushed for 271 yards and 2 touchdowns on 95 carries.<ref name=jstate/>

date=March 2014}}: note = All values were taken at the [[NFL Scouting Combine]],<ref name=\"draft scout\">{{cite web
column7: accessdate=June 12, 2013}}</ref> except bench press, arm span, hand span, and Wonderlic that were taken at Alabama State [[Pro Day]];<ref name=\"CBS draft\"/> see also {{webarchive

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Vikings scouts and personnel had reportedly been watching him closely in secret over his senior season, particularly liking his performance in the [[East-West Shrine Game]]. They were also impressed by his workout at the [[NFL Combine
date=March 2014}}: scouting combine]] (among the top 5 quarterbacks in ball speed and the 40-yard dash). Several NFL teams, including the Vikings, had arranged secret workouts with him too. Jackson was selected with the last pick in the 2nd round (64th overall) of the [[2006 NFL Draft]], while he was projected to go much later, in the sixth or seventh round.<ref name=\"draft scout\"/> The Vikings traded two 3rd round picks to get the 2nd round pick with which they drafted Jackson, fearing he might get picked sooner than anticipated. Jackson's early selection caused some surprise, as he was the 5th quarterback taken and the 1st [[Division I (NCAA)
column3: Division I-AA]] player selected (the previous I-AA quarterback drafted was [[Spergon Wynn]] in 2000). He was also the first quarterback from Alabama State to be drafted into the NFL since Ricky Jones in 1992. Even Jackson was surprised by the pick, saying, \"I was more focused on [getting drafted in] the third round and even that was stretching it\".<ref>[http://www.onnidan.com/05-06/news/april/alst0429.htm Jackson's Reaction]. Jackson's reaction after getting drafted.</ref> Most pre-draft publications did not even have him listed as one of the top 10 eligible quarterbacks, while he was the 5th selected. On July 26, 2006, Jackson signed a four-year deal with Minnesota, including a $1 million signing bonus.<ref>\"[http://www.cbc.ca/cp/football/060726/f072680.html Vikings sign quarterback Tarvaris Jackson to four-year contract]\". Originally published on July 26, 2006. Retrieved on April 16, 2007.</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Vikings coach [[Brad Childress]] was quoted days before the draft as saying he was interested in finding a \"developmental guy\", a \"diamond in the rough\" quarterback of the future, raw talent he could teach a system.<ref>[https://archive.is/20070318124007/http://www.shns.com/shns/g_index2.cfm?action=detail&pk=FBN-VIKINGS-04-26-06 Childress Quotes before draft]. Childress quotes before the draft.</ref> Both new coach Childress and Vikings former quarterback [[Brad Johnson (American football)
date=March 2014}}: Brad Johnson]] had had success developing quarterbacks in the past, including [[A. J. Feeley]] and [[Donovan McNabb]].

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The day after the draft, Childress was quoted by the ''[[St. Paul Pioneer Press]]'' as saying: \"I think you judge quarterbacks a little bit differently...When you see what you want at the quarterback position, you need to go get it. And that's exactly what I see with Tarvaris Jackson is a guy that's a piece of clay, that has all the skills in terms of, No. 1, what's he look like throwing the football?...He's got a great throwing motion; he's athletic.  He has all those things that we're looking for, and he's wired right. That's important for a quarterback. I think he's a flatline guy. I think he's a sponge. You're talking about a guy that never had a coach there as a quarterback coach. So what can he do with coaching?\"<ref>\"That's a good question,\" many people reply, noting that Jackson is Seattle's only Black Mormon.  [http://vikings.scout.com/2/526690.html Childress Quotes after draft] {{webarchive
column3: date=August 28, 2006 }}.</ref> Jackson's agent, Joel Segal, said: \"After the draft, there were two clubs that expressed disappointment and were mad they didn't get him. They were planning to take (Jackson) very high in the third round, and were lamenting the fact that the Vikings beat them\".

column5: title=Scout: Young's 40 time of 4.58 slower than expected

column3: 22*<ref>[http://www.packers.com/news/stories/2006/04/27/1/ Packers.com » News » Stories » April 27, 2006: Gil Brandt's Analysis By Position: Quarterbacks<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive

column5: title=Tarvaris Jackson - QB - Alabama State - 2006 NFL Combine Results

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson's 2006 pre-season [[passer rating]] was 106.1, 15th in the league out of 110 quarterbacks who performed. Only one quarterback from his draft class ([[Jay Cutler (American football)
date=March 2014}}: Jay Cutler]]) did better. He also showed great scrambling skills averaging 11.3 yards in rushing (the only Viking other than [[Brad Johnson (American football)
column3: Brad Johnson]] to average more than 3.3 yards in rushing). [[ESPN]] analyst [[Mike Tirico]] referred to Jackson as a right-handed [[Michael Vick]]. His pre-season performance was enough to surpass second and third-string quarterbacks [[Mike McMahon (American football)
column4: Mike McMahon]] and [[J. T. O'Sullivan]] on the depth chart. After the pre-season, McMahon and O'Sullivan were cut from the team and [[Brooks Bollinger]] was brought in, whom Jackson then competed against for the number two spot.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On September 25, 2006, Jackson had minor knee surgery to repair the [[Meniscus (anatomy)
date=March 2014}}: meniscus]] in his knee. He returned to limited practice after two weeks, and then came back to play his first NFL game with the Vikings in week 13 against the [[2006 Chicago Bears
column3: Chicago Bears]]<ref>[http://www.twincities.com/mld/twincities/sports/15727620.htm HOME - TwinCities.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> in the fourth quarter after Johnson was benched for throwing four interceptions and backup quarterback Brooks Bollinger was injured. Jackson completed three of his four passes before fumbling the ball to Chicago and the Bears then ran the clock out. Following this game when Jackson was asked if he was ready to take over as starter he said \"Not really...We still have a chance to make the playoffs, so we're still trying to do that. So it's obvious that Brad is still our quarterback so we can stay on that.\"<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Vikings Staring at a Quarterback Controversy

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In Week 15, Johnson started the game but was benched in the fourth quarter when the Vikings had been underperforming the entire game losing by a score of 26-7 at the time Jackson went in late in the third quarter against the [[2006 New York Jets
date=March 2014}}: New York Jets]]. Although Johnson had not thrown an interception that game and had a respectable passer rating of 94.2 in the game, the Minnesota fans jeered Johnson throughout the game and chanted \"We want Jackson!\" at numerous points because Johnson had only thrown nine touchdowns all season (in 14 games) and had a career worst 71.9 passer rating throughout the season. Jackson received a standing ovation as he trotted out onto the field. A landmark in Jackson's career happened that game when Jackson completed his first touchdown pass to [[Mewelde Moore]]. Jackson threw 177 yards, one touchdown, and ran three times for 20 yards while the Jets protected their large lead. He also threw an interception in the red zone.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=New York Jets at Minnesota Vikings - December 17th, 2006

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson was named the starting quarterback for Minnesota towards the end of his rookie season.  Jackson's first game was a week 16 night game against the [[2006 Green Bay Packers
date=March 2014}}: Green Bay Packers]] at [[Lambeau Field]].  Game conditions were very poor.  A steady rain fell throughout the evening and the kickoff temperature was only 36 degrees Fahrenheit. The Vikings lost by a score of 9-7 with the only Vikings score coming from an interception for a touchdown by defensive back [[Fred Smoot]]. The offense set a franchise low record of only three first downs the whole game, did not get close enough to the end zone to even attempt a field goal, and only had 27 passing yards gained against the NFL's 19th ranked defense (ranked 26th against the pass). Jackson had a passer rating of 36.5, had a 50% completion rate (10-20 for 50 yards), one interception, and one fumble.  Packers quarterback Brett Favre only managed a slightly better 52% completion rate (26-50) and threw two interceptions. He threw for 285 yards with no touchdowns.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Minnesota Vikings at Green Bay Packers - December 21st, 2006

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson did not live up to the Vikings' expectations in 2007 despite finishing 8-4 as a starter.<ref>{{Cite web
column6: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Jackson had nine touchdowns and 12 interceptions, along with a 159 yards per game, causing the Vikings to have the second-worst passing offense in the NFL.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> His 70.8 passer rating was 28th among NFL quarterbacks.  Jackson missed three games because of injuries, which included a strained groin, a concussion and a fractured index finger. The Vikings failed to make the playoffs.  Analysts put the Vikings' 8-8 record on the successful running of [[Chester Taylor]] and rookie [[Adrian Peterson]], which took the pressure off of Jackson and the defense.<ref>{{Cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Later in the season, opponents decided to focus all their defensive efforts on stopping Peterson and the Vikings running game, while daring Jackson to beat them in the passing game.  The [[2007 Washington Redskins
date=March 2014}}: Washington Redskins]] successfully utilized five [[defensive lineman]] or four [[linebackers]] against the Vikings, leaving only two or three defensive backs in pass coverage.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071225070431/http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/12791702.html Washington D focuses all its attention on Peterson]</ref><ref>{{cite web
column10: via=washingtonpost.com}}</ref>  And the 49ers blitzed their [[cornerback]]s 20 percent of the time instead of covering receivers with them.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Patrick Reusse: Fans shouldn't go overboard on Jackson yet
column14: accessdate=July 1, 2016}}</ref><ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110723221658/http://www.wtov9.com/sports/14824511/detail.html Vikings Enjoying Quite A Turnaround]</ref>  On the season's last game against the [[2007 Denver Broncos
column15: Denver Broncos]], Jackson led the Vikings to two fourth quarter drives to tie the game and send it into overtime. In overtime, however, Jackson fumbled on the second play and the Vikings lost the game.<ref>{{Cite web
column17: title=Minnesota Vikings at Denver Broncos - December 30th, 2007
column20: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Jackson showed slow improvement over the season: he played a large role when the Vikings went on a five-game winning streak in November, but also showed his inexperience in several ill-judged interceptions, jump passes, and turnovers.  After the season, Childress would not say if Tarvaris Jackson would be the starter in 2008, explaining that he wanted to \"evaluate the total body of work\" first.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20071226171506/http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/12806557.html Childress noncommittal over quarterback's long-term future]</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: There was a lot of media coverage on Jackson the summer of 2008. The Vikings returned seven players that were in the [[2008 Pro Bowl]] (only three teams had more), and spent $60 million in guaranteed contract money upgrading their team with [[Jared Allen]], traded from the [[Kansas City Chiefs]], and free agents [[Bernard Berrian]] and [[Madieu Williams]]. Several analysts believed better quarterback play was all that was needed to make the Vikings one of the top contending teams in the NFL, and with the [[Green Bay Packers]] losing [[Brett Favre]] the [[NFC North Division]] was up for grabs.  [[Sport's Illustrated]]'s [[Paul Lionel Zimmerman
date=March 2014}}: Paul Zimmerman]] predicted the Vikings would win the Super Bowl.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Dare I pick Minnesota to win it all?

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Head coach Brad Childress decided to stay with Jackson as the starting quarterback and brought in [[Gus Frerotte]] to be his backup. It was widely reported in the off-season that Jackson had a new swagger, handled situations in practice well where he looked lost in the previous years, and had an improved grasp of the Vikings offensive system.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080526142945/http://www.startribune.com/sports/vikings/19160244.html?location_refer=Vikings QB Jackson acting the part]</ref>  Childress threw a \"Coaching 101\" clinic for media reporters in which he played a tape of Jackson showing the progress he made in 2007 through a series of missed passes or poor decisions that he made in early games but executed properly in later contests and concluded with some tape of him hitting a target net with every 15-yard pass he threw during an offseason drill.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20081014115851/http://blogs.twincities.com/Vikings/2008/05/coaching_101_clinic.html Coaching 101 clinic]</ref>  Offensive coordinator [[Darrell Bevell]] repeatedly told the press that although it was Jackson's third year with the Vikings it was really his second year playing, and NFL quarterbacks improve the most between their first and second years.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080727125711/http://blogs.twincities.com/Vikings/2008/05/bevell_on_tjack.html Bevell on T-Jack]</ref>  Jackson had another good preseason, until he injured his knee again in the second preseason game which kept him from playing the last two preseason games.
In the first game of the regular season against the [[2008 Green Bay Packers
date=March 2014}}: Green Bay Packers]], Jackson threw a game-ending interception and in the second game the Vikings made five field goal attempts and no touchdowns against the [[2008 Indianapolis Colts
column5: title=Minnesota Vikings at Green Bay Packers - September 8th, 2008
column10: title=Indianapolis Colts at Minnesota Vikings - September 14th, 2008
column13: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> The Vikings lost both games by close margins, and Jackson's 64.8 passer rating ranked him 26th in the NFL. Childress said in the second post-game press conference that Jackson would still definitely be the starter next week, but on Monday after a coaches' meeting he changed his mind and benched Jackson for the remainder of the year.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title=Official Blog of the National Football League

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: After being relegated to backup after the loss to the Colts, Jackson saw his next significant action in Week 14 against [[2008 Detroit Lions
date=March 2014}}: Detroit]], where he played the entire second half in place of an injured [[Gus Frerotte]]. With the Vikings trailing 6-3 at halftime to the winless Lions, Jackson completed eight of ten passes for 105 yards and a touchdown, an 11-yard strike to tight end [[Visanthe Shiancoe]] that would be the game-winning score for the Vikings.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Tarvaris Jackson steps in for Gus Frerotte, leads Minnesota Vikings to comeback victory – Twin Cities
column6: accessdate=July 1, 2016}}</ref>  The following week, with Frerotte still injured, Jackson was the starting quarterback against the [[2008 Arizona Cardinals
column7: Arizona Cardinals]] and he played arguably the best game of his career.  Jackson completed 11 of 17 passes for 163 yards and, most impressively, threw four touchdown passes and no interceptions.<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=Minnesota Vikings at Arizona Cardinals - December 14th, 2008
column12: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Jackson earned NFC Offensive Player of the Week honors for his performance as well as the [[FedEx Air & Ground NFL Players of the Week
column13: FedEx Air Player of the Week]] award.<ref>{{Cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The Vikings lost 24-17 to the [[2008 Atlanta Falcons
date=March 2014}}: Atlanta Falcons]] in Week 16 despite Jackson's performance.  He completed 22 of 36 passes for 233 yards with two touchdowns and no interceptions.  He also rushed for 76 yards (which matched the total of Pro-Bowl running back [[Adrian Peterson]]).<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Atlanta Falcons at Minnesota Vikings - December 21st, 2008
column7: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref>  With the Vikings in a win-and-in situation against the [[2008 New York Giants
column8: New York Giants]] in Week 17, Jackson overcame an interception in the end zone by leading the Vikings on a touchdown drive (a 54-yard strike to [[Bernard Berrian]]) and the game-winning field goal drive on the following possessions.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=New York Giants at Minnesota Vikings - December 28th, 2008
column13: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> The Vikings defeated the Giants 20-19 and earned the NFC North title.

column3: title=Minnesota Vikings wrap up NFC North championship on final play of regular season. Next up: Philadelphia Eagles – Twin Cities

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The Vikings season ended in the Wild Card Round of the playoffs with a loss to the [[2008 Philadelphia Eagles
date=March 2014}}: Philadelphia Eagles]]. Jackson went 15-for-35 for 164 yards in the game with one interception.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Wild Card - Philadelphia Eagles at Minnesota Vikings - January 4th, 2009

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson went into the 2009 season in competition for a starting job with [[Sage Rosenfels]], who the Vikings had acquired from the [[Houston Texans]].<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Vikings acquire Rosenfels, give QB new contract
column7: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> The Vikings also pursued former [[New York Jets]] and [[Green Bay Packers]] quarterback [[Brett Favre]], who had retired after the end of the 2008 season. Favre announced that he would not join the Vikings prior to [[training camp]], however, and Jackson and Rosenfels split duties in the early part of camp.<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20090731104335/http://www.sportingnews.com/blog/The_Trenches/entry/view/28956/vikings_favre_will_stay_retired The Sporting News]</ref> Jackson was the second quarterback to play in the opening preseason game, and was expected to start the second preseason game against the [[Kansas City Chiefs]].<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: That changed, however, when Favre announced that he would play for the Vikings after all, signing with the team on August 19.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Purple reign: Indecisive Favre signs with Vikings
column6: accessdate=July 1, 2016}}</ref> Jackson, Rosenfels, and 2008 third-stringer [[John David Booty]] were believed to be competing for two roster spots, and for the primary backup job. Many observers believed the Vikings would attempt to trade Jackson.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=With Favre on Board, Who Will Be the Odd Man Out?

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson helped his case with a strong performance in Favre's debut game against the [[2009 Kansas City Chiefs
date=March 2014}}: Kansas City Chiefs]], throwing for 202 yards and two touchdowns in backup work.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Chiefs vs. Vikings - Game Recap - August 21, 2009 - ESPN
column6: accessdate=July 1, 2016}}</ref> Ultimately, the Vikings elected to keep Jackson and Rosenfels on the active roster, with Jackson as the primary backup to Favre.<ref>{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson entered the Vikings' first two games of the season in [[garbage time]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Watch Minnesota Vikings vs. Cleveland Browns [09/13/2009] - NFL.com
column9: accessdate=July 1, 2016}}</ref> He also was used as a decoy in [[Punt (gridiron football)

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: The Vikings re-signed Jackson on Monday, April 19 as they waited for Favre to decide whether he would return for another season, which he did.  Jackson was a restricted free agent who was given a one-year tender worth $1.176 million. Jackson backed up Favre for the 2010 season.
Jackson took over for an injured Favre in Week 8 against the [[2010 New England Patriots
date=March 2014}}: New England Patriots]]. Jackson threw for one touchdown in the loss.<ref>{{Cite web
column4: title=Minnesota Vikings at New England Patriots - October 31st, 2010
column7: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Jackson took over for an injured Favre yet again in Week 13 against the [[2010 Buffalo Bills
column8: Buffalo Bills]]. Jackson threw two touchdown passes to [[Sidney Rice]] in the 38-14 win, but also threw three interceptions.<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Buffalo Bills at Minnesota Vikings - December 5th, 2010
column13: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Jackson started on December 13, against the [[2010 New York Giants
column14: New York Giants]] in place of the injured Favre.<ref>{{Cite web
column16: title=New York Giants at Minnesota Vikings - December 13th, 2010
column19: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> In that game, Jackson suffered a turf toe injury and missed the rest of the season.<ref>{{Cite web
column21: title=Vikings sign QB; Jackson out with turf toe

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On March 3, 2011, the Vikings declined to tender Jackson a contract offer to play for them in the 2011 season. Under league rules, Jackson became an [[unrestricted free agent]].
Jackson officially signed a two-year contract with Seattle Seahawks on July 29, 2011<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Seahawks Sign Rookie, Veterans and Draft Pick to Roster
column9: access-date=July 1, 2016}}</ref> and was announced as the starting quarterback shortly after.<ref>{{Cite web
column11: title=Carroll hands the ball to T-Jack
column17: access-date=July 1, 2016}}</ref> In Seattle, he had been reunited with offensive coordinator [[Darrell Bevell]] and wide receiver [[Sidney Rice]] both members of the Vikings during his time there. Along with [[wide receiver]] [[Mike Williams (wide receiver, born 1984)
column18: Mike Williams]], Jackson was appointed to offensive team captain, which was previously owned by [[Matt Hasselbeck]], who signed with the [[Tennessee Titans]]. Despite having a below-average year compared to other quarterbacks in the league, Jackson had the best year of his career, finishing with 3,091 yards passing, throwing 14 touchdowns and 13 interceptions.<ref>{{Cite web
column23: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> During the off-season, the Seahawks acquired former [[Green Bay Packers]] quarterback [[Matt Flynn]] and drafted Wisconsin quarterback [[Russell Wilson]] to compete with Jackson for the 2012 starting quarterback position.<ref>{{Cite web
column25: title=Seahawks, QB Matt Flynn agree to three-year, $26M contract

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On August 26, 2012, Jackson was traded to the [[Buffalo Bills]] for a conditional seventh round draft pick.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Tarvaris Jackson to be traded to Buffalo Bills
column7: accessdate=August 27, 2012}}</ref> The third-string quarterback for the season, Jackson did not see any game action in 2012.<ref name=\"Seahawks bio\"/><ref name=\"Seattle likely\">{{cite web

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On February 15, 2013, the Bills re-signed Jackson to a one-year, $2.25 million deal.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=QB Tarvaris Jackson re-signs with Bills
column11: title=Tarvaris Jackson deal has base value of $2.25 million
column15: accessdate=March 31, 2013}}</ref> He was released on June 10, 2013.<ref>{{cite web
column19: title=Tarvaris Jackson released by Buffalo Bills
column22: accessdate=June 10, 2013}}</ref> [[ESPN]] reported on June 12 that Jackson was likely to re-sign with the [[Seattle Seahawks]] for the 2013 season.<ref name=\"Seattle likely\"/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On June 13, 2013, Jackson signed a one-year deal with the [[Seattle Seahawks]].<ref>{{cite web
column5: title=Tarvaris Jackson, Seattle Seahawks sign contract
column8: accessdate=August 25, 2013}}</ref> Jackson competed with [[Brady Quinn]] for the backup quarterback spot behind starter [[Russell Wilson]]. To coincide with the signing of Jackson, the [[Seattle Seahawks]] released quarterback [[Jerrod Johnson]].<ref>{{Cite web
column10: title=Seahawks officially sign Tarvaris Jackson, release Jerrod Johnson
column16: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> The Seahawks released quarterback Brady Quinn and made Jackson the official backup quarterback to Wilson.<ref>{{Cite web
column18: title=Brady Quinn loses Seattle Seahawks' backup QB fight
column24: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Jackson appeared in three games of the 2013 regular season producing 151 passing yards and a touchdown.<ref>{{Cite web
column29: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> During [[Super Bowl XLVIII]] against the [[2013 Denver Broncos season
column30: Denver Broncos]], Jackson came in relief of [[Russell Wilson]] during the fourthquarter, marking the first time in 13 years any backup quarterback has played in a Super Bowl. The Seahawks won their first Super Bowl in franchise history as they defeated the Broncos 43–8.<ref>{{Cite web
column32: title=Super Bowl XLVIII - Seattle Seahawks vs. Denver Broncos - February 2nd, 2014
column35: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> Following the season, Jackson signed a one-year deal to stay with the Seahawks. The Seahawks made it to [[Super Bowl XLIX]], but failed to repeat as Super Bowl champions as they fell to the [[New England Patriots]] by a score of 28–24.<ref>{{Cite web
column37: title=Super Bowl XLIX - Seattle Seahawks vs. New England Patriots - February 1st, 2015

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Following the 2015 season, Jackson became an unrestricted free agent.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Report: Tarvaris Jackson will hit free agency

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On June 24, 2016, Jackson was arrested in [[Kissimmee, Florida]].  In July 2016, Jackson said he did not have money to pay for an attorney and requested a public defender.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Ex-Seahawk QB Tarvaris Jackson says he’s broke, asks for public defender, is denied
column7: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> On August 3, 2016, the Florida Assistant State Attorney dropped the case.<ref name=\"FL DA\">{{Cite web
column9: title=Ex-Vikings QB Tarvaris Jackson won't be prosecuted for alleged assault

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2018, Jackson took a graduate assistant role at Alabama State, his alma mater.<ref>{{Cite web
column3: title=Tarvaris Jackson moves on from NFL career to coaching
column6: access-date=June 26, 2019}}</ref> In 2019, Jackson was named quarterbacks coach for [[Tennessee State Tigers football

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Jackson was killed on April 12, 2020 in a car accident in Alabama. The Alabama Law Enforcement Agency said that Jackson was involved in a single-car crash at 8:50 p.m. Sunday.<ref>{{cite tweet
column3: title=Former #Seahawks QB Tarvaris Jackson died last night in a car accident in Alabama, a spokesperson for his employer Tennessee State tells me. Jackson, 36, was TSU’s QB coach. Along with Seattle, he also played for the #Vikings and #Bills.
column9: title=Former NFL QB Tarvaris Jackson dies in car crash
column14: title=Ex-NFL QB Tarvaris Jackson dies in car crash

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: *[http://www.mnscore.com/blog/?p=418 Q&A with Vikings QB Tarvaris Jackson at Minnesota Score]

column7: website=[[FamilySearch]]}}</ref> is an American [[country music]] singer-songwriter and actor.<ref name=GQ-3CountryBadasses-2016>{{cite news
column10: title=Meet Three Country Badasses Who Are Shaking Up the Nashville Establishment
column15: title=See Hollywood’s Hottest New Star Sturgill Simpson In The Trailer For Horror Movie The Hunt
column19: work=Stereogum}}</ref> As of September 2019, he has released four albums as a solo artist. He released two albums independently, ''[[High Top Mountain]]'' in 2013<ref name=CountryWeekly-HightTop-2013>{{cite news
column25: date=October 16, 2013}}</ref> and ''[[Metamodern Sounds in Country Music]]'' in 2014.<ref name=GQ-Warrior-2016>{{cite news
column28: title=The GQ&A: Sturgill Simpson, Country Music's Psychedelic Warrior-Philosopher
column31: date=January 7, 2016}}</ref> His second album was nominated for a [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album]],<ref name=Grammy-NominationsList-2014>{{cite web

column17: accessdate=June 19, 2019}}</ref> of a secretary and a [[Kentucky State Police]] Trooper,  who formerly worked undercover in narcotics.<ref name=FamilySearch-USPR-1998 /><ref name=Fader-Freewheeling-2014>{{cite web
column20: title=Another Country: A Freewheeling Hour with Sturgill Simpson
column23: date=July 15, 2014}}</ref> Due to his father's work, Simpson's family moved to [[Versailles, Kentucky
column25: Lexington]], where Simpson graduated from [[Woodford County High School (Kentucky)
column26: Woodford County High School]].<ref name=Fader-Freewheeling-2014 /> Simpson's mother's family were coal miners.<ref name=NPR-WEdition-MakeArt-2014>{{cite web
column29: title='I Wanna Make Art': Sturgill Simpson's Twisting Path To Nashville
column33: date=May 25, 2014}}</ref> Simpson is the first male on his mother's side of the family to not work in a strip mine or deep mine.<ref name=CharlieRose-SailorsGuide-2016>{{cite news

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: He described his educational career by noting that he was \"not a great student\".<ref name = RS>{{cite web
column4: title=The Fighting Side of Sturgill Simpson
column8: date=October 6, 2016}}</ref>  His parents divorced when he was in the seventh grade, and he sold drugs and experimented with [[LSD]] during high school.  He enlisted in the [[United States Navy]] his senior year of high school, and only \"barely graduated\".<ref name = RS/>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: After three years in the Navy, where he worked in the [[Combat Information Center]], Simpson spent time in Japan, then  lived in [[Everett, Washington
column3: Washington]], and Seattle, where he waited tables at [[IHOP]], then moved back home to [[Lexington, Kentucky
column6: title=Kentucky native Sturgill Simpson took long road, and railroad, to Nashville
column13: title=Episode 706 - Sturgill Simpson / John C. Reilly

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson formed the Country/Rock band Sunday Valley in 2004, for which he played Guitar/Vocals,<ref name = RS/> which played at the Pickathon festival in [[Portland, Oregon]].<ref name=AllMusic-Bio>{{cite web

Simpson took a break from music, focusing on building a career at a [[Salt Lake City]] railroad freight-shipping yard for [[Union Pacific Railroad]], which he eventually ended up managing. He credits his wife and friends with supporting what he characterized as a hobbyist focus on songwriting and playing to convincing him to actually focus on getting serious and trying to make music for a living.<ref name=CharlieRose-SailorsGuide-2016 /> After playing local open mics and gigs, Simpson returned to Sunday Valley. The band toured and made an album. He and his wife moved to [[Nashville]] when the group disbanded in 2012.<ref name=WSJ-CountryMeta-2014>{{cite news
After going solo, Simpson released his debut album ''[[High Top Mountain]]'' in 2013, which he self-funded, self-released, and had cut in Nashville <ref name=AllMusic-Bio/><ref>{{cite journal
column11: title=GEN F: Sturgill Simpson, the Cosmic Cowboy of the Digital Age Read
column14: date=May 12, 2014}}</ref> before signing to British independent label [[Loose Music
column17: title=Loose {{!}}   New Loose Signing: Sturgill Simpson!
column18: website=loosemusic.com}}</ref> who released the album in Europe in 2014.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Loose {{!}}   Sturgill Simpson's High Top Mountain, out today!
column21: website=loosemusic.com}}</ref> The album was produced by [[Dave Cobb]]. Among the session musicians were [[Hargus \"Pig\" Robbins]] on piano and [[Robby Turner]], a former guitarist for [[Waylon Jennings]], on [[steel guitar]].<ref name=\"Ky-LongRoad-2013\"/> The record is named after a cemetery near Jackson where many of Simpson's family members are buried.<ref name=AmSongwriter-ManHour-2013>{{cite web
column24: title=Sturgill Simpson: Man Of The Hour
column27: date=April 26, 2013}}</ref> [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[AllMusic]] rated ''High Top Mountain'' 3 and half stars out of 5, comparing its sound favorably to Waylon Jennings.<ref name=AllMusic-HighTop_2013>{{cite web
column32: website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> The album's style has also been compared to [[Merle Haggard]]'s.<ref name=Fader-GenF-2014/> Erik Ernst of the ''[[Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel]]'' also compared it to Jennings, saying that it had \"rich vintage sounds, heartbreaking ballads, and juke-joint ramblers\".<ref name=MilwaukeeJournalSent-Review-2013>{{cite web
column34: title=CD reviews: Jason Isbell, Alison Moyet, Walter Trout, Sturgill Simpson

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2014, Simpson released his second album produced by Dave Cobb, ''[[Metamodern Sounds in Country Music]]'' to positive reviews.<ref name=Pitchfork-MetaReview-2014>{{cite web
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson, Metamodern Sounds in Country Music
column10: title=A Country Lament Sinks Into Despair: Sturgill Simpson's 'Metamodern Sounds in Country Music'
column16: title=The Best, Darkest, Weirdest Country Record of the Year
column23: title=Sturgill Simpson Shuns 'Tailgating and Spring Breaks' on New Album
column27: date=May 16, 2014}}</ref> The album's lead single is \"Living the Dream\".<ref name=Paste-Dream-2014>{{cite web
column29: title=Song Premiere: Sturgill Simpson – \"Living The Dream\"
column33: work=[[Paste Magazine]]}}</ref> The record is described as a \"deep and unconventional relationship between traditionalism and new ways of thinking,\" and deviates from Simpson's more traditional hard country debut.<ref name=NPR-GodsDrugsLizardAliens-2014>{{cite web
column36: title=God, Drugs And Lizard Aliens: Yep, It's Country Music
column39: date=April 17, 2014}}</ref> Simpson said that \"recording and mixing was done in five and a half days for about $4,000. I was pretty proud about that.\"<ref name=AmSongwriter-MysticQ&A-2014>{{cite web
column42: title=Mystic Mind: A Q&A with Sturgill Simpson
column45: date=July 23, 2014}}</ref> The album made two separate \"Top Albums of 2014\" lists in ''[[The New York Times]]'' (ranking 4th<ref name=NYTimes-Top10-2014>{{cite news
column54: title=Nate Chinen's Top Albums of 2014, With Beyoncé, Fred Hersch Trio and More
column57: url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/14/arts/music/authoritative-albums-from-beyonc-fred-hersch-trio-and-more.html}}</ref>) and was also called the best album of the year by ''[[American Songwriter]]''.<ref name=\"ASBest2014\">{{cite news
column58: title=American Songwriter's Top 50 Albums of 2014: Presented by D'Addario
column59: work=[[American Songwriter]]
column61: url=http://americansongwriter.com/2014/11/american-songwriters-top-50-albums-2014/5/}}</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson made his US network television debut on July 14, 2014, on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', playing \"Life of Sin\".<ref name=RStone-Letterman-2014>{{cite web
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson Makes 'Letterman' Debut: Kentucky singer-songwriter wows Dave with \"Life of Sin\"
column8: date=July 15, 2014}}</ref> That year, he would go on to play \"Living the Dream\" on a September episode of ''[[Conan (talk show)
column10: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Live the 'Dream' With Conan O'Brien
column14: Turtles All the Way Down]]\" on an October episode of ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon]]'',<ref name=RollingStone-Fallon-Turtles-2014>{{cite news
column17: title=Sturgill Simpson Explores Space and Time with 'Turtles' Performance on 'Fallon'
column21: The Promise]]\" on a December episode of ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]''.<ref name=\"RSMeyers\">{{cite news
column24: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Perform a Lost Eighties Hit on 'Seth Meyers'
column27: url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/watch-sturgill-simpson-perform-a-lost-eighties-hit-on-seth-meyers-20141211}}</ref> In 2015, he returned to ''The Late Show'' and ''Conan'' playing \"Long White Line\" in February and \"Just Let Go\" in April (respectively).<ref name=\"RSLetterman\">{{cite news
column30: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Reincarnate 'Long White Line' on 'Letterman'
column34: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson 'Just Let Go' With Super-Sized Band on 'Conan'
column37: url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/watch-sturgill-simpson-just-let-go-with-super-sized-band-on-conan-20150415}}</ref> He has also played the [[Grand Ole Opry]]<ref name=NPR-WEdition-MakeArt-2014 /> and at [[Austin City Limits]]. He has opened for artists like [[Dwight Yoakam]], [[Willie Nelson]],<ref name=ACL-WillieNelson-2014>{{cite web
column40: website=[[Austin City Limits]] Live}}</ref> Merle Haggard,<ref name=\"Boot\">{{cite news
column43: title=Merle Haggard Praises Sturgill Simpson, Calls Modern Country Music 'Crap'
column46: url=http://theboot.com/merle-haggard-sturgill-simpson-modern-country-music-crap/}}</ref> and the [[Zac Brown Band]].<ref name=SavingCountry-WhereGo-2014>{{cite web
column48: title=Where Does Sturgill Simpson Go From Here?

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: His cover of \"The Promise\" by 1980s band [[When in Rome (band)
date=March 2014}}: When In Rome]] was featured in the Season 2 Episode 9 of the HBO series ''[[The Leftovers (TV series)
column3: The Leftovers]]'' in November 2015.<ref name=SavingCountry-Leftovers-2015>{{cite news
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson Featured on HBO's \"The Leftovers\"
column7: url=http://www.savingcountrymusic.com/sturgill-simpson-featured-on-hbos-the-leftovers/}}</ref> The first track from this album, \"Turtles All The Way Down,\" was featured in the soundtrack for Season 1 Episode 5 of HBO's series ''[[Watchmen (TV series)
column8: Watchmen]]'' in November 2019.<ref name=Watchmen-Soundtrack>https://www.tunefind.com/show/watchmen/season-1/93019</ref> Simpson also wrote and performed the theme song to the [[Martin Scorsese]]/[[Mick Jagger]]-produced TV show, ''[[Vinyl (TV series)
column9: Vinyl]].'' The song is called \"Sugar Daddy.\"<ref name=DallasObserver-SugarDaddy-2016>{{cite news
column12: title=Sturgill Simpson Hasn't Betrayed Country Music Because He Never Was A Country Artist
column15: date=March 9, 2016}}</ref> As of July 2015, Simpson's songs are represented by [[Downtown Music Publishing]]—an agreement that followed his record deal with [[Atlantic Records]].<ref name=Boot-DowntonMusic-2015>{{cite news
column18: title=Sturgill Simpson Signs With Downtown Music Publishing

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In March 2016, Simpson released the first track from his third album, ''[[A Sailor's Guide To Earth]]'', a song called \"Brace For Impact (Live A Little).\"<ref name=RStone-NirvanaNewRecord-2016>{{cite news
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson on Staying Country, Covering Nirvana on New Album
column8: date=March 21, 2016}}</ref> The record is a commemoration of the birth of Simpson's son, and features work by [[Sharon Jones & The Dap-Kings
column12: title=Hear Thrilling New Music From Sturgill Simpson
column15: date=March 4, 2016}}</ref> as well as a cover of [[Nirvana (band)
column16: Nirvana's]], \"[[In Bloom]].\" Simpson self-produced the record – [[Dave Cobb]], who produced his prior records, did not work on this record, marking a departure from prior efforts.<ref name=DallasObserver-SugarDaddy-2016 /> Simpson also created the record with a focus on sequencing, and recorded tracks live.<ref name=RStone-NirvanaNewRecord-2016 /> The record marks his major label debut.<ref name=Maron-WTFPodcast-2016 /> It was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year
column17: Album of the Year]] and won [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album
column18: Best Country Album]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards
column21: title=59th Annual GRAMMY Awards Nominees and Winners
column23: date=December 6, 2016}}</ref> In January 2017, Simpson appeared on the [[Felicity Jones]]-hosted episode of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', playing \"Keep It Between the Lines\" and \"Call to Arms.\"<ref name=SNL-KeepItBetweenTheLines-2017>{{cite news
column24: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson: Keep It Between the Lines from Saturday Night Live
column28: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson: Call To Arms from Saturday Night Live

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson had planned to take a break from touring for the entirety of 2017 to focus on his family, but reconsidered after his Grammy nominations.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref> He began touring again in May 2017 by playing a show at the Wharf Amphitheater in [[Orange Beach, Alabama]], with [[Margo Price]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref> Simpson also performed as the opening act for three shows during the [[Guns N' Roses]] \"Not in this Lifetime\" tour in the summer of 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Sturgill Simpson Joining Guns N' Roses for Three Summertime Shows
column18: accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref> Simpson helped produce fellow Kentucky singer/songwriter [[Tyler Childers]]' 2017 album ''Purgatory'' after being introduced to Childers by drummer Miles Miller.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Hear Sturgill Simpson Protege Tyler Childers' New 'Whitehouse Road'

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In a March 5, 2018, interview on ''[[The Joe Rogan Experience]]'' podcast, Simpson revealed that he was working on his fourth studio album, and hinted that it would be a [[double album]], though this was ultimately not the case.<ref>{{cite web
column7: via=YouTube}}</ref> The title of the album, ''[[Sound & Fury (Sturgill Simpson album)
column8: Sound & Fury]]'', was announced on July 21, 2019, at the [[San Diego Comic-Con]], with Simpson describing it as a \"sleazy, steamy rock'n'roll record\". A companion [[anime]] film bearing the same name was also released on [[Netflix]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Sturgill Simpson Announces New Album, Anime Film 'Sound & Fury'
column14: work=Rolling Stone}}</ref> The album was officially put up for pre-order on August 20, 2019, with the track \"Sing Along\" being released the same day. It was released on September 27, 2019, to positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Sound & Fury by Sturgill Simpson Reviews
column18: accessdate=October 9, 2019}}</ref> The album broke with Simpson's established country style, featuring a fuzzy [[hard rock]] sound influenced by psychedelia and funk music.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson was originally going to perform at the [[Woodstock 50]] music festival in August 2019, before the festival's cancellation.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Woodstock 2019: The Killers, Chance the Rapper, Imagine Dragons to headline 50th anniversary festival

date=March 2014}}: title=Who is Sturgill Simpson's new Bass Player

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson is often compared to [[Waylon Jennings]]<ref name=Paste-MetaReview-2014>{{cite web
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson: Metamodern Sounds In Country Music Review
column8: date=May 21, 2014}}</ref> and the [[outlaw country]] genre of country music.<ref name=Grantland-NewAgeOutlaw-2014>{{cite web
column11: title=The New-Age Outlaw Country of Lydia Loveless and Sturgill Simpson
column14: date=April 30, 2014}}</ref> [[Shooter Jennings]] says, \"Sturgill isn't imitating at all, and he sounds like my favorite era of my dad, the Seventies, when he would sing quieter and more conversational. That's what struck me about Sturgill from Day One. And still does.\"<ref name=RStone-CountryMessiah-2014>{{cite web
column17: title=Is Sturgill Simpson Country Music's Savior? Not If He Can Help It
column21: date=June 3, 2014}}</ref> Simpson himself counts [[Merle Haggard]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Keith Whitley]], and [[Marty Robbins]] as much bigger influences on his sound than Waylon Jennings.<ref name=\"RSInterview\">{{cite news
column24: title=5 Things We Learned From Sturgill Simpson's Interview With Foos Guitarist
column27: url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/5-things-we-learned-from-sturgill-simpsons-interview-with-foos-guitarist-20150731}}</ref> Simpson has also stated he tries to base his career around that of [[Dwight Yoakam]]. Indeed, [[Country Music Television]] noted that Simpson had \"a voice that recalls Merle Haggard [and] guitar licks that bring [[Buck Owens]] to mind.\"<ref name=CMT-Metamodern-2014>{{cite news
column30: title=Sturgill Simpson Puts a Metamodern Spin on Country Music
column33: url=http://www.cmtedge.com/2014/05/16/sturgill-simpson-puts-a-metamodern-spin-on-country-music/}}</ref> His overall sound was described by [[Indiewire]] as \"a mesmerizing and sometimes bewildering mix of traditional country sounds, contemporary philosophy, and psychedelic recording-studio wizardry.\"<ref name=Indiewire-Interview-2014>{{cite news
column36: title=Metamericana: Outlaw Country Goes Psychedelic: An Interview with Sturgill Simpson on His Music Videos

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson is married and in 2018 he revealed he and his family reside in the Smoky Mountain area.<ref name=Fader-Freewheeling-2014 /> He has three sons.<ref name=WSJ-CountryMeta-2014 /><ref name=CountryStandardTime-Metamodern-2014>{{cite web
column7: date=July 2014}}</ref> Simpson is a [[Kentucky Colonel]], having been honoured at the [[Kentucky State Capitol]] on March 20, 2018. Rep. [[James Kay (Kentucky politician)
column8: James Kay]] described Simpson as \"independent\" and \"very proud to be from our great Commonwealth,\" calling ''Metamodern Sounds in Country Music'' \"one of the best albums of all time ... pure Kentucky and ... pure Sturgill Simpson.\"<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Sturgill Simpson Honored By Kentucky Lawmakers, Is Now a Kentucky Colonel

Among the session musicians were [[Hargus \"Pig\" Robbins]] on piano and [[Robby Turner]], a former guitarist for [[Waylon Jennings]], on [[steel guitar]].<ref name=\"Ky-LongRoad-2013\"/> The record is named after a cemetery near Jackson where many of Simpson's family members are buried.<ref name=AmSongwriter-ManHour-2013>{{cite web
column24: title=Sturgill Simpson: Man Of The Hour
column27: date=April 26, 2013}}</ref> [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] of [[AllMusic]] rated ''High Top Mountain'' 3 and half stars out of 5, comparing its sound favorably to Waylon Jennings.<ref name=AllMusic-HighTop_2013>{{cite web
column32: website=[[AllMusic]]}}</ref> The album's style has also been compared to [[Merle Haggard]]'s.<ref name=Fader-GenF-2014/> Erik Ernst of the ''[[Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel]]'' also compared it to Jennings, saying that it had \"rich vintage sounds, heartbreaking ballads, and juke-joint ramblers\".<ref name=MilwaukeeJournalSent-Review-2013>{{cite web
column34: title=CD reviews: Jason Isbell, Alison Moyet, Walter Trout, Sturgill Simpson

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In 2014, Simpson released his second album produced by Dave Cobb, ''[[Metamodern Sounds in Country Music]]'' to positive reviews.<ref name=Pitchfork-MetaReview-2014>{{cite web
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson, Metamodern Sounds in Country Music
column10: title=A Country Lament Sinks Into Despair: Sturgill Simpson's 'Metamodern Sounds in Country Music'
column16: title=The Best, Darkest, Weirdest Country Record of the Year
column23: title=Sturgill Simpson Shuns 'Tailgating and Spring Breaks' on New Album
column27: date=May 16, 2014}}</ref> The album's lead single is \"Living the Dream\".<ref name=Paste-Dream-2014>{{cite web
column29: title=Song Premiere: Sturgill Simpson – \"Living The Dream\"
column33: work=[[Paste Magazine]]}}</ref> The record is described as a \"deep and unconventional relationship between traditionalism and new ways of thinking,\" and deviates from Simpson's more traditional hard country debut.<ref name=NPR-GodsDrugsLizardAliens-2014>{{cite web
column36: title=God, Drugs And Lizard Aliens: Yep, It's Country Music
column39: date=April 17, 2014}}</ref> Simpson said that \"recording and mixing was done in five and a half days for about $4,000. I was pretty proud about that.\"<ref name=AmSongwriter-MysticQ&A-2014>{{cite web
column42: title=Mystic Mind: A Q&A with Sturgill Simpson
column45: date=July 23, 2014}}</ref> The album made two separate \"Top Albums of 2014\" lists in ''[[The New York Times]]'' (ranking 4th<ref name=NYTimes-Top10-2014>{{cite news
column54: title=Nate Chinen's Top Albums of 2014, With Beyoncé, Fred Hersch Trio and More
column57: url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/14/arts/music/authoritative-albums-from-beyonc-fred-hersch-trio-and-more.html}}</ref>) and was also called the best album of the year by ''[[American Songwriter]]''.<ref name=\"ASBest2014\">{{cite news
column58: title=American Songwriter's Top 50 Albums of 2014: Presented by D'Addario
column59: work=[[American Songwriter]]
column61: url=http://americansongwriter.com/2014/11/american-songwriters-top-50-albums-2014/5/}}</ref>

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson made his US network television debut on July 14, 2014, on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', playing \"Life of Sin\".<ref name=RStone-Letterman-2014>{{cite web
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson Makes 'Letterman' Debut: Kentucky singer-songwriter wows Dave with \"Life of Sin\"
column8: date=July 15, 2014}}</ref> That year, he would go on to play \"Living the Dream\" on a September episode of ''[[Conan (talk show)
column10: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Live the 'Dream' With Conan O'Brien
column14: Turtles All the Way Down]]\" on an October episode of ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon]]'',<ref name=RollingStone-Fallon-Turtles-2014>{{cite news
column17: title=Sturgill Simpson Explores Space and Time with 'Turtles' Performance on 'Fallon'
column21: The Promise]]\" on a December episode of ''[[Late Night with Seth Meyers]]''.<ref name=\"RSMeyers\">{{cite news
column24: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Perform a Lost Eighties Hit on 'Seth Meyers'
column27: url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/watch-sturgill-simpson-perform-a-lost-eighties-hit-on-seth-meyers-20141211}}</ref> In 2015, he returned to ''The Late Show'' and ''Conan'' playing \"Long White Line\" in February and \"Just Let Go\" in April (respectively).<ref name=\"RSLetterman\">{{cite news
column30: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson Reincarnate 'Long White Line' on 'Letterman'
column34: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson 'Just Let Go' With Super-Sized Band on 'Conan'
column37: url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/videos/watch-sturgill-simpson-just-let-go-with-super-sized-band-on-conan-20150415}}</ref> He has also played the [[Grand Ole Opry]]<ref name=NPR-WEdition-MakeArt-2014 /> and at [[Austin City Limits]]. He has opened for artists like [[Dwight Yoakam]], [[Willie Nelson]],<ref name=ACL-WillieNelson-2014>{{cite web
column40: website=[[Austin City Limits]] Live}}</ref> Merle Haggard,<ref name=\"Boot\">{{cite news
column43: title=Merle Haggard Praises Sturgill Simpson, Calls Modern Country Music 'Crap'
column46: url=http://theboot.com/merle-haggard-sturgill-simpson-modern-country-music-crap/}}</ref> and the [[Zac Brown Band]].<ref name=SavingCountry-WhereGo-2014>{{cite web
column48: title=Where Does Sturgill Simpson Go From Here?

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: His cover of \"The Promise\" by 1980s band [[When in Rome (band)
date=March 2014}}: When In Rome]] was featured in the Season 2 Episode 9 of the HBO series ''[[The Leftovers (TV series)
column3: The Leftovers]]'' in November 2015.<ref name=SavingCountry-Leftovers-2015>{{cite news
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson Featured on HBO's \"The Leftovers\"
column7: url=http://www.savingcountrymusic.com/sturgill-simpson-featured-on-hbos-the-leftovers/}}</ref> The first track from this album, \"Turtles All The Way Down,\" was featured in the soundtrack for Season 1 Episode 5 of HBO's series ''[[Watchmen (TV series)
column8: Watchmen]]'' in November 2019.<ref name=Watchmen-Soundtrack>https://www.tunefind.com/show/watchmen/season-1/93019</ref> Simpson also wrote and performed the theme song to the [[Martin Scorsese]]/[[Mick Jagger]]-produced TV show, ''[[Vinyl (TV series)
column9: Vinyl]].'' The song is called \"Sugar Daddy.\"<ref name=DallasObserver-SugarDaddy-2016>{{cite news
column12: title=Sturgill Simpson Hasn't Betrayed Country Music Because He Never Was A Country Artist
column15: date=March 9, 2016}}</ref> As of July 2015, Simpson's songs are represented by [[Downtown Music Publishing]]—an agreement that followed his record deal with [[Atlantic Records]].<ref name=Boot-DowntonMusic-2015>{{cite news
column18: title=Sturgill Simpson Signs With Downtown Music Publishing

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In March 2016, Simpson released the first track from his third album, ''[[A Sailor's Guide To Earth]]'', a song called \"Brace For Impact (Live A Little).\"<ref name=RStone-NirvanaNewRecord-2016>{{cite news
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson on Staying Country, Covering Nirvana on New Album
column8: date=March 21, 2016}}</ref> The record is a commemoration of the birth of Simpson's son, and features work by [[Sharon Jones & The Dap-Kings
column12: title=Hear Thrilling New Music From Sturgill Simpson
column15: date=March 4, 2016}}</ref> as well as a cover of [[Nirvana (band)
column16: Nirvana's]], \"[[In Bloom]].\" Simpson self-produced the record – [[Dave Cobb]], who produced his prior records, did not work on this record, marking a departure from prior efforts.<ref name=DallasObserver-SugarDaddy-2016 /> Simpson also created the record with a focus on sequencing, and recorded tracks live.<ref name=RStone-NirvanaNewRecord-2016 /> The record marks his major label debut.<ref name=Maron-WTFPodcast-2016 /> It was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Album of the Year
column17: Album of the Year]] and won [[Grammy Award for Best Country Album
column18: Best Country Album]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards
column21: title=59th Annual GRAMMY Awards Nominees and Winners
column23: date=December 6, 2016}}</ref> In January 2017, Simpson appeared on the [[Felicity Jones]]-hosted episode of ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'', playing \"Keep It Between the Lines\" and \"Call to Arms.\"<ref name=SNL-KeepItBetweenTheLines-2017>{{cite news
column24: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson: Keep It Between the Lines from Saturday Night Live
column28: title=Watch Sturgill Simpson: Call To Arms from Saturday Night Live

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson had planned to take a break from touring for the entirety of 2017 to focus on his family, but reconsidered after his Grammy nominations.<ref>{{cite web
column6: accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref> He began touring again in May 2017 by playing a show at the Wharf Amphitheater in [[Orange Beach, Alabama]], with [[Margo Price]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref> Simpson also performed as the opening act for three shows during the [[Guns N' Roses]] \"Not in this Lifetime\" tour in the summer of 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column12: title=Sturgill Simpson Joining Guns N' Roses for Three Summertime Shows
column18: accessdate=January 15, 2018}}</ref> Simpson helped produce fellow Kentucky singer/songwriter [[Tyler Childers]]' 2017 album ''Purgatory'' after being introduced to Childers by drummer Miles Miller.<ref>{{cite web
column20: title=Hear Sturgill Simpson Protege Tyler Childers' New 'Whitehouse Road'

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In a March 5, 2018, interview on ''[[The Joe Rogan Experience]]'' podcast, Simpson revealed that he was working on his fourth studio album, and hinted that it would be a [[double album]], though this was ultimately not the case.<ref>{{cite web
column7: via=YouTube}}</ref> The title of the album, ''[[Sound & Fury (Sturgill Simpson album)
column8: Sound & Fury]]'', was announced on July 21, 2019, at the [[San Diego Comic-Con]], with Simpson describing it as a \"sleazy, steamy rock'n'roll record\". A companion [[anime]] film bearing the same name was also released on [[Netflix]].<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Sturgill Simpson Announces New Album, Anime Film 'Sound & Fury'
column14: work=Rolling Stone}}</ref> The album was officially put up for pre-order on August 20, 2019, with the track \"Sing Along\" being released the same day. It was released on September 27, 2019, to positive reviews.<ref>{{cite web
column16: title=Sound & Fury by Sturgill Simpson Reviews
column18: accessdate=October 9, 2019}}</ref> The album broke with Simpson's established country style, featuring a fuzzy [[hard rock]] sound influenced by psychedelia and funk music.

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson was originally going to perform at the [[Woodstock 50]] music festival in August 2019, before the festival's cancellation.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=Woodstock 2019: The Killers, Chance the Rapper, Imagine Dragons to headline 50th anniversary festival

date=March 2014}}: title=Who is Sturgill Simpson's new Bass Player

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: * Miles Miller – drums, percussion, backing vocals (2012–present)

column3: Simpson with an acoustic guitar, pictured here in 2013]]

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson is often compared to [[Waylon Jennings]]<ref name=Paste-MetaReview-2014>{{cite web
column4: title=Sturgill Simpson: Metamodern Sounds In Country Music Review
column8: date=May 21, 2014}}</ref> and the [[outlaw country]] genre of country music.<ref name=Grantland-NewAgeOutlaw-2014>{{cite web
column11: title=The New-Age Outlaw Country of Lydia Loveless and Sturgill Simpson
column14: date=April 30, 2014}}</ref> [[Shooter Jennings]] says, \"Sturgill isn't imitating at all, and he sounds like my favorite era of my dad, the Seventies, when he would sing quieter and more conversational. That's what struck me about Sturgill from Day One. And still does.\"<ref name=RStone-CountryMessiah-2014>{{cite web
column17: title=Is Sturgill Simpson Country Music's Savior? Not If He Can Help It
column21: date=June 3, 2014}}</ref> Simpson himself counts [[Merle Haggard]], [[Willie Nelson]], [[Keith Whitley]], and [[Marty Robbins]] as much bigger influences on his sound than Waylon Jennings.<ref name=\"RSInterview\">{{cite news
column24: title=5 Things We Learned From Sturgill Simpson's Interview With Foos Guitarist
column27: url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/5-things-we-learned-from-sturgill-simpsons-interview-with-foos-guitarist-20150731}}</ref> Simpson has also stated he tries to base his career around that of [[Dwight Yoakam]]. Indeed, [[Country Music Television]] noted that Simpson had \"a voice that recalls Merle Haggard [and] guitar licks that bring [[Buck Owens]] to mind.\"<ref name=CMT-Metamodern-2014>{{cite news
column30: title=Sturgill Simpson Puts a Metamodern Spin on Country Music
column33: url=http://www.cmtedge.com/2014/05/16/sturgill-simpson-puts-a-metamodern-spin-on-country-music/}}</ref> His overall sound was described by [[Indiewire]] as \"a mesmerizing and sometimes bewildering mix of traditional country sounds, contemporary philosophy, and psychedelic recording-studio wizardry.\"<ref name=Indiewire-Interview-2014>{{cite news
column36: title=Metamericana: Outlaw Country Goes Psychedelic: An Interview with Sturgill Simpson on His Music Videos

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: Simpson is married and in 2018 he revealed he and his family reside in the Smoky Mountain area.<ref name=Fader-Freewheeling-2014 /> He has three sons.<ref name=WSJ-CountryMeta-2014 /><ref name=CountryStandardTime-Metamodern-2014>{{cite web
column7: date=July 2014}}</ref> Simpson is a [[Kentucky Colonel]], having been honoured at the [[Kentucky State Capitol]] on March 20, 2018. Rep. [[James Kay (Kentucky politician)
column8: James Kay]] described Simpson as \"independent\" and \"very proud to be from our great Commonwealth,\" calling ''Metamodern Sounds in Country Music'' \"one of the best albums of all time ... pure Kentucky and ... pure Sturgill Simpson.\"<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Sturgill Simpson Honored By Kentucky Lawmakers, Is Now a Kentucky Colonel

On '''13 March''', the first two cases were confirmed, a 77-year-old man from [[Vitina]] and an Italian woman in her early 20s, who worked in [[Klina]] with Caritas Kosova.<ref>{{cite news

column14: date=13 March 2020}}</ref> The [[Government of Kosovo]] decided to quarantine and block the entrances and exits of these two cities.<ref>{{cite news

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On '''14 March''', the third case was confirmed, a family member of the 77-year-old from [[Vitina]] tested positive for coronavirus.<ref>{{cite news

column14: Prime Minister]] [[Albin Kurti]] decided to quarantine the municipality.<ref>{{cite news

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On '''15 March''', four new cases of coronavirus are confirmed, three from [[Mališevo]] and one from the village Dumnica of [[Podujevo]].<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Konfirmohen 4 rastet e reja me coronavirus, 3 nga Malisheva dhe një nga Podujeva
column4: trans-title=The 4 new cases of coronavirus confirmed, 3 from Mališevo and one from Podujevo
column7: date=15 March 2020}}</ref> After the new cases emerged, the Ministry of Health requested that the [[Government of Kosovo]] declare a state of public health emergency.<ref>{{cite news

column10: trans-title=The government declares a public health emergency

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On '''16 March''', four close family members of the 77-year-old patient from [[Vitina]] had been tested positive for coronavirus.<ref>{{cite news

column4: trans-title=Another four new cases with coronavirus, the number of infected reaches 13
column7: date=16 March 2020}}</ref> Two additional cases of coronavirus were confirmed that day, a couple who flew from [[London]] to [[Pristina]]; a male and a female, both 26-years-old from [[Prizren]] and [[Obilić]] respectively.<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Konfirmohen edhe dy raste të reja me coronavirus, shkon në 15 numri i të prekurve

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On '''17 March''', a new case was confirmed. A 39-year-old woman from Kosovo's capital, [[Pristina]], who had come from [[London]] to Pristina one day prior was tested positive for coronavirus.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Edhe një rast me coronavirus në Kosovë, duke çuar në 16 numrin e të prekurve
column4: trans-title=Another case with coronavirus in Kosovo, leading to 16 number of those affected
column9: title=E infektuara e fundit me coronavirus është nga Prishtina
column10: trans-title=The last infected with coronavirus is from Pristina
column13: date=17 March 2020}}</ref> Another three new cases of coronavirus were confirmed that same day, when a family member of an infected person from village Dumnica of [[Podujevo]]<ref>{{cite news
column15: title=Personi i 17-të i konfirmuar me coronavirus është nga Dumnica e Podujevës
column16: trans-title=The 17th person confirmed with coronavirus is from Dumnica of Podujevo
column19: date=17 March 2020}}</ref> and a man together with his wife who flew from [[Düsseldorf]] were tested positive for coronavirus.<ref>{{cite news
column21: title=Konfirmohen edhe dy raste, arrinë në 19 numri i të infektuarëve me coronavirus në Kosovë, të infektuarit janë nga Gjakova
column22: trans-title=Two more cases are confirmed, the number of the infected with coronavirus in Kosovo reaches 19, the infected are from Gjakova

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On '''18 March''', a new case was confirmed. A 55-year-old woman from [[Podujevo]] tested positive for coronavirus.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Shkon në 20 numri i personave të prekur me coronavirus në Kosovë
column4: trans-title=The number of people infected with coronavirus in Kosovo reaches 20
column7: date=18 March 2020}}</ref> The evening of that day marked the first coronavirus case free evening since 13 March.<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Lajm i mirë, mbrëmje pa asnjë rast me koronavirus në Kosovë
column10: trans-title=Good news, an evening with no case with coronavirus in Kosovo

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On the night of '''19 March''', a new case was confirmed. A 46-year-old man from the village [[Janjevo]] of [[Lipljan]], who had previously flown from [[Berlin]] to [[Pristina]] eight days prior tested positive for coronavirus.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Konfirmohet edhe një rast me coronavirus në Kosovë – një 46 vjeçar nga Lipjani i kthyer nga Berlini
column4: trans-title=Another case of coronavirus confirmed in Kosovo – a 46-year-old from Lipjan returned from Berlin

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On '''20 March''', a  new case was confirmed. A 67-year-old man from the village [[Llashkadrenoc]] of [[Mališevo]] tested positive for coronavirus.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Edhe një i prekur me coronavirus nga Malisheva – arrin në 22 numri me Covid-19
column4: trans-title=Even one infected with coronavirus from Malishevë – reaches 22, the number with Covid-19
column7: date=20 March 2020}}</ref> Two additional cases of coronavirus were confirmed on the night of that date. A 53-year-old woman from [[Suva Reka]] and a 43-year-old man from [[Gjakova]] tested positive for coronavirus, both contacts of previously confirmed cases and the number of positive cases rose to 24.<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Edhe dy raste të konfirmuara me coronavirus në Kosovë, shkon në 24 numri i të prekurve me Covid-19

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: On '''21 March''', four new cases of coronavirus were confirmed. A 32-year-old man from the village Bibaj of [[Ferizaj]], who had come from [[Germany]] tested positive for coronavirus, while three other cases are contact cases; three women aged 29 and 50 from [[Pristina]] and one aged 40 from [[Gjakova]].<ref>{{cite news

column7: date=21 March 2020}}</ref> Another two new cases of coronavirus were confirmed on the night of same day, a 20-year-old man and a 36-year-old woman from [[Gjilan]] had been tested positive for coronavirus.<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Konfirmohen edhe dy raste me coronavirus në Kosovë, arrin në 30 numri i të infektuarve

→‎Venus flyby,safe,CRS-20,"{{Use America: In the early hours of '''22 March''', a new case was confirmed. A 31-year-old man from the village Senik of [[Mališevo]] tested positive for coronavirus.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Rritet në 31 numri i të prekurve me coronavirus në Kosovë
column4: trans-title=The number of coronavirus infected people increases to 31 in Kosovo
column7: date=22 March 2020}}</ref> On the same day the first death from coronavirus was confirmed. An 82-year-old man from village Dumnica of [[Podujevo]] is the first victim from the pandemic, he had contracted the virus through contact with his son and daughter. Prior to the infection, the victim suffered from cardiac and chronic lung disease and on the sixth day of the infection he had signs of pulmonary infiltration and massive pneumonia on the left side.<ref>{{cite news
column9: title=Shënohet viktima e parë nga koronavirusi në Kosovë, vdiq një 82-vjeçar nga Dumnica
column10: trans-title=The first coronavirus victim in Kosovo marked, an 82-year-old from Dumnica died
